body_text.section: Pathogenesis/cell of origin ::: Inflammation (N) Eye ::: General Terms ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Cell lineage varies with inciting cause.Leukocyte infiltrates or aggregations, associated with adjacent tissue
damage, and may be accompanied by necrosis, vascular inflammation, and
hemorrhage.
body_text.section: Diagnostic Features ::: Inflammation (N) Eye ::: General Terms ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Infiltrate, inflammatory cell
body_text.section: Differential Diagnosis ::: Inflammation (N) Eye ::: General Terms ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Leukocyte infiltrates without other indications of inflammation or tissue
injury.
body_text.section: Differential Diagnosis ::: Inflammation (N) Eye ::: General Terms ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Inflammation should only be used diagnostically when tissue injury or other
indicators of inflammation are present, in addition to leukocytes. Intraocular
inflammation is an indication that a breach in the blood-ocular barrier has
occurred. This is associated with loss of immune deviation (“immune privilege”),
and a conversion from the ocular homeostasis immune suppressive environment to one
that is pro-inflammatory. Intraocular proteins, normally sequestered from the
immune system (preventing establishment of tolerance to self-antigens), may come
under immune surveillance and generate a delayed hypersensitivity response,
resulting in additional ocular injury. Modifiers should be used to designate cell
lineage, and locators to identify tissue type.
body_text.section: Comment ::: Inflammation (N) Eye ::: General Terms ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Mouse; Rat.
body_text.section: Species ::: Mitosis, increased number (N) Eye ::: General Terms ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Mitotic figures, increased
body_text.section: Other Term(s) Used ::: Mitosis, increased number (N) Eye ::: General Terms ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Varies with cell type and location.
body_text.section: Pathogenesis/cell of origin ::: Mitosis, increased number (N) Eye ::: General Terms ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Chromatin in varying stages of division.Cells are typically enlarged as they are for cell division.
body_text.section: Diagnostic Features ::: Mitosis, increased number (N) Eye ::: General Terms ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Neoplasia
body_text.section: Differential Diagnosis ::: Mitosis, increased number (N) Eye ::: General Terms ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Increased numbers of mitotic figures are commonly observed as a reparative or
regenerative process following tissue injury. Mitotic figures are normally
observed in the cornea, which has a high rate of epithelial turn-over. An increase
in incidence occurs following phototoxicity or administration of tubulin
inhibitors. Mitosis can also be observed in the endothelial cells of the
vasculature, epithelial cells of the uvea, and occasionally in cells within the
retina.
body_text.section: Comment ::: Mitosis, increased number (N) Eye ::: General Terms ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Mouse; Rat.
body_text.section: Species ::: Necrosis; Necrosis, single-cell (N) Eye ::: General Terms ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: None
body_text.section: Other Term(s) Used ::: Necrosis; Necrosis, single-cell (N) Eye ::: General Terms ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Often contiguous cells.Cell and organelle swelling.Pyknosis (nuclear condensation; minor component).Karyorrhexis (nuclear fragmentation).Karyolysis (degradation of nuclear material).Cytoplasmic blebs.Plasma membrane rupture.Intracellular contents released into surrounding tissue.Inflammation may be present.
body_text.section: Diagnostic Features ::: Necrosis; Necrosis, single-cell (N) Eye ::: General Terms ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Apoptosis
body_text.section: Differential Diagnoses ::: Necrosis; Necrosis, single-cell (N) Eye ::: General Terms ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Diagnostic nomenclature should follow recommendations from the INHAND
Apoptosis/Necrosis Working Group (Elmore et. al., 2016).
body_text.section: Comment ::: Necrosis; Necrosis, single-cell (N) Eye ::: General Terms ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Mouse; Rat.
body_text.section: Species ::: Neovascularization (N) Eye ::: General Terms ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: New blood vessels; angiogenesis
body_text.section: Other Term(s) Used ::: Neovascularization (N) Eye ::: General Terms ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Neovascularization is characterized by the outgrowth of pre-existing blood
vessels within a region into adjacent ocular tissue that generally is avascular.
Typical regions of the eye subject to neovascularization are the cornea (corneal
neovascularization) and retina (retina neovascularization). Choroidal
neovascularization involves the expansion of choroidal vessels into the retina and
is observed in spontaneous disease of humans with macular degeneration, and in
some animal models. Primary drivers of neovascularization are conditions that
promote anoxia, inflammation, or diseases that have a cytokine milieu (e.g.
metalloproteinases, VEGF, Ang-2) that favors angiogenesis.
body_text.section: Pathogenesis/cell of origin ::: Neovascularization (N) Eye ::: General Terms ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Extension of a blood vessel into a region that should be avascular.May be blind ended (cornea).Evidence of vascular leakage (edema, inflammation). Unlike normal vessels,
vessels produced under these conditions do not have adequate tight
junctions.Associated with other elements of primary disease specific to region.
body_text.section: Diagnostic Features ::: Neovascularization (N) Eye ::: General Terms ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Immunohistochemistry for endothelial cells, pericytes, smooth muscle.Fluorescein angiography in-vivo.
body_text.section: Special Techniques for Diagnostics ::: Neovascularization (N) Eye ::: General Terms ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Angioma; angiosarcoma
body_text.section: Differential Diagnoses ::: Neovascularization (N) Eye ::: General Terms ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Proliferation of capillary channels (capillary hemangioma) of the retina and
optic nerve have been reported in humans. Local ocular vascular tumors are rare in
animals, and there are no reports in rodents.
body_text.section: Differential Diagnoses ::: Neovascularization (N) Eye ::: General Terms ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Vascular hamartomas
body_text.section: Differential Diagnoses ::: Neovascularization (N) Eye ::: General Terms ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Local proliferation of well-formed, non-neoplastic, but redundant blood vessels
within a tissue that is normally vascularized. Vascular harmatomas are considered
to be an embryological malformation. There are no reports in the eyes of
rodents.
body_text.section: Differential Diagnoses ::: Neovascularization (N) Eye ::: General Terms ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Vascular hyperplasia
body_text.section: Differential Diagnoses ::: Neovascularization (N) Eye ::: General Terms ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Local nodular benign proliferation of blood vessels limited to their point of
origin. Not reported for ocular tissues.
body_text.section: Differential Diagnoses ::: Neovascularization (N) Eye ::: General Terms ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Telangiectasia
body_text.section: Differential Diagnoses ::: Neovascularization (N) Eye ::: General Terms ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Dilated blood vessels; may potentially be observed in the conjunctiva.
body_text.section: Differential Diagnoses ::: Neovascularization (N) Eye ::: General Terms ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Neovasularization is a unique phenomenon that results in the sprouting of new
blood vessels from a pre-existing blood supply to an adjacent tissue (e.g.
conjunctiva, retina, optic nerve, choroid). It is driven by a number of local
cytokine and metalloproteinases influences that are upregulated by diseases that
result in anoxia or inflammation within ocular tissues that do not have their own
blood supply. New blood vessels have poorly formed or inadequate tight junctions
and thus leak plasma and proteins into the tissue, severely compromising vision.
Neovascularization can potentially be reversed by removing the inciting cause, and
through treatment with VEGF antagonists, which have proven to be efficacious in
clinical use.
body_text.section: Comment ::: Neovascularization (N) Eye ::: General Terms ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Mouse; Rat.
body_text.section: Species ::: Infiltrate, inflammatory cell, eyelid (N) Eyelid ::: Eyelid ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: None.
body_text.section: Other Term(s) Used ::: Infiltrate, inflammatory cell, eyelid (N) Eyelid ::: Eyelid ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Leukocyte infiltrates without other indications of inflammation (see
general terminology, above).
body_text.section: Diagnositic Features ::: Infiltrate, inflammatory cell, eyelid (N) Eyelid ::: Eyelid ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Inflammation
body_text.section: Differential Diagnosis ::: Infiltrate, inflammatory cell, eyelid (N) Eyelid ::: Eyelid ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Leukocyte infiltrates with features of inflammation (see general
terminology, above).
body_text.section: Differential Diagnosis ::: Infiltrate, inflammatory cell, eyelid (N) Eyelid ::: Eyelid ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Infiltrates are not uncommon at the eyelid dermal or conjunctival margins.
Infiltrates may also be associated with adnexa in the dermis.
body_text.section: Comment ::: Infiltrate, inflammatory cell, eyelid (N) Eyelid ::: Eyelid ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Mouse; Rat.
body_text.section: Species ::: Inflammation, eyelid (N) Eyelid ::: Eyelid ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Blepharitis; blepharoconjunctivitis.
body_text.section: Other Term(s) Used ::: Inflammation, eyelid (N) Eyelid ::: Eyelid ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Leukocyte infiltrates associated with other indications of inflammation
(see general definition above).
body_text.section: Diagnostic Features ::: Inflammation, eyelid (N) Eyelid ::: Eyelid ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Infiltrate, inflammatory cell
body_text.section: Differential Diagnosis ::: Inflammation, eyelid (N) Eyelid ::: Eyelid ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Leukocyte infiltrates without other features of inflammation.
body_text.section: Differential Diagnosis ::: Inflammation, eyelid (N) Eyelid ::: Eyelid ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Inflammation is macroscopically characterized by excessive sebum or keratin
debris adherent to the eyelid margin and eyelashes. Some inbred mouse strains are
affected by blepharoconjunctivitis (Smith, Montagutelli, and Sundberg 1996a). Secondary bacterial infection
is common in affected mice and periorbital abscesses have been reported.
Inflammation of epidermis and adnexal structures of the eyelid as well as common
diseases of rodent skin are covered in the manuscript on Integument (see
Introduction, Mecklenburg et
al. 2013). For information on inflammation of the dermis and stroma of
the eyelid, the reader is referred to the manuscript on Soft Tissue (see
Introduction, Greaves et al.
2013).
body_text.section: Comment ::: Inflammation, eyelid (N) Eyelid ::: Eyelid ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Mouse; Rat.
body_text.section: Species ::: Atrophy, Meibomian gland (N) Eyelid ::: Eyelid ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: None
body_text.section: Other Term(s) Used ::: Atrophy, Meibomian gland (N) Eyelid ::: Eyelid ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Acinar and/or ductal epithelial cells.
body_text.section: Pathogenesis/cell of origin ::: Atrophy, Meibomian gland (N) Eyelid ::: Eyelid ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Irregularly shaped tubules or acini with dilated or reduced lumina.Lined by cuboidal or flattened epithelium.Loss of normal vacuolated cytoplasmic appearance.Interstitial fibrosis may be present.The lumina of the tubules may be filled with desquamated cells and
accumulated sebaceous material.
body_text.section: Diagnostic Features ::: Atrophy, Meibomian gland (N) Eyelid ::: Eyelid ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Atrophy of the Meibomian gland has been reported with deficiency/inhibition of
enzymes involved in fatty acid synthesis (Miyazaki et al. 2001).
body_text.section: Comment ::: Atrophy, Meibomian gland (N) Eyelid ::: Eyelid ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Mouse; Rat.
body_text.section: Species ::: Infiltrate, inflammatory cell, Meibomian gland (N) Eyelid ::: Eyelid ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: None
body_text.section: Other Term(s) Used ::: Infiltrate, inflammatory cell, Meibomian gland (N) Eyelid ::: Eyelid ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Acini and/or ducts and interstitial tissue.
body_text.section: Pathogenesis/cell of origin ::: Infiltrate, inflammatory cell, Meibomian gland (N) Eyelid ::: Eyelid ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Foci of a single inflammatory cell population or a mixture of different
cell types without other features of inflammation.
body_text.section: Diagnostic Features ::: Infiltrate, inflammatory cell, Meibomian gland (N) Eyelid ::: Eyelid ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Minimal to mild infiltrates of neutrophils and lymphocytes are normally present
in the meibomian gland (Yoshitomi and Boorman 1990).
body_text.section: Comment ::: Infiltrate, inflammatory cell, Meibomian gland (N) Eyelid ::: Eyelid ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Mouse; Rat.
body_text.section: Species ::: Inflammation, Meibomian gland (N) Eyelid ::: Eyelid ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: None
body_text.section: Other Term(s) Used ::: Inflammation, Meibomian gland (N) Eyelid ::: Eyelid ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Acini and/or ducts and associated interstitial tissue.
body_text.section: Pathogenesis/cell of origin ::: Inflammation, Meibomian gland (N) Eyelid ::: Eyelid ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Focal or multifocal areas of single or mixed inflammatory cellular
types.Interstitial edema and/or vascular congestion with other indications of
inflammation (see general terminology above).May be associated with squamous metaplasia of acinar/ductal epithelium or
interstitial fibrosis in chronic conditions.Granulomatous or pyogranulomatous inflammation can be observed.
body_text.section: Diagnostic Features ::: Inflammation, Meibomian gland (N) Eyelid ::: Eyelid ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Infiltrate, inflammatory cell, Meibomian gland:
body_text.section: Differential Diagnoses ::: Inflammation, Meibomian gland (N) Eyelid ::: Eyelid ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Foci of single or mixed inflammatory cell types without other features of
inflammation.
body_text.section: Differential Diagnoses ::: Inflammation, Meibomian gland (N) Eyelid ::: Eyelid ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Modifiers are recommended in relation to the predominant inflammatory cellular
type (neutrophilic, eosinophilic, lymphocytic, plasmacytic or histiocytic) or
mixture of different cellular types (mixed). Viral infections tend to result in
multilobular inflammation and may have inclusions present.
body_text.section: Comment ::: Inflammation, Meibomian gland (N) Eyelid ::: Eyelid ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Mouse; Rat.
body_text.section: Species ::: Inflammation, Granulomatous, Meibomian gland (N) Eyelid ::: Eyelid ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Foreign body inflammation; stye; chalazion.
body_text.section: Other Term(s) Used ::: Inflammation, Granulomatous, Meibomian gland (N) Eyelid ::: Eyelid ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Alveoli/ ducts; often spontaneous and/or age-related.
body_text.section: Pathogenesis/cell of origin ::: Inflammation, Granulomatous, Meibomian gland (N) Eyelid ::: Eyelid ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Granulomatous reaction composed of epithelioid macrophages, multinucleated
giant cells, lymphocytes and plasma cells.Foreign body may be present (lipid secretions, released secondary to
blocked ducts).
body_text.section: Diagnostic Features ::: Inflammation, Granulomatous, Meibomian gland (N) Eyelid ::: Eyelid ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Granulomatous inflammatory reactions of the eyelid margin secondary to released
lipid secretions of sebaceous glands of Zeis or Meibomian glands are clinically
referred to as stye and chalazion, respectively.
body_text.section: Comment ::: Inflammation, Granulomatous, Meibomian gland (N) Eyelid ::: Eyelid ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Mouse; Rat.
body_text.section: Species ::: Atrophy, epithelium (N) Cornea: Conjunctiva ::: Cornea/Conjunctiva ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Decreased number of epithelial cells, or decreased cell layers (cornea).
Attenuation is a specific change observed on spectral microscopy for the corneal
endothelium (see below) and should not be used in place of atrophy for the cornea
epithelium.
body_text.section: Other Term(s) Used ::: Atrophy, epithelium (N) Cornea: Conjunctiva ::: Cornea/Conjunctiva ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Corneal or conjunctival epithelial cell; may be drug-induced or incidental.
body_text.section: Pathogenesis/cell of origin ::: Atrophy, epithelium (N) Cornea: Conjunctiva ::: Cornea/Conjunctiva ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Decreased number of cells, and/or cell layers.May be associated with secondary changes, such as edema.
body_text.section: Diagnostic Features ::: Atrophy, epithelium (N) Cornea: Conjunctiva ::: Cornea/Conjunctiva ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Epithelium, regeneration:
body_text.section: Differential Diagnoses ::: Atrophy, epithelium (N) Cornea: Conjunctiva ::: Cornea/Conjunctiva ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Reparative phase following erosion/ulceration (flattened cells covering
ulcerated/eroded area); enlarged epithelial cells with mitotic figures are
present.
body_text.section: Differential Diagnoses ::: Atrophy, epithelium (N) Cornea: Conjunctiva ::: Cornea/Conjunctiva ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Artifact:
body_text.section: Differential Diagnoses ::: Atrophy, epithelium (N) Cornea: Conjunctiva ::: Cornea/Conjunctiva ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Associated with removal of epithelium or endothelium during tissue
processing.
body_text.section: Differential Diagnoses ::: Atrophy, epithelium (N) Cornea: Conjunctiva ::: Cornea/Conjunctiva ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Inhibition of mitosis (such as by chemotherapeutic agents) causes an inability of
basal cells or limbal stem cells to proliferate, leading to decreased numbers of
epithelial cells/layers. The epithelial cells remaining may appear enlarged and/or
disorganized in compensation for fewer cells present. Atrophy does not occur in
the endothelium of the cornea, which consists of a single layer.
body_text.section: Comment ::: Atrophy, epithelium (N) Cornea: Conjunctiva ::: Cornea/Conjunctiva ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Mouse; Rat.
body_text.section: Species ::: Attenuation, endothelium (N) Cornea ::: Cornea/Conjunctiva ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: None.
body_text.section: Other Term(s) Used ::: Attenuation, endothelium (N) Cornea ::: Cornea/Conjunctiva ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Cornea endothelial cells, in regions where cell loss has occurred.
body_text.section: Pathogenesis/cell of origin ::: Attenuation, endothelium (N) Cornea ::: Cornea/Conjunctiva ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Individual endothelial cells flatten and spread out to cover spatial
defects created by endothelial cell loss. This change may not be appreciated
on light microscopy, and is best visualized using spectral microscopy.On cross section, cells are flattened in profile, and appear smaller on
histological examination.Endothelial cell layer may have evidence of cell drop-out.
body_text.section: Diagnostic Features ::: Attenuation, endothelium (N) Cornea ::: Cornea/Conjunctiva ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Decreased numbers of endothelial cells.
body_text.section: Differential Diagnoses ::: Attenuation, endothelium (N) Cornea ::: Cornea/Conjunctiva ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Cell loss without compensatory attenuation; cornea homeostasis is compromised and
thus there is associated corneal edema in regions of spatial defects. Inflammation
may occur secondarily.
body_text.section: Differential Diagnoses ::: Attenuation, endothelium (N) Cornea ::: Cornea/Conjunctiva ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
When endothelial cells are lost due to trauma, disease, or other reasons, the
adjacent cells spread out in an attempt to cover the resulting defect and maintain
cornea homeostasis. Attenuation is commonly observed on the peripheral margins of
the cornea, although it may be difficult to appreciate on histological examination
of cross sections. Attenuation and generalized loss of corneal endothelial cells
are best observed on clinical examination using spectral microscopy. Attenuation
is seen in rats administered the phototoxic agent, 8-methoxypsoralen, followed by
exposure to UV radiation.
body_text.section: Comment ::: Attenuation, endothelium (N) Cornea ::: Cornea/Conjunctiva ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Mouse; Rat.
body_text.section: Species ::: Cyst, inclusion (N) Cornea; Conjunctiva  ::: Cornea/Conjunctiva ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: None
body_text.section: Other Term(s) Used ::: Cyst, inclusion (N) Cornea; Conjunctiva  ::: Cornea/Conjunctiva ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Corneal epithelial cells, organized to form a small cystic structure.
body_text.section: Pathogenesis/cell of origin ::: Cyst, inclusion (N) Cornea; Conjunctiva  ::: Cornea/Conjunctiva ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Cystic space that is lined by well-differentiated epithelial cells within
the cornea.Epithelial cells may be keratinized.Cyst may contain fluid.Leukocyte infitrates or inflammation may be present.
body_text.section: Diagnostic Features ::: Cyst, inclusion (N) Cornea; Conjunctiva  ::: Cornea/Conjunctiva ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Neoplastic lesions (see Papilloma, squamous cell and Carcinoma, squamous
cell).
body_text.section: Differential Diagnoses ::: Cyst, inclusion (N) Cornea; Conjunctiva  ::: Cornea/Conjunctiva ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Pathogenesis has not been determined – may either be congenital or the result of
trauma, followed by disorganized healing (Geiss and Yoshitomi 1999).
body_text.section: Comment ::: Cyst, inclusion (N) Cornea; Conjunctiva  ::: Cornea/Conjunctiva ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Mouse; Rat.
body_text.section: Species ::: Edema (N) Cornea; Conjunctiva ::: Cornea/Conjunctiva ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: None
body_text.section: Other Term(s) Used ::: Edema (N) Cornea; Conjunctiva ::: Cornea/Conjunctiva ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Injury or functional failure of either the endothelium or epithelium of the
cornea; barriers may be intact, or a spatial defect may be evident.
body_text.section: Pathogenesis/cell of origin ::: Edema (N) Cornea; Conjunctiva ::: Cornea/Conjunctiva ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Paleness of the stroma on H&E staining, and irregular expansion of the
collagen fibers.Separation of epithelium or endothelium from the basal lamina.Clear spaces or vacuoles within epithelial cells, or clefts between
epithelial cells (fluid-filled, but may not be evident following tissue
processing).Edema appears as corneal opacification macroscopically.
body_text.section: Diagnostic Features ::: Edema (N) Cornea; Conjunctiva ::: Cornea/Conjunctiva ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Artifact splitting of collagen fibers:
body_text.section: Differential Diagnoses ::: Edema (N) Cornea; Conjunctiva ::: Cornea/Conjunctiva ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Varying degrees of hydration of the sectioned tissues can result in
variable appearance on the slide, leading to incorrect diagnosis of edema in
some instances.
body_text.section: Differential Diagnoses ::: Edema (N) Cornea; Conjunctiva ::: Cornea/Conjunctiva ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Edema often occurs from a functional failure of the corneal endothelium
homeostasis mechanisms, resulting in altered stromal fluid and electrolyte
balance. Fluid may accumulate in both the stroma (altering the arrangement of the
collagen bundles) and in the epithelium. Edema may occur with trauma,
developmental abnormalities, or degenerative age changes. Similar to other
species, rodents lose endothelial cells with age, which may result in osmotic
decompensation. Regardless of cause, corneal edema occurs due to insufficient
endothelial pumping mechanisms.
body_text.section: Comment ::: Edema (N) Cornea; Conjunctiva ::: Cornea/Conjunctiva ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Mouse; Rat.
body_text.section: Species ::: Erosion/ulcer (N) Cornea; Conjunctiva ::: Cornea/Conjunctiva ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: None
body_text.section: Other Term(s) Used ::: Erosion/ulcer (N) Cornea; Conjunctiva ::: Cornea/Conjunctiva ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Corneal/conjunctival epithelium. Associated with trauma, reduced tear production
resulting in dry eyes, topical or gas/vapor caustic agents, and corneal
mineralization. Unregulated, energy independent, passive cell death with leakage
of cytoplasm into surrounding tissue and subsequent inflammatory reaction.
body_text.section: Pathogenesis/cell of origin ::: Erosion/ulcer (N) Cornea; Conjunctiva ::: Cornea/Conjunctiva ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Incomplete loss (erosion) or focal deficit (ulcer) of the surface
epithelium.Histologically, the outer epithelial layer is eroded. Abrasions may be
associated with inflammatory infiltrates and necrosis.Chronic conditions may be associated with corneal neovascularization.Fluorescein positive when examined in-vivo.
body_text.section: Diagnostic Features ::: Erosion/ulcer (N) Cornea; Conjunctiva ::: Cornea/Conjunctiva ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Inflammation (Keratitis):
body_text.section: Differential Diagnoses ::: Erosion/ulcer (N) Cornea; Conjunctiva ::: Cornea/Conjunctiva ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Inflammation of the corneal epithelium and stroma without loss of the
epithelium. Inflammation may facilitate artifact epithelial separation from
the stroma during processing.
body_text.section: Differential Diagnoses ::: Erosion/ulcer (N) Cornea; Conjunctiva ::: Cornea/Conjunctiva ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: artifact:
body_text.section: Differential Diagnoses ::: Erosion/ulcer (N) Cornea; Conjunctiva ::: Cornea/Conjunctiva ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Processing artifacts, such as separation of the cornea epithelium from the
stroma, are common in the eye. A diagnosis of ulcer should be associated
with expectant concurrent findings in the stroma and/or epithelium (e.g.
inflammation, edema).
body_text.section: Differential Diagnoses ::: Erosion/ulcer (N) Cornea; Conjunctiva ::: Cornea/Conjunctiva ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Mineralization (Corneal dystrophy):
body_text.section: Differential Diagnoses ::: Erosion/ulcer (N) Cornea; Conjunctiva ::: Cornea/Conjunctiva ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Dystrophy is the clinical term for accumulation of abnormal material in the
cornea; mineral is most often seen in the rodent. Corneal mineralization may
be associated with inflammation, edema and neovascularization.
Mineralization is most often observed in aged rats.
body_text.section: Differential Diagnoses ::: Erosion/ulcer (N) Cornea; Conjunctiva ::: Cornea/Conjunctiva ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Abrasions may be incidental in rodents, often related to caging conditions or
environmental irritants. Topical acid or alkali burns, gases/vapors, dust or other
foreign particles contacting the eye, and desiccation are all possible causes or
erosion/ulceration. Erosion and necrosis of conjunctival epithelium may be
associated with ocular irritants (Maurer et al. 1998; Maurer and Parker 1996).
body_text.section: Comment ::: Erosion/ulcer (N) Cornea; Conjunctiva ::: Cornea/Conjunctiva ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Mouse; Rat.
body_text.section: Species ::: Fibroplasia (N) Cornea ::: Cornea/Conjunctiva ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Retrocorneal membrane.
body_text.section: Other Term(s) Used ::: Fibroplasia (N) Cornea ::: Cornea/Conjunctiva ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Stromal keratocytes or corneal endothelial cells that have undergone cellular
transdifferentiation (metaplasia) assuming a fibroblast phenotype. Fibroplasia
occurs as a reparative process following injury to the cornea endothelium, and
from the failure of adjacent endothelial cells to adequately cover subsequent
spatial defects.
body_text.section: Pathogenesis/cell of origin ::: Fibroplasia (N) Cornea ::: Cornea/Conjunctiva ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Localized layers of elongated to spindle-shaped cells overlying the inner
surface of the cornea.May be associated with adjacent focal changes to the stroma, such as edema
or inflammation.
body_text.section: Diagnostic Features ::: Fibroplasia (N) Cornea ::: Cornea/Conjunctiva ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Corneal endothelial cells do not regenerate in most species. Corneal fibroplasia
is more likely to occur when there is loss of enough cells to the point that the
endothelium cannot respond adequately to cover a defect.
body_text.section: Comment ::: Fibroplasia (N) Cornea ::: Cornea/Conjunctiva ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Mouse; Rat.
body_text.section: Species ::: Fibrosis, stroma (N) Cornea ::: Cornea/Conjunctiva ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Corneal scar.
body_text.section: Other Term(s) Used ::: Fibrosis, stroma (N) Cornea ::: Cornea/Conjunctiva ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Activated keratocytes.
body_text.section: Pathogenesis/cell of origin ::: Fibrosis, stroma (N) Cornea ::: Cornea/Conjunctiva ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Area within the corneal stroma that microscopically appears as dense
collagenous stroma.Fibrosis may correspond macroscopically to corneal opacity.
body_text.section: Diagnostic Features ::: Fibrosis, stroma (N) Cornea ::: Cornea/Conjunctiva ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Keratocytes are activated following corneal injury and may proliferate to fill in
wound gaps. Activated keratocytes contain smooth muscle actin and may
phenotypically behave similar to myofibroblasts. In these cases high levels of
collagen are produced that lack the organized latticelike structure that is
typical of the translucent cornea, instead forming an opaque extracellular matrix
(ECM) within the defect. Transparency can be restored through cell turn-over, and
replacement with fibroblasts that are capable of producing ECM that contains
sulfated glycosaminoglycans (Hassell and Birk 2010).
body_text.section: Comment ::: Fibrosis, stroma (N) Cornea ::: Cornea/Conjunctiva ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Mouse; Rat.
body_text.section: Species ::: Hypertrophy, Descemet’s membrane (N) Cornea ::: Cornea/Conjunctiva ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Increased thickness, Descemet’s membrane.
body_text.section: Other Term(s) Used ::: Hypertrophy, Descemet’s membrane (N) Cornea ::: Cornea/Conjunctiva ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Spontaneous accumulation of collagen within Descemet’s membrane adjacent to the
corneal endothelium.
body_text.section: Pathogenesis/cell of origin ::: Hypertrophy, Descemet’s membrane (N) Cornea ::: Cornea/Conjunctiva ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Fuch’s Dystrophy (reported in humans):
body_text.section: Differential Diagnoses ::: Hypertrophy, Descemet’s membrane (N) Cornea ::: Cornea/Conjunctiva ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Focal thickenings of Descemet’s membranes associated with endothelial cell
loss.
body_text.section: Differential Diagnoses ::: Hypertrophy, Descemet’s membrane (N) Cornea ::: Cornea/Conjunctiva ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Baned collagen fibers:
body_text.section: Differential Diagnoses ::: Hypertrophy, Descemet’s membrane (N) Cornea ::: Cornea/Conjunctiva ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Secreted by corneal endothelial cells as a sequela to injury or a disease
process. Banded collagen can be differentiated from unbanded collagen using
electron microscopy.
body_text.section: Differential Diagnoses ::: Hypertrophy, Descemet’s membrane (N) Cornea ::: Cornea/Conjunctiva ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Hypertrophy of Descemet’s membrane is occasionally observed in aging mice (Jun, Chakravarti et al. 2006).
body_text.section: Comment ::: Hypertrophy, Descemet’s membrane (N) Cornea ::: Cornea/Conjunctiva ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Mouse; Rat.
body_text.section: Species ::: Infiltrate, inflammatory cell, conjunctiva (N) Cornea; Conjunctiva ::: Cornea/Conjunctiva ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Foci of a single inflammatory cell type or a mixture of different cell
types without other features of inflammation.
body_text.section: Diagnostic Features ::: Infiltrate, inflammatory cell, conjunctiva (N) Cornea; Conjunctiva ::: Cornea/Conjunctiva ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Inflammation
body_text.section: Differential Diagnosis ::: Infiltrate, inflammatory cell, conjunctiva (N) Cornea; Conjunctiva ::: Cornea/Conjunctiva ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Infiltrates of leukocytes associated with inflammatory features such as
edema, hemorrhage and necrosis.
body_text.section: Differential Diagnosis ::: Infiltrate, inflammatory cell, conjunctiva (N) Cornea; Conjunctiva ::: Cornea/Conjunctiva ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Infiltrates of lymphocytes, sometimes with lymphoid follicle formation, are
normally present in the conjunctiva (Yoshitomi and Boorman 1990). Infiltrates
may be seen at the periperhal margins but are not normally observed within the
cornea.
body_text.section: Comment ::: Infiltrate, inflammatory cell, conjunctiva (N) Cornea; Conjunctiva ::: Cornea/Conjunctiva ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Mouse; Rat.
body_text.section: Species ::: Inflammation (N) (Figures 2fig_002fig, 3fig_003fig, 6fig_006fig) Cornea; Conjunctiva ::: Cornea/Conjunctiva ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Keratitis (corneal inflammation); Conjunctivitis (conjunctival inflammation).
body_text.section: Other Term(s) Used ::: Inflammation (N) (Figures 2fig_002fig, 3fig_003fig, 6fig_006fig) Cornea; Conjunctiva ::: Cornea/Conjunctiva ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Inflammatory response due to a variety of possible causes, including injury,
infection (SDAV, Staphylococcus, others), photosensitization, or necrosis. Type of
leukocyte response varies with inciting cause.
body_text.section: Pathogenesis/cell of origin ::: Inflammation (N) (Figures 2fig_002fig, 3fig_003fig, 6fig_006fig) Cornea; Conjunctiva ::: Cornea/Conjunctiva ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Inflammatory cellular infiltrate with associated edema, congestion,
hemorrhage and/or necrosis.May be associated with neovascularization, degenerative or hyperplastic
alterations of the epithelium, fibrosis, or mineralization.
body_text.section: Diagnostic Features ::: Inflammation (N) (Figures 2fig_002fig, 3fig_003fig, 6fig_006fig) Cornea; Conjunctiva ::: Cornea/Conjunctiva ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Infiltrate, inflammatory cell, conjunctiva:
body_text.section: Differential Diagnoses ::: Inflammation (N) (Figures 2fig_002fig, 3fig_003fig, 6fig_006fig) Cornea; Conjunctiva ::: Cornea/Conjunctiva ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Foci of a single population or mixed inflammatory cell types without other
features of inflammation.
body_text.section: Differential Diagnoses ::: Inflammation (N) (Figures 2fig_002fig, 3fig_003fig, 6fig_006fig) Cornea; Conjunctiva ::: Cornea/Conjunctiva ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Modifiers are recommended in relation to the predominant inflammatory cellular
type (neutrophilic, eosinophilic, lymphocytic, plasmacytic or histiocytic) or
mixture of different cellular types (mixed). Ocular irritation is a common
clinical feature (Maurer et al.
1998) and while inflammation may originate in either the conjunctiva or
cornea, it generally extends to both areas. Inflammation of the conjunctiva or
cornea is associated with submucosal or stromal edema respectively, and may result
in erosion/ ulceration, and subsequent regeneration of the epithelium.
body_text.section: Comment ::: Inflammation (N) (Figures 2fig_002fig, 3fig_003fig, 6fig_006fig) Cornea; Conjunctiva ::: Cornea/Conjunctiva ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Mouse; Rat.
body_text.section: Species ::: Keratinization (N) (Figures 3fig_003fig, 5fig_005fig, 10fig_010fig) Cornea ::: Cornea/Conjunctiva ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Cornification; dyskeratosis.
body_text.section: Other Term(s) Used ::: Keratinization (N) (Figures 3fig_003fig, 5fig_005fig, 10fig_010fig) Cornea ::: Cornea/Conjunctiva ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Superficial keratocytes that become cornified with chronic injury.
body_text.section: Pathogenesis/cell of origin ::: Keratinization (N) (Figures 3fig_003fig, 5fig_005fig, 10fig_010fig) Cornea ::: Cornea/Conjunctiva ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Focal regions of the cornea that contain superficial layers of keratin.
body_text.section: Diagnostic Features ::: Keratinization (N) (Figures 3fig_003fig, 5fig_005fig, 10fig_010fig) Cornea ::: Cornea/Conjunctiva ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Keratocytes become progressively flattened as they migrate towards the corneal
surface for removal. Chronic injury is associated with the production of keratin.
Defective tear production and vitamin A deficiency are reported causes of corneal
keratinization.
body_text.section: Comment ::: Keratinization (N) (Figures 3fig_003fig, 5fig_005fig, 10fig_010fig) Cornea ::: Cornea/Conjunctiva ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Mouse; Rat.
body_text.section: Species ::: Mineralization (N) Cornea ::: Cornea/Conjunctiva ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Corneal dystrophy; calcific band keratopathies; dystrophic calcification.
body_text.section: Other Term(s) Used ::: Mineralization (N) Cornea ::: Cornea/Conjunctiva ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Mineralization of the cornea generally occurs secondary to focal injury, but can
also occur with metastatic mineralization. Mineralization can develop due to
incomplete eyelid closure, and subsequent chronic irritation of the cornea.
Mineral formation has also been associated with high ammonia levels due to
urease-positive bacteria in the bedding. Subepithelial mineralization has been
reported in numerous mouse strains (Swiss, BALB/C, C2H, DBA/2, C57BL/6) and rats
(Sprague-Dawley, F344, Wistar).
body_text.section: Pathogenesis/cell of origin ::: Mineralization (N) Cornea ::: Cornea/Conjunctiva ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Mineralization occurs in the subepithelial region or in the anterior stroma
and has a basophilic, extracellular granular to globular appearance on
H&E similar to mineralization elsewhere. Mineralization may be confirmed
with von Kossa stain, if present in sufficient quantity.May be associated with epithelial necrosis, foreign body reaction and
scarring.
body_text.section: Diagnostic Features ::: Mineralization (N) Cornea ::: Cornea/Conjunctiva ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Sequestrum
body_text.section: Differential Diagnoses ::: Mineralization (N) Cornea ::: Cornea/Conjunctiva ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Focal region of divitalized stromal or epithelial tissue surrounded by
vital tissue. Sequestrum has been reported in several species, but the
occurrence in rodents is uncertain.
body_text.section: Differential Diagnoses ::: Mineralization (N) Cornea ::: Cornea/Conjunctiva ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Mineralization appears as punctate opacities in the cornea grossly.
Mineralization may be related to changes in the corneal microenvironment causing
calcium to precipitate. When present in rodents, careful histologic examination of
all major organs should be conducted to see if there is evidence of systemic
mineralization. Most instances of mineralization in rodents do not fit the true
definition of corneal dystrophy, described as spontaneous, non-inflammatory,
bilateral changes with no associated systemic disease. Mouse strains with true
corneal dystrophies include C57BL/10ChPr, Rhino and OEL (Van Winkle 1991).
body_text.section: Comment ::: Mineralization (N) Cornea ::: Cornea/Conjunctiva ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Mouse; Rat.
body_text.section: Species ::: Neovascularization (H) Cornea ::: Cornea/Conjunctiva ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: New blood vessels, cornea.
body_text.section: Other Term(s) Used ::: Neovascularization (H) Cornea ::: Cornea/Conjunctiva ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Neovascularization generally occurs secondary to corneal damage and is often
associated with inflammatory mediators. Blood vessels originate from
extension/proliferation of endothelial cells from the limbal vessels into the
peripheral margins of the corneal stroma and extend centrally into the normally
avascular cornea.
body_text.section: Pathogenesis/cell of origin ::: Neovascularization (H) Cornea ::: Cornea/Conjunctiva ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Blood vessels within normally avascular corneal stroma.May be associated with corneal stromal edema and inflammation as well as
conjunctival congestion.
body_text.section: Diagnostic Features ::: Neovascularization (H) Cornea ::: Cornea/Conjunctiva ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Corneal nerves:
body_text.section: Differential Diagnoses ::: Neovascularization (H) Cornea ::: Cornea/Conjunctiva ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Special stains or IHC to differentiate corneal nerves from non-perfused
blood vessels may be necessary.
body_text.section: Differential Diagnoses ::: Neovascularization (H) Cornea ::: Cornea/Conjunctiva ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Neovascularization may occur spontaneously in older animals; the finding has been
reported in nude (Fox1nu) and hairless
(hr) mice (Smith, Sundberg, and John 2002b; Smith, Hawes et al. 1996b). Vessels may persist
as nonperfused ghost vessels visible on ophthalmic exam as linear opacities.
Neovascularization can be related to deficiencies of tryptophan, riboflavin,
Vitamin A and zinc. In some species, corneal vessels may extend normally beyond
the limbus, and may/may not be perfused.
body_text.section: Comment ::: Neovascularization (H) Cornea ::: Cornea/Conjunctiva ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Mouse; Rat.
body_text.section: Species ::: Pigment (N) Cornea; Conjunctiva ::: Cornea/Conjunctiva ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Extracellular granular or amorphous material deposited within the stroma or
epithelium of the cornea or conjunctiva. Increased pigmentation also occurs from
an increase in number of melanocytes within the tissue, or an increase in
intracellular pigment within the resident epithelial cells.
body_text.section: Pathogenesis/cell of origin ::: Pigment (N) Cornea; Conjunctiva ::: Cornea/Conjunctiva ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Variably sized, shaped and colored aggregates of material, either
cytoplasmic or extracellular.
body_text.section: Diagnostic Features ::: Pigment (N) Cornea; Conjunctiva ::: Cornea/Conjunctiva ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Mineralization
body_text.section: Differential Diagnoses ::: Pigment (N) Cornea; Conjunctiva ::: Cornea/Conjunctiva ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: See above.
body_text.section: Differential Diagnoses ::: Pigment (N) Cornea; Conjunctiva ::: Cornea/Conjunctiva ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Pigment may be endogenous (e.g. melanin), occur from hemorrhage (hemosiderin,
hemoglobin), or derive from exogenous sources (e.g.foreign body). Increased
pigmentation associated with an increase in melanin granules can occur with
chronic irritation or trauma. Melanin granules can be found intracellular within
intraepithelial melanocytes (which may increase in number following injury) or
corneal epithelial cells (thought to acquire melanin from melanocytes), or as
extracellular deposits (McCracken and Klintworth 1976). Extracellular deposits of brown-colored
metabolic intermediates in the cornea epithelium or stroma occurred with
administration of chlorpromazine and other phenothiazine deritives, and pigment
changes have been reported with exposure to gold, mercury and analine dyes (Hogan and Zimmerman 1962).
Potential vision effects vary with severity and location; pigmentation within the
perilimbal region has no impact to vision, and pigmentation in the central cornea
may go unnoticed to the patient if minimal. Pigmentation resolves over time with
removal of the stimulus and when intracellular, with cell turnover.
body_text.section: Comment ::: Pigment (N) Cornea; Conjunctiva ::: Cornea/Conjunctiva ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Mouse; Rat.
body_text.section: Species ::: Vacuolation, epithelium or endothelium (N) ::: Cornea/Conjunctiva ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Lipidosis; phospholipidosis.
body_text.section: Other Term(s) Used ::: Vacuolation, epithelium or endothelium (N) ::: Cornea/Conjunctiva ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Lysosomal accumulation of lipid or other substances (including
glycosaminoglycans, mucopolysaccharides and others) within the cytoplasm of
epithelial cells, endothelial cells, or keratocytes. These are generally removed
during tissue processing, resulting in the appearance of clear vacuolated spaces
on light microscopy.
body_text.section: Pathogenesis/cell of origin ::: Vacuolation, epithelium or endothelium (N) ::: Cornea/Conjunctiva ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Clear cytoplasmic vacuoles following tissue processing.Phospholipidosis causes lipid-like vacuoles in corneal epithelial cells and
keratocytes; bluish granules may be observed on H&E staining.
body_text.section: Diagnostic Features ::: Vacuolation, epithelium or endothelium (N) ::: Cornea/Conjunctiva ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Semi-thin sections followed by Toluidine Blue staining: irregular
cytoplasmic inclusions are seen with phospholipidosis.Electron microscopy: typical lamellar and crystalline inclusions of
phospholipidosis.
body_text.section: Special Techniques for Diagnostics ::: Vacuolation, epithelium or endothelium (N) ::: Cornea/Conjunctiva ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Artifact vacuolation
body_text.section: Differential Diagnoses ::: Vacuolation, epithelium or endothelium (N) ::: Cornea/Conjunctiva ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Vacuolation resulting from edema (see above; Figure 2)
body_text.section: Differential Diagnoses ::: Vacuolation, epithelium or endothelium (N) ::: Cornea/Conjunctiva ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Vacuolation may be drug-induced. Some cationic amphiphilic drugs can cause
phospholipidosis of the corneal epithelium and/or corneal endothelium. Tilorone
can cause phospholipidosis and mucopolysaccharidosis (MPS) in rats. Lysosomal
storage diseases result in the abnormal accumulation of substances, most often
glycosaminoglycans, within cells. MPS VII, caused by a deficiency in
Bglucuronidase, is an autosomal recessive mutation reported to occur in homozygous
mice (gusmps/gusmps) (Smith, Sundberg, and John 2002b). Lysosomal
accumulation may result in corneal opacities that are grossly visible on
ophthalmic examination.
body_text.section: Comment ::: Vacuolation, epithelium or endothelium (N) ::: Cornea/Conjunctiva ::: Nonproliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Mouse; Rat.
body_text.section: Species ::: Malformation, filtration angle (N) FA/TM ::: Congenital ::: Filtration Angle/Trabecular Meshwork ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Pectinate ligament dysplasia; mesodermal dysgenesis, goniodysgenesis.
body_text.section: Other Term(s) Used ::: Malformation, filtration angle (N) FA/TM ::: Congenital ::: Filtration Angle/Trabecular Meshwork ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Malformation occurs from a failure in development of the spaces forming the
trabecular meshwork.
body_text.section: Pathogenesis/cell of origin ::: Malformation, filtration angle (N) FA/TM ::: Congenital ::: Filtration Angle/Trabecular Meshwork ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Secondary alterations of the drainage angle:
body_text.section: Differential Diagnoses ::: Malformation, filtration angle (N) FA/TM ::: Congenital ::: Filtration Angle/Trabecular Meshwork ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Due to iridal-trabecular adhesion, trabecular collapse, trabecular
fibrosis, or proliferation of the cells that line the trabecular
meshwork.
body_text.section: Differential Diagnoses ::: Malformation, filtration angle (N) FA/TM ::: Congenital ::: Filtration Angle/Trabecular Meshwork ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Malformation of the filtration angle significantly impacts aqueous fluid outflow,
and can result in glaucoma. Abnormalities of the aqueous plexus and the trabecular
meshwork occur in Foxc1 and Foxc2 mutant mice (Smith, Sundberg, and John 2002b).
body_text.section: Comment ::: Malformation, filtration angle (N) FA/TM ::: Congenital ::: Filtration Angle/Trabecular Meshwork ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Mouse; Rat.
body_text.section: Species ::: Narrowed filtration angle (N) FA/TM ::: Acquired ::: Filtration Angle/Trabecular Meshwork ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Compaction of trabecular beams; collapse, trabecular meshwork.
body_text.section: Other Term(s) Used ::: Narrowed filtration angle (N) FA/TM ::: Acquired ::: Filtration Angle/Trabecular Meshwork ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Displacement, compression or collapse of the trabecular beams, reducing or
obliterating the spaces between the beams.
body_text.section: Pathogenesis/cell of origin ::: Narrowed filtration angle (N) FA/TM ::: Acquired ::: Filtration Angle/Trabecular Meshwork ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Reduced space between the trabeculae, compaction of trabecular beams, and
partial or complete obliteration of aqueous plexus.The presence of cells and/or material within the drainage angle/trabecular
meshwork.Enlargement and/or distortion of the eye if aqueous flow is sufficiently
impaired.
body_text.section: Diagnostic Features ::: Narrowed filtration angle (N) FA/TM ::: Acquired ::: Filtration Angle/Trabecular Meshwork ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Malformation, filtration angle
body_text.section: Differential Diagnoses ::: Narrowed filtration angle (N) FA/TM ::: Acquired ::: Filtration Angle/Trabecular Meshwork ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Malformations are best observed on ophthalmoscopy.
body_text.section: Differential Diagnoses ::: Narrowed filtration angle (N) FA/TM ::: Acquired ::: Filtration Angle/Trabecular Meshwork ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
A narrow filtration angle is associated with increased resistance in aqueous
humour outflow and IOP, clinically causing glaucoma. Glaucoma is more commonly
observed spontaneously in larger species, but can be induced experimentally in
rodents. The trabecular meshwork is scant in rodents and spontaneous collapse
apparently is rare. However, iridal-cornea adhesion can block the outflow of
aqueous humor to a degree that the filtration angle collapses on itself. Following
laser photocoagulation, the iris may scar to the angle over the meshwork
(iridal-trabecular adhesion), and hyphema of the anterior chamber or atrophy of
the ciliary body may occur (Levkovitch-Verbin, Quigley et al.
2002). Collapse of the trabecular meshwork may be experimentally induced
in animal glaucoma models (i.e. laser photocoagulation) (Ueda, Sawaguchi et al. 1998, Levkovitch-Verbin, Quigley et al.
2002). Substances such as cells (red blood cells and leukocytes), free
pigment, melanocytes or macrophages containing pigment, or test material that has
been administered into the aqueous or vitreous humour may become lodged within the
meshwork and impede aqueous flow.
body_text.section: Comment ::: Narrowed filtration angle (N) FA/TM ::: Acquired ::: Filtration Angle/Trabecular Meshwork ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Mouse; Rat.
body_text.section: Species ::: Inflammation (N) Anterior Chamber; Aqueous Humor ::: Acquired ::: Filtration Angle/Trabecular Meshwork ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Inflammation, anterior segment; uveitis
body_text.section: Other Term(s) Used ::: Inflammation (N) Anterior Chamber; Aqueous Humor ::: Acquired ::: Filtration Angle/Trabecular Meshwork ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Recruitment of leukocytes originating from the systemic circulation.
body_text.section: Pathogenesis/cell of origin ::: Inflammation (N) Anterior Chamber; Aqueous Humor ::: Acquired ::: Filtration Angle/Trabecular Meshwork ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
The presence of leukocytes of single or mixed cell type in the anterior
chamber.Generally associated with increased protein in the aqueous appearing as
eosinophilic fluid.Severe inflammation may appear as flocculent fluid and/or contain beads or
strands of fibrin.
body_text.section: Diagnostic Features ::: Inflammation (N) Anterior Chamber; Aqueous Humor ::: Acquired ::: Filtration Angle/Trabecular Meshwork ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: None
body_text.section: Differential Diagnoses ::: Inflammation (N) Anterior Chamber; Aqueous Humor ::: Acquired ::: Filtration Angle/Trabecular Meshwork ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Leukocytes are not found in the anterior chamber without inflammation in some
other part of the eye, e.g. the cornea, uvea, or vitreous. However on occasion it
may be possible to observe residual inflammatory cells following an inflammatory
insult that have yet to be cleared from the anterior chamber, or that have
migrated from the posterior to the anterior chamber.
body_text.section: Comment ::: Inflammation (N) Anterior Chamber; Aqueous Humor ::: Acquired ::: Filtration Angle/Trabecular Meshwork ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Mouse; Rat.
body_text.section: Species ::: Proteineous fluid (N) Anterior Chamber; Aqueous Humor ::: Acquired ::: Filtration Angle/Trabecular Meshwork ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Increased protein
body_text.section: Other Term(s) Used ::: Proteineous fluid (N) Anterior Chamber; Aqueous Humor ::: Acquired ::: Filtration Angle/Trabecular Meshwork ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye
