body_text.text: Vascular compromise within the uveal tissues of the anterior segment.
body_text.section: Pathogenesis/cell of origin ::: Proteineous fluid (N) Anterior Chamber; Aqueous Humor ::: Acquired ::: Filtration Angle/Trabecular Meshwork ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Generally associated with increased protein in the aqueous appearing as
eosinophilic fluid.Lack of other inflammatory features.Aqueous may contain beads or strands of fibrin.
body_text.section: Diagnostic Features ::: Proteineous fluid (N) Anterior Chamber; Aqueous Humor ::: Acquired ::: Filtration Angle/Trabecular Meshwork ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: None
body_text.section: Differential Diagnoses ::: Proteineous fluid (N) Anterior Chamber; Aqueous Humor ::: Acquired ::: Filtration Angle/Trabecular Meshwork ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
The aqueous normally has a low protein content and increases are generally
associated with an inflammatory process within the uveal tissues of the anterior
segment (ciliary body, iris). However, on occasion an increase in protein may be
observed in the eye without other indications of inflammation (drug
administration, needle insertion). Increased protein is diagnosed as ‘flare’ on
ophthalmoscopy.
body_text.section: Comment ::: Proteineous fluid (N) Anterior Chamber; Aqueous Humor ::: Acquired ::: Filtration Angle/Trabecular Meshwork ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Mouse; Rat.
body_text.section: Species ::: Adhesion, iris (N) Uvea: Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Congenital ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Iridocorneal fibroplasia or strands; iridal-corneal adhesion. Adhesions may be
congenital or acquired.
body_text.section: Other Term(s) Used ::: Adhesion, iris (N) Uvea: Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Congenital ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Adhesions between the anterior edge of the iris and the endothelium of the cornea
(anterior synechia) or the posterior edge of the iris and the anterior surface of
the lens (posterior synechia).
body_text.section: Pathogenesis/cell of origin ::: Adhesion, iris (N) Uvea: Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Congenital ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Adherence of the iris to the cornea or lens (on ophthalmoscopy observed as
anterior and posterior synechia, respectively). Anterior adhesions to the
cornea can potentially block the outflow of the aqueous humor through the
filtration angle causing increased intraocular pressure and glaucoma (Ramos, Attar, et al.
2017).Peripheral anterior synechia refers to a condition in which the iris
adheres to the angle. Failure of aqueous drainage may result from peripheral
anterior adhesions in conditions such as uveitis (Williams 2007).Pigment on the anterior lens capsule suggests prior occurrence of posterior
adhesions.Adhesions may cause opacities in either the cornea or lens (Foster 1958).
body_text.section: Diagnostic Features ::: Adhesion, iris (N) Uvea: Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Congenital ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Artifact
body_text.section: Differential Diagnosis ::: Adhesion, iris (N) Uvea: Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Congenital ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Artifacts associated with tissue processing can result in displacement of
the iris; pigment on the anterior lens capsule or corneal endothelium may
also occur as an artifact of processing.
body_text.section: Differential Diagnosis ::: Adhesion, iris (N) Uvea: Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Congenital ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Adhesions can be detected on examination through topical instillation of a
mydriatic agent; distortion of the pupil occurs upon pupil dilation. Acquired
adhesions are most often observed as a sequela to anterior uveitis, but may also
occur with trauma, or can be experimentally induced by laser photocoagulation
(Ueda, Sawaguchi et al.
1998). Spontaneous adhesions are observed in SD rats (Taradach and Greaves 1984), but are rare
in the mouse. Adhesions in older mice are usually a sequela of inflammation in the
anterior segment. Posterior adhesions in mice are often associated with cataracts
(Geiss and Yoshitomi
1999). The etiology of congenital adhesions is not well understood.
Synechia is a clinical ophthalmic term, and should not be used as a histological
diagnosis.
body_text.section: Comment ::: Adhesion, iris (N) Uvea: Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Congenital ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Mouse; Rat.
body_text.section: Species ::: Hypoplasia, ciliary body (N) Uvea: Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Congenital ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Reduced size, ciliary body
body_text.section: Other Term(s) Used ::: Hypoplasia, ciliary body (N) Uvea: Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Congenital ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Myofibrils of the ciliary body; dysgenesis associated with defects in Fibrillin-2
(Fbn2) gene.
body_text.section: Pathogenesis/cell of origin ::: Hypoplasia, ciliary body (N) Uvea: Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Congenital ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Decreased size of ciliary body – often segmental.Associated with a decreased number of folds on EM examination.
body_text.section: Diagnostic Features ::: Hypoplasia, ciliary body (N) Uvea: Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Congenital ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Atrophy, Ciliary Body
body_text.section: Differential Diagnosis ::: Hypoplasia, ciliary body (N) Uvea: Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Congenital ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Degeneration, Ciliary Body
body_text.section: Differential Diagnosis ::: Hypoplasia, ciliary body (N) Uvea: Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Congenital ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
In either atrophy or degeneration, a loss of tissue mass occurs secondary
to traumatic or inflammatory injury, or to another disease process.
body_text.section: Differential Diagnosis ::: Hypoplasia, ciliary body (N) Uvea: Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Congenital ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Reported in Fbn2 -/- mice (Shi, Tu
et al. 2013b). Hypoplasia of the ciliary body is associated with
anatomical defects in the iris.
body_text.section: Comment ::: Hypoplasia, ciliary body (N) Uvea: Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Congenital ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Mouse; Rat.
body_text.section: Species ::: Malformation, iris (N) Uvea: Iris and Cilary Body ::: Congenital ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Coloboma (iris, or posterior); dyscoria.
body_text.section: Other Term(s) Used ::: Malformation, iris (N) Uvea: Iris and Cilary Body ::: Congenital ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Failure of closure in the optic fissure can cause malformations resulting in
small holes, spatial defects, or other irregularities to the iris.
body_text.section: Pathogenesis/cell of origin ::: Malformation, iris (N) Uvea: Iris and Cilary Body ::: Congenital ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
The rodent iris contains scant stroma and has a narrow-curved profile on
cross section. Malformations can appear as irregular expansions of the
stroma, or as blunting or folding at the inner margin. Spatial defects may
be recognized as irregularities in either the posterior or anterior surface
on histopathology; differentiation from tissue processing artifact is
facilitated by advanced knowledge of clinical findings.Posterior or choroidal coloboma is a spatial defect of the choroidal blood
vessels near the optic nerve, and may occur simultaneously with iris
malformation in congenital cases. In these occurrences, the regional sensory
retina and RPE are not developed, and the retina vasculature is
distorted.
body_text.section: Diagnostic Features ::: Malformation, iris (N) Uvea: Iris and Cilary Body ::: Congenital ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Abnormalities in pupil shape:
body_text.section: Differential Diagnoses ::: Malformation, iris (N) Uvea: Iris and Cilary Body ::: Congenital ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Associated with inflammation of the anterior uvea.
body_text.section: Differential Diagnoses ::: Malformation, iris (N) Uvea: Iris and Cilary Body ::: Congenital ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Iridal malformations in young rodents (especially mice) appear as an abnormality
in pupil shape (spatial defect in the iris), and is clinically diagnosed as
pupillary dyscoria (Rubin and Daly
1982). Careful sectioning is important to capture spatial defects
histologically. Coloboma is a clinical term, and should not be used as a
histological diagnosis. Localized developmental errors may lead to spatial
defects/holes in other specific ocular structures such as the choroid and optic
nerve. They can occur in association with microphthalmia (Geiss and Yoshitomi 1999; Williams 2002).
body_text.section: Comment ::: Malformation, iris (N) Uvea: Iris and Cilary Body ::: Congenital ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Mouse; Rat.
body_text.section: Species ::: Persistent pupillary membrane (N) Uvea: Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Congenital ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Persistent pupillary strands; iridal fetal membrane.
body_text.section: Other Term(s) Used ::: Persistent pupillary membrane (N) Uvea: Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Congenital ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Vessels and mesenchyme of the pupillary membrane.
body_text.section: Pathogenesis/cell of origin ::: Persistent pupillary membrane (N) Uvea: Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Congenital ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Collagenous or membranous strand of tissues found in the anterior or
posterior chamber, or spanning across the pupillary opening (Heywood 1973).Strands of tissue may appear on cross section as free-floating, or can be
tethered at one or more places to the iris, lens, or cornea.
body_text.section: Diagnostic Features ::: Persistent pupillary membrane (N) Uvea: Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Congenital ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Persistent embryonic lens vasculature:
body_text.section: Differential Diagnoses ::: Persistent pupillary membrane (N) Uvea: Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Congenital ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
A more likely diagnosis if associated with the presence of blood in the
anterior segment.
body_text.section: Differential Diagnoses ::: Persistent pupillary membrane (N) Uvea: Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Congenital ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: iridal fibroplasia
body_text.section: Differential Diagnoses ::: Persistent pupillary membrane (N) Uvea: Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Congenital ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Persistent pupillary membranes are remnant vascular strands of the developing
iris that fail to undergo postnatal atrophy; they are best diagnosed on
ophthalmoscopy. Membranes may be free-floating, bridge the iris, or extend from
the iris to the lens or cornea where they are associated with focal opacity of the
lens, or corneal opacity, respectively (Taradach, Regnier et al. 1981). They may be
observed in Sprague-Dawley rats, Crj:CD (SD) rats, and in mice, and individuals
with this finding should be excluded from ocular studies. Persistent pupillary
membranes may block the filtration angle, impair aqueous drainage, and cause
pupil-block glaucoma (Young et al.
1974; Williams
2007).
body_text.section: Comment ::: Persistent pupillary membrane (N) Uvea: Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Congenital ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Mouse; Rat.
body_text.section: Species ::: Atrophy, iris (N) Uvea: Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Degenerative ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Degeneration, iris
body_text.section: Other Term(s) Used ::: Atrophy, iris (N) Uvea: Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Degenerative ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Iris stroma.
body_text.section: Pathogenesis/cell of origin ::: Atrophy, iris (N) Uvea: Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Degenerative ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Decreased size of iris associated with reduction in stroma and blood
vessels.Iris may appear irregular in size or shape circumferentially on cross
section.Irregular contours may suggest the presence of spatial defects within the
stroma.Enlarged posterior epithelial cells containing prominent pigment
granules.Pupillary sphincter and ciliary processes appear hypertrophic.
body_text.section: Diagnostic Features ::: Atrophy, iris (N) Uvea: Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Degenerative ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Iris atrophy is best diagnosed on ophthalmic examination and can readily be
recognized due to distortions of the pupil size and shape and poor response to
miotics. As the iris atrophies, small holes in the stroma appear initially,
followed by coalescence, and the stroma appears increasingly disorganized as
mesodermal tissue and blood vessels regress. Iris atrophy occurs in the (C57L X
A/He) F1 mouse (Geiss and
Yoshitomi 1999), and may occur in association with glaucoma in aging
DBA/2J mice (Smith, Sundberg, and
John 2002b).
body_text.section: Comment ::: Atrophy, iris (N) Uvea: Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Degenerative ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Mouse; Rat.
body_text.section: Species ::: Atrophy, ciliary body (N) Uvea: Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Degenerative ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Degeneration, ciliary body
body_text.section: Other Term(s) Used ::: Atrophy, ciliary body (N) Uvea: Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Degenerative ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Ciliary body myofibrils.
body_text.section: Pathogenesis/cell of origin ::: Atrophy, ciliary body (N) Uvea: Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Degenerative ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Decreased size and/or decreased numbers of myofibrils within the ciliary
body.Fragmentation of myofibrils and detachment of the sarcoplasma may be
observed on electron microscopy.
body_text.section: Diagnositic Features ::: Atrophy, ciliary body (N) Uvea: Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Degenerative ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Atrophy of the ciliary body muscle has been described in aged Wistar rats (Eiben and Liebich 1989) and
may occur in other rodents. Atrophy of the ciliary muscle may result in
distortions of the iris, and pupil size and shape.
body_text.section: Comment ::: Atrophy, ciliary body (N) Uvea: Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Degenerative ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Mouse; Rat.
body_text.section:
Species ::: Congestion (N) (figure 12fig_012fig) Uvea: Iris
and Ciliary Body ::: Acquired ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: None
body_text.section:
Other Term(s) Used ::: Congestion (N) (figure 12fig_012fig) Uvea: Iris
and Ciliary Body ::: Acquired ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Microvasculature of the iris.
body_text.section:
Pathogenesis/cell of origin ::: Congestion (N) (figure 12fig_012fig) Uvea: Iris
and Ciliary Body ::: Acquired ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Dilated vessels with the presence of erythrocytes (congestion as a
histological diagnosis should be avoided due to the common occurrence of
postmortem pooling of blood within the microvasculature).
body_text.section:
Diagnostic Features ::: Congestion (N) (figure 12fig_012fig) Uvea: Iris
and Ciliary Body ::: Acquired ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Vascular dilation:
body_text.section:
Differential Diagnoses ::: Congestion (N) (figure 12fig_012fig) Uvea: Iris
and Ciliary Body ::: Acquired ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Associated with inflammation.
body_text.section:
Differential Diagnoses ::: Congestion (N) (figure 12fig_012fig) Uvea: Iris
and Ciliary Body ::: Acquired ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Artifact of postmortem blood pooling
body_text.section:
Differential Diagnoses ::: Congestion (N) (figure 12fig_012fig) Uvea: Iris
and Ciliary Body ::: Acquired ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Iridal blood circulation is best assessed on clinical examination using
ophthalmoscopy. Dilation of iridal vessels, with or without the presence of
erythrocytes, can occur irrespective of physiological status of the eye at time of
euthanasia. Iritis is a clinical term associated with vascular congestion observed
on ophthalmoscopy irrespective of the presence of inflammation, and should not be
used as a histological diagnosis.
body_text.section:
Comment ::: Congestion (N) (figure 12fig_012fig) Uvea: Iris
and Ciliary Body ::: Acquired ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Mouse; Rat.
body_text.section: Species ::: Infiltrate, inflammatory cell (N) Uvea: Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Acquired ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: None
body_text.section: Other Term(s) Used ::: Infiltrate, inflammatory cell (N) Uvea: Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Acquired ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Leukocytes that have entered the eye via the uveal vessels of the ciliary body
and iris.
body_text.section: Pathogenesis/cell of origin ::: Infiltrate, inflammatory cell (N) Uvea: Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Acquired ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Infiltrates of leukocytes in the ciliary body or processes, and iris stroma
and/or epithelium.Inflammatory features are not present.
body_text.section: Diagnostic Features ::: Infiltrate, inflammatory cell (N) Uvea: Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Acquired ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Mononuclear cells, including lymphocyte aggregates, are found spontaneously in
uveal tissues.
body_text.section: Comment ::: Infiltrate, inflammatory cell (N) Uvea: Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Acquired ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Mouse; Rat.
body_text.section: Species ::: Inflammation (N) Uvea: Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Acquired ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: None
body_text.section: Other Term(s) Used ::: Inflammation (N) Uvea: Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Acquired ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Leukocytes that have entered the eye via the uveal vessels of the ciliary body
and iris. Cell lineage varies with inciting cause.
body_text.section: Pathogenesis/cell of origin ::: Inflammation (N) Uvea: Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Acquired ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Infiltrates of leukocytes in the ciliary body or processed, and iris stroma
and/or epithelium.Inflammatory features such as edema and expansion of the stroma,
hemorrhage, and/or necrosis are present.Vascular involvement is usually evident with inflammation (activated
endothelia, damage to vascular walls, perivascular infiltrates).
body_text.section: Diagnostic Features ::: Inflammation (N) Uvea: Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Acquired ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Inflammation is the preferred diagnostic term used with appropriate modifiers as
to cell type when features of inflammation are present. Inflammation of the iris
or ciliary body may be associated with aqueous leukocytes and protein, which
appear as irregular regions of eosinophilic, amorphous fluid in the anterior
compartment of the eye. Leakage of protein into the aqueous is diagnosed as
‘flare’ on ophthalmic examination. Inflammation of the iris indicates a breach in
the blood-ocular barrier, and a possible loss of immune deviation. Uveitis is a
clinical term and should not be used as a histological diagnosis.
body_text.section: Comment ::: Inflammation (N) Uvea: Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Acquired ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Mouse; Rat.
body_text.section: Species ::: Pigment, increased/decreased, iris (N) Uvea: Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Acquired ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Discoloration, iris; alteration in iris color
body_text.section: Other Term(s) Used ::: Pigment, increased/decreased, iris (N) Uvea: Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Acquired ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Change in the number of melanocytes within the stroma, or the quantity of pigment
granules within the melanocytes. Only relevant in pigmented species or
strains.
body_text.section: Pathogenesis/cell of origin ::: Pigment, increased/decreased, iris (N) Uvea: Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Acquired ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Increased numbers or size of melanocytes in the iris stroma.If decreased pigmentation, decreased number of melanocytes or decreased
amount of pigment within melanocytes.
body_text.section: Diagnostic Features ::: Pigment, increased/decreased, iris (N) Uvea: Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Acquired ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Sequel to hemorrhage (hemosiderin).
body_text.section: Differential Diagnoses ::: Pigment, increased/decreased, iris (N) Uvea: Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Acquired ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Pigment changes can occur following administration of compounds (for example
urethane in neonatal hooded rats; Roe,
Millican et al. 1963). Decreased pigmentation may be associated with
inflammation, edema, and aging. Pigment changes can also be congenital (Schafer and Render 2013b).
Increased pigment deposition occurs in DBA/2J mice homozygous for iris pigment
dispersion or iris stromal atrophy (Smith, Sundberg, and John 2002b). Increased pigment and/or a change in
pigment may also occur with topical application of prostanoid compounds such as
latanoprost.
body_text.section: Comment ::: Pigment, increased/decreased, iris (N) Uvea: Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Acquired ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Mouse; Rat.
body_text.section: Species ::: Vacuolation, cytoplasmic, epithelial (N) Uvea: Iris and Ciliary body ::: Acquired ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Lysosomal storage disease, varies with cause (e.g., phospholipidosis).
body_text.section: Other Term(s) Used ::: Vacuolation, cytoplasmic, epithelial (N) Uvea: Iris and Ciliary body ::: Acquired ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Epithelium of the iris or ciliary body processes. Metabolic defect leading to
accumulation of molecules within the epithelial cells of iris, ciliary body
processes, or ciliary muscle.
body_text.section: Pathogenesis/cell of origin ::: Vacuolation, cytoplasmic, epithelial (N) Uvea: Iris and Ciliary body ::: Acquired ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Vacuolated spaces within the cytoplasm of the epithelial cells of the iris
or ciliary processes, or within the ciliary muscle.
body_text.section: Dianostic Features ::: Vacuolation, cytoplasmic, epithelial (N) Uvea: Iris and Ciliary body ::: Acquired ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Cystine crystal accumulation has been reported in the ciliary body stroma and
process epithelium of CTNS -/- mice, an animal model for cystinosis lysosomal
storage disease (Kalatzis,
Serratrice et al. 2007).
body_text.section: Comment ::: Vacuolation, cytoplasmic, epithelial (N) Uvea: Iris and Ciliary body ::: Acquired ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Mouse; Rat.
body_text.section: Species ::: Degeneration, lens fiber (N) Lens ::: Lens ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Lens fiber swelling; lens fiber fragmentation; Morgagnian globule; bladder cells;
liquefaction; cleft formation; cataract.
body_text.section: Other Term(s) Used ::: Degeneration, lens fiber (N) Lens ::: Lens ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Degeneration results from biochemical changes that alter the homeostasis of the
lens, denature the proteins of the lens, and/or disrupt the integrity of the lens
fiber. The initial biochemical change is often acidification, whereupon fibers
lose fluid, shrink, and fluid collects in clefts between fibers. With other
pathogeneses, such as with osmotic changes, the fibers will instead swell and
become globular (‘Morgagnian globules’). Degeneration is a diagnostic term that
encompasses many of the specific terms listed below.
body_text.section: Pathogenesis/cell of origin ::: Degeneration, lens fiber (N) Lens ::: Lens ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Clefts - spaces form between lens fibers, which have a rounded profile,
with accumulation of fluid with variable amounts of protein. Lens fibers may
fragment if the lesion progresses.Fragmentation – swollen, membrane-bound fragments; rounded globules
(Morgagnian globules).Liquefaction – collection of proteinaceous fluid within the lens cortex as
small pockets or larger areas, in place of lens fibers.In severe cases, may be associated with dystrophic mineralization.
body_text.section: Diagnostic Features ::: Degeneration, lens fiber (N) Lens ::: Lens ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Artifact:
body_text.section: Differential Diagnoses ::: Degeneration, lens fiber (N) Lens ::: Lens ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
It is important to recognize artifact lens fiber fragmentation due to
fixation, which is often angular, and may result in cleft formation (this is
most notable in nonhuman primate eyes fixed with modified Davidson’s fluid).
Careful comparison to concurrent controls is necessary.
body_text.section: Differential Diagnoses ::: Degeneration, lens fiber (N) Lens ::: Lens ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Autolysis
body_text.section: Differential Diagnoses ::: Degeneration, lens fiber (N) Lens ::: Lens ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Vacuolation
body_text.section: Differential Diagnoses ::: Degeneration, lens fiber (N) Lens ::: Lens ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: See below
body_text.section: Differential Diagnoses ::: Degeneration, lens fiber (N) Lens ::: Lens ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
‘Degeneration’ may be used as an aggregate diagnostic term to include many of the
nonspecific changes observed in the lens fibers, while more specific changes are
best described as comments. In advanced disease the cortical fibers are completely
liquefied and lost, and the nucleus of the lens is free floating in the lens
capsule. Cataract is a clinical diagnostic term used to describe opacities
visualized on ophthalmic examination, and should not be used as a histological
diagnosis.
body_text.section: Comment ::: Degeneration, lens fiber (N) Lens ::: Lens ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Mouse; Rat.
body_text.section: Species ::: Dislocation, lens, anterior or posterior (N) Lens ::: Lens ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Lens luxation; lens displacement.
body_text.section: Other Term(s) Used ::: Dislocation, lens, anterior or posterior (N) Lens ::: Lens ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Rupture of zonular fibers (suspensory ligament of the lens) that suspend the lens
behind the iris. Primary occurrence may be related to hereditary zonulary
weakness. Spontaneous occurrence may be secondary to trauma, glaucoma,
inflammation, and neoplasia.
body_text.section: Pathogenesis ::: Dislocation, lens, anterior or posterior (N) Lens ::: Lens ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
On histology, the lens is displaced either into the anterior chamber
(anterior luxation) or posterior compartment (posterior luxation).Chronic dislocation may be associated with secondary changes, such as
inflammation, vitreal fibroplasia, and iridal-lens adhesions.
body_text.section: Diagnostic Features ::: Dislocation, lens, anterior or posterior (N) Lens ::: Lens ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Artifact:
body_text.section: Differential Diagnoses ::: Dislocation, lens, anterior or posterior (N) Lens ::: Lens ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Associated with processing, particularly trimming.
body_text.section: Differential Diagnoses ::: Dislocation, lens, anterior or posterior (N) Lens ::: Lens ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Posterior luxation may be associated with secondary trauma to the retina and
cataract formation. Anterior luxation may be associated with adhesions between the
anterior lens and posterior iris (synechia) or with the corneal endothelium.
Fibroblastic transdifferentiation (metaplasia) of the anterior lens epithelial
cells may occur as a sequela (Tanaka, Inagaki et al. 1995). Due to the frequent occurrence of artifact
displacement of the lens during tissue processing, this diagnosis should be made
with caution.
body_text.section: Comment ::: Dislocation, lens, anterior or posterior (N) Lens ::: Lens ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Mouse; Rat.
body_text.section:
Species ::: Fibroplasia, lens epithelium (N) (Figure
19fig_019fig) Lens ::: Lens ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Metaplasia, fibrous, or cellular-transdifferentiation, lens epithelium.
body_text.section:
Other Term(s) Used ::: Fibroplasia, lens epithelium (N) (Figure
19fig_019fig) Lens ::: Lens ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Injury to the lens and subsequent cellular transdifferentiation (metaplasia) of
the anterior lenticular epithelium.
body_text.section:
Pathogenesis/cell of origin ::: Fibroplasia, lens epithelium (N) (Figure
19fig_019fig) Lens ::: Lens ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Spindloid cells and an eosinophilic collagenous matrix in place of the lens
epithelium and subjacent lens fibers.Linear arrays of collagen.
body_text.section:
Diagnostic Features ::: Fibroplasia, lens epithelium (N) (Figure
19fig_019fig) Lens ::: Lens ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Hyperplasia, Lens epithelium
body_text.section:
Differential Diagnosis ::: Fibroplasia, lens epithelium (N) (Figure
19fig_019fig) Lens ::: Lens ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: See below. (Figures 18, 56)
body_text.section:
Differential Diagnosis ::: Fibroplasia, lens epithelium (N) (Figure
19fig_019fig) Lens ::: Lens ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Fibrosis
body_text.section:
Differential Diagnosis ::: Fibroplasia, lens epithelium (N) (Figure
19fig_019fig) Lens ::: Lens ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: If mature collagen is present.
body_text.section:
Differential Diagnosis ::: Fibroplasia, lens epithelium (N) (Figure
19fig_019fig) Lens ::: Lens ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Following injury, the anterior lens epithelium assumes a myofibroblast-like
phenotype that produces type I and type III collagen and glycosaminoglycans,
forming fibrous tissue. Fibroplasia often occurs in association with hyperplasia
of the anterior lenticular epithelium. A new lens capsule may be secreted over the
fibrotic region following maturation.
body_text.section:
Comment ::: Fibroplasia, lens epithelium (N) (Figure
19fig_019fig) Lens ::: Lens ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Mouse; Rat.
body_text.section: Species ::: Hypertrophy, lens capsule (N) Lens ::: Lens ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Increased size, lens capsule.
body_text.section: Other Term(s) Used ::: Hypertrophy, lens capsule (N) Lens ::: Lens ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Anterior lenticular epithelium.
body_text.section: Pathogenesis/cell of origin ::: Hypertrophy, lens capsule (N) Lens ::: Lens ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Increased thickness of lens capsule.May be uniform (age-related) or focal (possible response to injury).
body_text.section: Diagnostic Features ::: Hypertrophy, lens capsule (N) Lens ::: Lens ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
The anterior lenticular epithelium continues to produce lens capsule material for
the life of the animal, i.e., the anterior lens capsule will continue to thicken
with age in the animal, while the posterior lens capsule does not.
body_text.section: Comment ::: Hypertrophy, lens capsule (N) Lens ::: Lens ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Mouse; Rat.
body_text.section: Species ::: Hypertrophy, lens epithelium (N) Lens ::: Lens ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Increased size, lens epithelium.
body_text.section: Other Term(s) Used ::: Hypertrophy, lens epithelium (N) Lens ::: Lens ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Injury to the anterior lenticular epithelium.
body_text.section: Pathogenesis/cell of origin ::: Hypertrophy, lens epithelium (N) Lens ::: Lens ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Enlarged or swollen cell profile.Often associated with adjacent swollen, pale lens fiber.
body_text.section: Diagnostic Features ::: Hypertrophy, lens epithelium (N) Lens ::: Lens ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Vacuolation, associated with inclusions.
body_text.section: Differential Diagnosis ::: Hypertrophy, lens epithelium (N) Lens ::: Lens ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Swollen lens fibers are most commonly seen in the area of the nuclear bow,
particularly in association with damage caused by exposure to phototoxicants and
UVA light. Bright eosinophilic spherical globules of denatured proteins
(Morgagnian globules), may be present.
body_text.section: Comment ::: Hypertrophy, lens epithelium (N) Lens ::: Lens ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Mouse; Rat.
body_text.section: Species ::: Hypertrophy, lens fiber (N) Lens ::: Lens ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Increased size/swelling of lens fiber; degeneration of lens fiber; ‘bladder
cells’.
body_text.section: Other Term(s) Used ::: Hypertrophy, lens fiber (N) Lens ::: Lens ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Fluid intake by lens fibers most often occurs due to hyperosmotic conditions.
body_text.section: Pathogenesis/cell of origin ::: Hypertrophy, lens fiber (N) Lens ::: Lens ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Swelling of lens fiber can vary from scattered individual fiber profiles
that are increased in size, to numerous, enlarged fusiform cells with foamy
cytoplasm (‘bladder cells’).Variable eosinophilic staining.
body_text.section: Diagnostic Features ::: Hypertrophy, lens fiber (N) Lens ::: Lens ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Degeneration
body_text.section: Differential Diagnosis ::: Hypertrophy, lens fiber (N) Lens ::: Lens ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: See above
body_text.section: Differential Diagnosis ::: Hypertrophy, lens fiber (N) Lens ::: Lens ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Increased glucose or other simple sugars, among other agents, can promote fluid
intake resulting in swollen fibers. Swollen lens fibers may not produce opacities
identifiable on ophthalmic examination, and may potentially be reversible. Simple
sugars passively diffuse into the lens fibers, but once inside, they are actively
reduced by aldose reductase (AR), which has high activity in the lens fibers.
Glucose is converted to sorbitol, which does not readily diffuse out of the lens
fiber. Significant accumulation of sorbitol within the fiber creates a
hyperosmotic environment that results in passive diffusion of fluid into the
fiber. Swelling may be irreversible with agents that are not metabolized by the
lens fiber. Degeneration results (see above) if the change progresses and there is
denaturation and coagulation of crystalline proteins, or if breaks occur in the
fiber membrane.
body_text.section: Comment ::: Hypertrophy, lens fiber (N) Lens ::: Lens ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Mouse; Rat.
body_text.section: Species ::: Inflammation, lens (N) Lens ::: Lens ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Phacoclastic uveitis.
body_text.section: Other Term(s) Used ::: Inflammation, lens (N) Lens ::: Lens ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Leukocyte infiltrates (neutrophilic and/or granulomatous) within the lens.
body_text.section: Pathogenesis/cell of origin ::: Inflammation, lens (N) Lens ::: Lens ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Accumulation of neutrophils and/or macrophages into and around the
lens.Lens fibers associated with the inflammatory cells are often liquefied or
fragmented.
body_text.section: Diagnostic Features ::: Inflammation, lens (N) Lens ::: Lens ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Leukocyte infitrates into the lens are generally not innocuous, and thus
invariably imply the presence of inflammation. Infectious processes are common
causes. Injury to the lens can result in inflammation but more often results in
proliferation of the anterior lens capsule. Phacoclastic uveitis is a clinical
term associated with rupture of the lens and inflammation.
body_text.section: Comment ::: Inflammation, lens (N) Lens ::: Lens ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Mouse; Rat.
body_text.section:
Species ::: Mineralization, lens fiber (N) (Figures
14fig_014fig, 21fig_021fig) Lens ::: Lens ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Calcification; dystrophic mineralization/calcification.
body_text.section:
Other Term(s) Used ::: Mineralization, lens fiber (N) (Figures
14fig_014fig, 21fig_021fig) Lens ::: Lens ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Injury to, or degeneration of, lens fibers resulting in mineral deposition, or
calcification of the damaged tissue.
body_text.section:
Pathogenesis/cell of origin ::: Mineralization, lens fiber (N) (Figures
14fig_014fig, 21fig_021fig) Lens ::: Lens ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Lens fibers have intensely basophilic granules or crystalline material.
body_text.section:
Diagnostic Features ::: Mineralization, lens fiber (N) (Figures
14fig_014fig, 21fig_021fig) Lens ::: Lens ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Mineral deposition or calcification is not an uncommon sequela to degenerative
changes of the lens, particularly those that result in devitalization of the
tissue.
body_text.section:
Comments ::: Mineralization, lens fiber (N) (Figures
14fig_014fig, 21fig_021fig) Lens ::: Lens ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Mouse; Rat.
body_text.section: Species ::: Necrosis, lens epithelium (N) Lens ::: Lens ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Anterior lenticular epithelium toxicant or inflammatory injury.
body_text.section: Pathogenesis/cell of origin ::: Necrosis, lens epithelium (N) Lens ::: Lens ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
See features of single cell necrosis described above.Focal, multifocal, or diffuse loss of anterior lenticular epithelium may
occur.
body_text.section: Diagnostic Features ::: Necrosis, lens epithelium (N) Lens ::: Lens ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Antineoplastics and radiomimetics can cause necrosis (or apoptosis) of the
anterior lenticular epithelium.
body_text.section: Comment ::: Necrosis, lens epithelium (N) Lens ::: Lens ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Mouse; Rat.
body_text.section: Species ::: Rupture, lens capsule (N) Lens ::: Lens ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: None
body_text.section: Other Term(s) Used: ::: Rupture, lens capsule (N) Lens ::: Lens ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Posterior lens capsule.
body_text.section: Pathogenesis/cell of origin ::: Rupture, lens capsule (N) Lens ::: Lens ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Extruded lens fibers (into the vitreous) from the posterior aspect of the
lens.Spatial defect or break in posterior lens capsule evident on
histopathology.Free ends of the lens fibers tend to coil away from the site of the
break.Adjacent lens fibers tend to have degenerative features.
body_text.section: Diagnostic Features ::: Rupture, lens capsule (N) Lens ::: Lens ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Artifact
body_text.section: Differential Diagnoses ::: Rupture, lens capsule (N) Lens ::: Lens ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Spontaneous rupture of the lens capsule can occur in rodents as early as 10 weeks
of age and is usually in the posterior portion of the lens since it is thinner
than the anterior lens capsule (Tanaka, Inagaki et al. 1996). Rupture may also occur in association with
cataracts or trauma. Rupture of the capsule can be associated with a significant
inflammatory response in the vitreous and lens.
body_text.section: Comment ::: Rupture, lens capsule (N) Lens ::: Lens ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Mouse; Rat.
body_text.section: Species ::: Vacuolation, lens epithelium or lens fiber (N) Lens ::: Lens ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Phospholipidosis.
body_text.section: Other Term(s) Used ::: Vacuolation, lens epithelium or lens fiber (N) Lens ::: Lens ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Vacuolation of lens epithelium or fibers is associated with cytoplasmic
inclusions that generally represent lysomal accumulation of molecules.
body_text.section: Pathogenesis/cell of origin ::: Vacuolation, lens epithelium or lens fiber (N) Lens ::: Lens ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Foamy vacuolation of the cytoplasm of the anterior lens epithelium.Vacuoles are non-staining or contain lightly amphiphilic material.
body_text.section: Diagnostic Features ::: Vacuolation, lens epithelium or lens fiber (N) Lens ::: Lens ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Hypertrophy, Lens epithelium or Hypertrophy, Lens fiberlens Fiber
liquification
body_text.section: Differential Diagnoses ::: Vacuolation, lens epithelium or lens fiber (N) Lens ::: Lens ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Definitive diagnosis may require electron microscopy to demonstrate the presence
of electron-dense lamellar inclusions within lysosomes. Several drugs are known to
cause phospholipidosis resulting in lysomal accumulation of both the drug and
cationic amphiphilic molecules in either the lens epithelium or lens fibers.
body_text.section: Comment ::: Vacuolation, lens epithelium or lens fiber (N) Lens ::: Lens ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Mouse; Rat.
body_text.section: Species ::: Agenesis, vitreous (N) Vitreous ::: Vitreous ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Development anomaly; absent vitreous
body_text.section: Other Term(s) Used ::: Agenesis, vitreous (N) Vitreous ::: Vitreous ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Agenesis of the vitreous is associated with other ocular development disorders
that result in microphthalmia.
body_text.section: Pathogenesis/cell of origin ::: Agenesis, vitreous (N) Vitreous ::: Vitreous ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: The eye is markedly smaller then normal (microphthalmia).Internal structures are malformed, rudimentary, or absent.
body_text.section: Diagnostic Features ::: Agenesis, vitreous (N) Vitreous ::: Vitreous ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Development of the vitreous is closely associated with that of the lens, retina,
and retinal vasculature and thus development abnormalties in any one structure are
reflected in the other structures, including the vitreous (Kingston et. al., 2014). Mutations in Pax6,
Mitf, Cat4 and other genes have been implicated in the occurance in mice (Smith et al., 1994; Smith, John, and Nishina 2002;
Collinson et al, 2000).
While failure of the development of the vitreous has been reported in mice in
association with microphthalmia (Smith, Roderick, Sundberg 1994), it is also possible that development of
the primary vitreous may begin, but not be completed. Other potential causes
include infectious diseases and toxicities. Experimental exposure to alcohol is a
model for fetal alcohol syndrome in which microphthalmia occurs.
body_text.section: Comment ::: Agenesis, vitreous (N) Vitreous ::: Vitreous ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Mouse; Rat.
body_text.section: Species ::: Persistent hyaloid vessels (N) Vitreous ::: Vitreous ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Persistent primary vitreous.
body_text.section: Other Term(s) Used ::: Persistent hyaloid vessels (N) Vitreous ::: Vitreous ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Embryonic hyaloid vessels that fail to completely involute and regress.
body_text.section: Pathogenesis/cell of origin ::: Persistent hyaloid vessels (N) Vitreous ::: Vitreous ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Generally, only small remnants (1-5 arteries) or a single vessel with
multiple branches extending from the optic disc into the vitreous cavity are
observed.Vessels may extend from the optic disc through the vitreous to contact the
posterior pole of the lens.Hyaloid vessels that extend along the inner surface of the sensory retina
from the optic disc to the lens have also been reported (Heywood 1973).Hemorrhage in the vitreous may be an associated finding in rats.
body_text.section: Diagnostic Features ::: Persistent hyaloid vessels (N) Vitreous ::: Vitreous ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Persistence of a portion of the embryonic hyaloid vessels is a congenital finding
reported in rats (Hebel and
Stromberg 1976, Taradach, Regnier et al. 1981, Taradach and Greaves 1984, Rubin 1986, Kuno, Usui et al. 1991, Shibuya, Satou et al. 1999, Williams 2002). Hyaloid vasculature
gradually undergoes involution, especially during the first 6 weeks; the incidence
is less than 1% by the end of one year (Heywood 1973). Mice have a similar hyaloid system as rats do that
generally regresses by 30 days (Smith, John, and Nishina 2002). Intravitreal hemorrhage does not appear
to be as common in mice as it is in rats (Rubin 1986).
body_text.section: Comment ::: Persistent hyaloid vessels (N) Vitreous ::: Vitreous ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Mouse; Rat.
body_text.section: Species ::: Persistent hyperplastic primary vitreous (N) Vitreous ::: Vitreous ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: PHPV; persistent fetal vasculature (PFV).
body_text.section: Other Term(s) Used ::: Persistent hyperplastic primary vitreous (N) Vitreous ::: Vitreous ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Development anomaly that occurs from failure of the embryological vitreous and
hyaloid vasculature (used in formation of the fetal eye) to regress.
body_text.section: Pathogenesis/cell of origin ::: Persistent hyperplastic primary vitreous (N) Vitreous ::: Vitreous ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Excess mesenchymal tissue; often associated with persistent hyaloid
vessels.Generally fibrous tissue, but may be cartilaginous tissue.Blood vessels and mesenchymal tissue extend from the optic disc to the
posterior capsule of the lens near the posterior pole where it blends into
the embryonic vessel, the posterior tunic vasculosa lentis (hyperplastic
tunica vasculosa lentis).
body_text.section: Diagnostic Features ::: Persistent hyperplastic primary vitreous (N) Vitreous ::: Vitreous ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Mutations are a common cause of persistent hyperplastic primary vitreous in mice
(Smith, John, and Nishina
2002).
body_text.section: Comment ::: Persistent hyperplastic primary vitreous (N) Vitreous ::: Vitreous ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Mouse; Rat.
body_text.section: Species ::: Fibroplasia; Fibrosis, vitreous (N) Vitreous ::: Vitreous ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Vitreal membranes; fibrovascular tissue proliferation.
body_text.section: Other Term(s) Used ::: Fibroplasia; Fibrosis, vitreous (N) Vitreous ::: Vitreous ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Multiple cell origins have been implicated in the formation of vitreal membranes
including hyalocytes, spindle cells associated with zonule fibrils, Müller cells,
glial cells, and RPE. Current thinking is that these cells transdifferentiate and
acquire phenotypic characteristics of fibroblasts or myofibroblasts with
contractile proteins.
body_text.section: Pathogenesis/cell of origin ::: Fibroplasia; Fibrosis, vitreous (N) Vitreous ::: Vitreous ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Linear strands of cells with a fibroplastic phenotype located anywhere
within the vitreous.Linear arrays of fibrillary collagenous tissue strands, often multilayered,
that resemble a mat of fibrous connective tissue.Fibroplastic strands of tissue frequently tether to fixed structures such
as the lens, retina, and optic disc.Vitreal fibroplasia is often associated with chronic inflammation,
hypertrophic hyalocytes, and pigmented hyalocytes.
body_text.section: Diagnostic Features ::: Fibroplasia; Fibrosis, vitreous (N) Vitreous ::: Vitreous ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Fibrosis:
body_text.section: Differential Diagnosis ::: Fibroplasia; Fibrosis, vitreous (N) Vitreous ::: Vitreous ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Mature collagen of relatively low cellularity is present; fibrosis is more
likely to be observed in end-stage lesions.
body_text.section: Differential Diagnosis ::: Fibroplasia; Fibrosis, vitreous (N) Vitreous ::: Vitreous ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Cell transdifferentiation, proliferation, and migration are thought to occur in
the eye in a similar manner to fibrotic reactions that occur systemically.
Cytokines, in particular TGBβ, have been ascribed a primary role in the process.
Fibroblastic membranes tend to tether to fixed ocular tissues, such as the lens,
retina, and optic nerve disc. Because they contain contractile proteins, tension
is transferred to these structures, and can result in lens luxation, retinal
detachments, and optic nerve prolapse. Vitreal membranes appear as vitreal
opacities on ophthalmic examination. In rats, vitreous fibroplasia occurs with or
without vessels, and may be accompanied by hemorrhage, pigmentladen macrophages
and inflammatory cells (Taradach and Greaves 1984). Fibrovascularization, or organization of the
vitreous body, has also been reported in F344 rats with advanced retinal
degeneration (Yoshitomi and
Boorman 1990), and likely represents a similar pathogenesis. Vitreal
fibroplasia tends to be a dynamic and progressive process. The presence of mature
collagen may warrant a diagnosis of fibrosis.
body_text.section: Comment ::: Fibroplasia; Fibrosis, vitreous (N) Vitreous ::: Vitreous ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Mouse; Rat.
body_text.section:
Species ::: Hemorrhage (N) (Figure 29fig_029fig)
Vitreous ::: Vitreous ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: None
body_text.section:
Other Term(s) Used ::: Hemorrhage (N) (Figure 29fig_029fig)
Vitreous ::: Vitreous ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Intraocular blood vessels.
body_text.section:
Histiogenesis/cell of origin ::: Hemorrhage (N) (Figure 29fig_029fig)
Vitreous ::: Vitreous ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Presence of erythrocytes, ranging from a population of scattered cells to
large aggregates, accompanied by serum.
body_text.section:
Diagnostic Features ::: Hemorrhage (N) (Figure 29fig_029fig)
Vitreous ::: Vitreous ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Erythrocytes, Extravasation
body_text.section:
Differential diagnosis ::: Hemorrhage (N) (Figure 29fig_029fig)
Vitreous ::: Vitreous ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Breakdown of tight junctions between endothelial cells of retinal blood
vessels.
body_text.section:
Differential diagnosis ::: Hemorrhage (N) (Figure 29fig_029fig)
Vitreous ::: Vitreous ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
A common source of spontaneous hemorrhage in young animals is a patent vascular
hyaloid. Erythrocytes may be derived from patent hyaloid vessels for 3 weeks or
more following birth (Hebel
and Stromberg 1976). Small numbers of erythrocytes and small clots that
vary in size eventually resolve, generally without sequelae (Rubin, 1986).
body_text.section:
Comment ::: Hemorrhage (N) (Figure 29fig_029fig)
Vitreous ::: Vitreous ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Mouse; Rat.
body_text.section:
Species ::: Hemosiderin-laden macrophages (N) (Figures
29fig_029fig, 30fig_030fig, 31fig_031fig) Vitreous ::: Vitreous ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: None
body_text.section:
Other Term(s) Used: ::: Hemosiderin-laden macrophages (N) (Figures
29fig_029fig, 30fig_030fig, 31fig_031fig) Vitreous ::: Vitreous ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Hemorrhage from any cause may result in red blood cell engulfment and processing
by hyalocytes (resident macrophages) or recruited macrophages (similar to that
observed systemically). Patent hyaloid vessels are a potential source of RBCs.
body_text.section:
Pathogenesis/cell of origin ::: Hemosiderin-laden macrophages (N) (Figures
29fig_029fig, 30fig_030fig, 31fig_031fig) Vitreous ::: Vitreous ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Hyalocytes and macrophages containing brown pigmented granules are
observed, primarily in the cortical vitreous, wherever hyalocytes
concentrate (i.e. adjacent to posterior retina and optic disc).
body_text.section:
Diagnostic Features ::: Hemosiderin-laden macrophages (N) (Figures
29fig_029fig, 30fig_030fig, 31fig_031fig) Vitreous ::: Vitreous ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Because of the slow turnover of fluid and cellular components of the vitreous,
cells containing hemosiderin may persist in the vitreous for prolonged periods of
time following the occurrence of hemorrhage.
body_text.section:
Comment ::: Hemosiderin-laden macrophages (N) (Figures
29fig_029fig, 30fig_030fig, 31fig_031fig) Vitreous ::: Vitreous ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Mouse; Rat.
body_text.section: Species ::: Infiltrate, inflammatory cell (N) Vitreous ::: Vitreous ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Hyalitis (if limited to increased numbers of hyalocytes) and infiltration,
inflammatory cell, if additional leukocytes are present.
body_text.section: Other Term(s) Used ::: Infiltrate, inflammatory cell (N) Vitreous ::: Vitreous ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Varies with cell lineage and inciting cause.Increased numbers of hyalocytes.Leukocytes recruited from the systemic circulation; can be observed near
the retinal surface as part of the immune surveillance process of the
eye.
body_text.section: Diagnostic Features ::: Infiltrate, inflammatory cell (N) Vitreous ::: Vitreous ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
As resident macrophages, hyalocytes are responsible for clearing debris from the
vitreous, and are responsive to perturbations within the eye, especially the
vitreous. Increased numbers and increased variability in appearance is associated
with intravitreal injections in the absence of other inflammatory cell types
suggesting that changes in hyalocytes can be sensitive indicator of subtle changes
in the eye. Due to the slow turnover rate of the vitreous, hyalocytes and other
inflammatory cells tend to have a prolonged presence in the vitreous, lasting well
beyond that of the inciting cause.
body_text.section: Comment ::: Infiltrate, inflammatory cell (N) Vitreous ::: Vitreous ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Mouse; Rat.
body_text.section: Species ::: Inflammation (N) (Figures 27fig_027fig, 30fig_030fig) Vitreous ::: Vitreous ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Vitritis.
body_text.section: Other Term(s) Used ::: Inflammation (N) (Figures 27fig_027fig, 30fig_030fig) Vitreous ::: Vitreous ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Varies with cell lineage and inciting cause.
body_text.section: Diagnostic Features ::: Inflammation (N) (Figures 27fig_027fig, 30fig_030fig) Vitreous ::: Vitreous ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Leukocytes derived from the systemic circulation.Leukocytes are most often observed on histopathology at or near the retinal
surface, posterior to the lens, or near the optic disc, but can also be
observed throughout the vitreous.Recruited leukocytes typically result from secondary spread of inflammation
from other structures of the globe (Taradach and Greaves 1984).Granulomatous inflammation may result in cellular aggregates within the
vitreous that appear as opacities on ophthalmic examination.
body_text.section: Diagnostic Features ::: Inflammation (N) (Figures 27fig_027fig, 30fig_030fig) Vitreous ::: Vitreous ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Ocular inflammation can occur from a number of inciting causes, including
infectious and immune-mediated diseases, metabolic disorders, toxicities, and
trauma. Inflammation in the vitreous implies a breach of the BOB, and loss of
immune deviation. Cytokine changes to the intraocular environment that are
associated with inflammatory conditions can induce transdifferentiation of ocular
cells and result in fibroplasia (vitreous or retinal/epiretinal fibroplasia).
body_text.section: Comment ::: Inflammation (N) (Figures 27fig_027fig, 30fig_030fig) Vitreous ::: Vitreous ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Mouse; Rat.
body_text.section: Species ::: Metaplasia, bone or cartilage (N) Vitreous ::: Vitreous ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Osseous metaplasia; cartilaginous metaplasia; cellular transdifferentiation.
body_text.section: Other Term(s) Used ::: Metaplasia, bone or cartilage (N) Vitreous ::: Vitreous ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Transdifferentiation of a cell population to bone or cartlilage.
body_text.section: Pathogenesis/cell of origin ::: Metaplasia, bone or cartilage (N) Vitreous ::: Vitreous ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Presence of bone or cartilage matrix in the vitreous body (Taradach and Greaves
1984).
body_text.section: Diagnostic Features ::: Metaplasia, bone or cartilage (N) Vitreous ::: Vitreous ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Mineralization
body_text.section: Differential Diagnosis ::: Metaplasia, bone or cartilage (N) Vitreous ::: Vitreous ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: See below.
body_text.section: Differential Diagnosis ::: Metaplasia, bone or cartilage (N) Vitreous ::: Vitreous ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Mechanism of intraocular bone or cartilage formation is poorly understood, but
may be seen with ocular trauma, or possibly conditions that result in anoxia and
degeneration of the vitreous. Cellular transdifferentiation requires the
elaboration of appropriate cytokines that favor bone or cartilage production. Both
mineralization and bone or cartilage metaplasia result in vitreal opacities on
ophthalmic examination.
body_text.section: Comment ::: Metaplasia, bone or cartilage (N) Vitreous ::: Vitreous ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Mouse; Rat.
body_text.section: Species ::: Mineralization, vitreous (N) Vitreous ::: Vitreous ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Metastatic mineralization or calcification; dystrophic calcification.
body_text.section: Other Term(s) Used ::: Mineralization, vitreous (N) Vitreous ::: Vitreous ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
