Vitreous matrix, or cells within the vitreous. Deposition of calcium salts within
the vitreous.
body_text.section: Pathogenesis/cell of origin ::: Mineralization, vitreous (N) Vitreous ::: Vitreous ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Irregular deposits of mineral; may be located anywhere within the
vitreous.May be accompanied by degenerative features in adjacent ocular structures
(dystrophic calcification).
body_text.section: Diagnostic Features ::: Mineralization, vitreous (N) Vitreous ::: Vitreous ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Vitreous metaplasia, Bone or Cartilage
body_text.section: Differential Diagnosis ::: Mineralization, vitreous (N) Vitreous ::: Vitreous ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: See above.
body_text.section: Differential Diagnosis ::: Mineralization, vitreous (N) Vitreous ::: Vitreous ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Mineral deposition in the vitreous is similar to that which occurs systemically
from two different processes: a) systemic metabolic disorder of calcium regulation
resulting in deposition of calcium salts in otherwise normal tissue (metastatic
calcification or mineralization), and b) deposition of calcium in tissue as a
degenerative process or secondary to trauma (dystrophic calcification). Conditions
that favor a dystrophic process include the presence of divitalized cells, and/or
conditions that result in anoxia and degeneration of the vitreous.
body_text.section: Comment ::: Mineralization, vitreous (N) Vitreous ::: Vitreous ::: Uvea, Iris and Ciliary Body ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Mouse; Rat.
body_text.section: Species ::: Retinal rosettes (N) Retina ::: Congenital ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Retinal dysplasia; linear retinopathy; retinochoroidal degeneration; retinal
dystrophy; retinal anomaly.
body_text.section: Other Term(s) Used ::: Retinal rosettes (N) Retina ::: Congenital ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Non-specific response to diverse stimuli that affect retinal cell differentiation
during development.
body_text.section: Pathogenesis/cell of origin ::: Retinal rosettes (N) Retina ::: Congenital ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Focal to multifocal rosette-like and tubular structures expanding and
distorting the inner and outer nuclear layers.Rarely lesions can diffusely affect the retina.Rosette-like and tubular structures can present variable morphology with a
combination of the following features:One to multiple layers of cells with nuclear profiles similar to neurons of
the inner and outer nuclear layers.Nuclei polarized away from the center or “lumen” of the rosette.Eosinophilic linear structures resembling photoreceptors inner segments
and/or ciliated cells from primitive neuroepithelial origin may be observed
in the inner layer of the rosette.Presence of a basement membrane-like structure near the center of the
rosette resembling the external limiting membrane of the retina.RPE-like cells or macrophages may be in the center of the rosette.
body_text.section: Diagnostic Features ::: Retinal rosettes (N) Retina ::: Congenital ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Retinal folds
body_text.section: Differential Diagnoses ::: Retinal rosettes (N) Retina ::: Congenital ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: See below.
body_text.section: Differential Diagnoses ::: Retinal rosettes (N) Retina ::: Congenital ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Artifact of processing:
body_text.section: Differential Diagnoses ::: Retinal rosettes (N) Retina ::: Congenital ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Differential-rate fixation of the vitreous and retina can lead to vitreous
shrinkage and retinal traction, creating artifact rosettes.
body_text.section: Differential Diagnoses ::: Retinal rosettes (N) Retina ::: Congenital ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Retinal rosettes are a focal or multifocal disorganization of the sensory retina
due to faulty development. In the rat rosettes appear as unilateral linear
elevations of the retina on ophthalmic examination (Hubert, Gillet et al. 1994) and can be induced
by the administration of cytosine arabinose, cycasin, N-methyl-N-nitrosurea and
trimethyltin (Schafer and
Render 2013a). Retinal rosettes (and folds, see below) may not have all
layers of the retina intact, often show loss of the outer nuclear layer, and may
have direct abutment of the retina onto the choroid or even the sclera (Schafer and Render
2013a).
body_text.section: Comment ::: Retinal rosettes (N) Retina ::: Congenital ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Mouse; Rat.
body_text.section: Species ::: Retinal folds (N) Retina ::: Congenital ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: None
body_text.section: Other Term(s) Used: ::: Retinal folds (N) Retina ::: Congenital ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Incidental, spontaneous, or associated with traction from fibroblastic membranes
at the retinal surface and subretinal hemorrhage.
body_text.section: Pathogenesis/cell of origin ::: Retinal folds (N) Retina ::: Congenital ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Focal inward projections of the retina with possible separation of the
photoreceptor from the retinal pigmented epithelium.Less severe lesions affect only the outer retinal layers and present as
micro-retinal detachment, with subretinal accumulation of phagocytic cells
and do not affect the retinal surface contour.More severe folds affect all retinal layers, and can exhibit with
subretinal hemorrhage and debris from the photoreceptor outer segments.
body_text.section: Diagnostic Features ::: Retinal folds (N) Retina ::: Congenital ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Artifact retinal fold:
body_text.section: Differential Diagnoses ::: Retinal folds (N) Retina ::: Congenital ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
• Related to 70% ethanol fixation, and/or relative time differences in tissue
fixation. True retinal folds are differentiated from artifact by an association
with preretinal traction membranes, sub-retinal deposits, hemorrhage, or
aggregates of RPE cells (Render,
Schafer et al. 2013).
body_text.section: Differential Diagnoses ::: Retinal folds (N) Retina ::: Congenital ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Spontaneous retinal folds have been reported in mice and rats (Sprague-Dawley and
Wistar) (Hubert, Gillet et al.
1994). Folds found in Sheffield-Wistar rats may be congenital and
associated with microphthalmia (Poulsom and Hayes 1988). Artifactual retinal folds (Lange’s folds) have
been described in the peripheral retina of young animals, and is associated with
tissue fixation with 70% ethanol (Gartner and Henkind 1981). When retinal
folds are sectioned in a tangential histologic plane they might resemble
rosettes.
body_text.section: Comment ::: Retinal folds (N) Retina ::: Congenital ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Decreased cell layers; retina; decreased thickness, retina.
body_text.section: Other Term(s) Used ::: Retinal Atrophy Retina ::: Acquired ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Degenerative process of the retina resulting in cell loss and collapse of the
retinal layers; atrophy may be specific to the ganglion cell layer and/or inner
nuclear layer, or outer retinal layer due to the susceptibility and sensitivity of
the cell populations in those areas to the inciting cause, or to both (global).
Global atrophy can also be an end-stage lesion associated with secondary
degeneration of retinal cells that progresses from one cell layer to the next.
body_text.section: Histiogenesis/cell of origin ::: Retinal Atrophy Retina ::: Acquired ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Mouse; Rat.
body_text.section:
Species ::: Inner retinal atrophy (N) (Figure
36fig_036fig) Retina ::: Acquired ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Atrophy of the inner retina (inner nuclear, inner plexiform and ganglion cell
layers) may be secondary to increased intraocular pressure, compressive lesions of
the optic nerve, or direct toxicity resulting in degeneration of retinal cells and
eventual cell loss.
body_text.section:
Pathogenesis/cell of origin ::: Inner retinal atrophy (N) (Figure
36fig_036fig) Retina ::: Acquired ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Decreased numbers of ganglion cells.Thinning of the nerve fiber and inner plexiform layers.Loss of nuclei in the inner nuclear layer.
body_text.section:
Diagnostic Features ::: Inner retinal atrophy (N) (Figure
36fig_036fig) Retina ::: Acquired ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
The most common causes of loss of ganglion cells and their axon fibers in the
nerve fiber layer are 1) an increase intraocular pressure resulting in
degeneration of these cells, and subsequent atrophy of the optic nerve and
secondary atrophy of the inner nuclear layer, and 2) compressive lesions on the
extraocular portion of the optic nerve leading to axonal degeneration and
subsequent ganglion cell death. The retinal ganglion cells are target of several
known retinal toxicants (e.g. carbon disulfide, doxorubicin, glutamate and
lidocaine). A few toxicants, like ethylcholine mustard aziridinium ion (AF64A),
preferentially target the cells in the inner nuclear layer (Ramos, Reilly et al. 2011).
body_text.section:
Comment ::: Inner retinal atrophy (N) (Figure
36fig_036fig) Retina ::: Acquired ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Mouse; Rat.
body_text.section: Species ::: Outer retinal atrophy (N) Retina ::: Acquired ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Conditions resulting in atrophy of the outer retinal layers (outer plexiform and
photoreceptor layers) include hereditary or direct photoreceptor injury, and/or
RPE toxicity. Atrophy may be incidental following choroidal circular disturbance
(Tanaka, Inagaki et al.
1993).
body_text.section: Pathogenesis/cell of origin ::: Outer retinal atrophy (N) Retina ::: Acquired ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Decreased numbers of nuclei in the outer nuclear layer, resulting in
decreased thickness of the retina.Decreased thickness or collapse of the outer plexiform layer with fusion of
the inner and outer nuclear layers.Loss of inner and outer segments of the photoreceptors.Displacement of photoreceptor nuclei to the inner and outer segment
layers.Hypertrophy of RPE cells, and possible migration of RPE cells and
macrophages into the sensory retina.
body_text.section: Diagnostic Features ::: Outer retinal atrophy (N) Retina ::: Acquired ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Outer retinal atrophy or degeneration is a broad term that indicates loss of
photoreceptors from a variety of causes that include hereditary, aging, toxicity,
phototoxicity, nutritional deficiencies, retinal detachment, and inflammation.
Photoreceptors have high metabolic demands, and thus are susceptible to toxins
that interfere with energy metabolism, e.g. nicotinamide phosphoribosyltransferase
(NAMPT) inhibitors (Zabka, Singh et
al. 2015). Genetic forms of atrophy occur in several strains of mice,
including several mutant and transgenic mouse strains and rats. Ocular screening
should be conducted prior to study inclusion and animals exhibiting atrophy
removed, or equally distributed amongst dose groups. Photoreceptor degeneration
may occur with remarkable sparing of the inner retinal layers and RPE. Outer
retinal atrophy in rodents is characteristic of senile retinal degeneration, which
has a tendency to begin at the peripheral retina (Hockwin, Green et al. 1992). Light-induced
retinal atrophy/degeneration (usually RPE cells are not affected) occurs in albino
rodents and is caused by prolonged exposure to light or exposure to high intensity
light. These lighting conditions may occur if animals are kept in cages on the top
of racks close to the room light source (De Vera Mudry, Kronenberg et al. 2013).
In contrast, focal atrophy of outer retinal segments following choroidal circular
disturbance is always associated with loss of regional RPE cells (Tanaka, Inagaki et al.
1993).

cite_spans.mention: De Vera Mudry, Kronenberg et al. 2013

body_text.section: Comment ::: Outer retinal atrophy (N) Retina ::: Acquired ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Mouse; Rat.
body_text.section: Species ::: Global retinal atrophy (N) Retina ::: Acquired ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Scar; Glial scar; Diffuse gliosis.
body_text.section: Other Term(s) Used ::: Global retinal atrophy (N) Retina ::: Acquired ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Involvement of all cell layers; end stage retinal lesion regardless of the
initial cause.
body_text.section: Pathogenesis/cell of origin ::: Global retinal atrophy (N) Retina ::: Acquired ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Decreased numbers of cells in all layers and associated collapse of the
plexiform layers.Complete collapse of retinal architecture.Replacement of the retinal tissue by a fibrous layer with glial cells and
occasional neurons.
body_text.section: Diagnostic Features ::: Global retinal atrophy (N) Retina ::: Acquired ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Retinal degeneration may occur as a spontaneous (hereditary, aging, exposure to
light, nutrient deficiency, inflammatory or trauma) or iatrogenic (e.g. laser
treatment, subretinal injection) finding and therefore must be differentiated from
treatment-related toxic effects (Schafer and Render 2013a).
body_text.section: Comment ::: Global retinal atrophy (N) Retina ::: Acquired ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Mouse; Rat.
body_text.section: Species ::: Detachment, retina (N) Retina ::: Acquired ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: None
body_text.section: Other Term(s) Used: ::: Detachment, retina (N) Retina ::: Acquired ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Outer retina; associated with trauma, intravitreal injections, chorioretinal
inflammation, vitreal degeneration and traction resulting from fibroplasia at the
retinal surface (retinal/epiretinal fibroplasia).
body_text.section: Pathogenesis/cell of origin ::: Detachment, retina (N) Retina ::: Acquired ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Separation of the photoreceptor outer segment from the retinal pigmented
epithelium.Subretinal accumulation of fluid, macrophages, red blood cells and cellular
debris.Secondary hypertrophy of the retinal pigmented epithelium (RPE
tombstones).Degeneration/atrophy of the photoreceptor outer segments.
body_text.section: Diagnostic Features ::: Detachment, retina (N) Retina ::: Acquired ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Artifact retinal detachment
body_text.section: Differential Diagnoses ::: Detachment, retina (N) Retina ::: Acquired ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Artifact retinal detachment can be differentiated from true retinal detachment by
the lack of subretinal deposits and absence of hypertrophy of the RPE cells.
Hypertrophy of the RPE needs to be distinguished from RPE “tenting”, an artifact
that result from traumatic shearing of the retina during tissue trimming. In
contrast to RPE hypertrophy, “tented” RPE cells have angular apices with fragments
of photoreceptor outer segments still attached to the surface. Spontaneous retinal
detachment is uncommon in laboratory animals, but may occur rarely in B6C3F1 mice
and Sprague-Dawley rats (Kuno, Usui
et al. 1991).
body_text.section: Comment ::: Detachment, retina (N) Retina ::: Acquired ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Mouse; Rat.
body_text.section: Species ::: Displacement, photoreceptor nuclei (N) Retina ::: Acquired ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Photoreceptor displaced nuclei (PDN); subretinal photoreceptor cells;
colloquially known as “torpedo” cells.
body_text.section: Other Term(s) Used ::: Displacement, photoreceptor nuclei (N) Retina ::: Acquired ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Photoreceptors of the outer nuclear layer; age-related degenerative process of
the photoreceptors.
body_text.section: Pathogenesis/cell of origin ::: Displacement, photoreceptor nuclei (N) Retina ::: Acquired ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Photoreceptor cell located external to the retinal outer limiting
membrane.Cell with scant or no cytoplasm.Nuclei morphology very similar to photoreceptor nuclei in the outer nuclear
layer; may also be pyknotic.
body_text.section: Diagnostic Features ::: Displacement, photoreceptor nuclei (N) Retina ::: Acquired ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Monocytes, (or macrophages):
body_text.section: Differential Diagnoses ::: Displacement, photoreceptor nuclei (N) Retina ::: Acquired ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Larger cells with cytoplasm; may contain melanin or hemosiderin pigment,
and may be associated with inflammation (Lai 1980).
body_text.section: Differential Diagnoses ::: Displacement, photoreceptor nuclei (N) Retina ::: Acquired ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Detached retinal pigment epithelial cells:
body_text.section: Differential Diagnoses ::: Displacement, photoreceptor nuclei (N) Retina ::: Acquired ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Larger cells with cytoplasm; may contain melanin pigment or other
inclusions, and may be associated with detachment of the sensory retina
(Lai 1980).
body_text.section: Differential Diagnoses ::: Displacement, photoreceptor nuclei (N) Retina ::: Acquired ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Artifact
body_text.section: Differential Diagnoses ::: Displacement, photoreceptor nuclei (N) Retina ::: Acquired ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Displacement of photoreceptor nuclei during microtomy.
body_text.section: Differential Diagnoses ::: Displacement, photoreceptor nuclei (N) Retina ::: Acquired ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Displaced photoreceptor nuclei (PDN) occur in humans and laboratory animals
including rats and mice. Both nonpyknotic and pyknotic nuclei may be found in
control eyes (Lai 1980; Lai, Masuda et al. 1982), but also
in areas of retinal degeneration or inflammation, or both (Saunders and Rubin 1975b; Geiss and Yoshitomi 1999).
Displaced nuclei were observed in all strains of rats with a frequency of
approximately 50% in normal retinas; they were observed more frequently in very
young developing retinas and in aged retinas (Lai 1980).
body_text.section: Comment ::: Displacement, photoreceptor nuclei (N) Retina ::: Acquired ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Mouse; Rat.
body_text.section: Species ::: Fibroplasia, Retinal or epiretinal (N) Retina ::: Acquired ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Epiretinal membrane; vitreal traction band
body_text.section: Other Term(s) Used ::: Fibroplasia, Retinal or epiretinal (N) Retina ::: Acquired ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Multiple cell origins have been implicated in fibroplasia at the retinal surface,
including, hyalocytes, fibroblasts, astrocytes, glial cells, and Müller cells.
Cell transdifferntiation occurs as a sequela to disruptions of the vitreous body
or internal limiting membrane, retinal or vitreal inflammation, neovascular
retinal disease or intraocular surgery.
body_text.section: Pathogenesis/cell of origin ::: Fibroplasia, Retinal or epiretinal (N) Retina ::: Acquired ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
A fibrocellular layer carpeting the inner (vitreal) surface of the
retina.Cellular components may be multiple: fibrocytes, glial cells and retinal
pigment epithelial cells.Inflammatory cells can be present when associated with ocular or retinal
inflammation.Small vascular profiles can be present when associated with retinal
vascular proliferations (neovascularization).
body_text.section: Diagnostic Features ::: Fibroplasia, Retinal or epiretinal (N) Retina ::: Acquired ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Histochemical stains for collagen (e.g. Masson’s trichrome or Picrosirius
red) can be useful to highlight the membranes.Immunohistochemistry for cell specific proteins can demonstrate the
different origins of cells present in the membranes. GFAP can be useful to
highlight the presence of glial cell component.
body_text.section: Special Techniques for Diagnostics ::: Fibroplasia, Retinal or epiretinal (N) Retina ::: Acquired ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Pre-retinal arteriolar loop
body_text.section: Differential Diagnoses ::: Fibroplasia, Retinal or epiretinal (N) Retina ::: Acquired ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Fibrosis (Figure 28)
body_text.section: Differential Diagnoses ::: Fibroplasia, Retinal or epiretinal (N) Retina ::: Acquired ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Replacement of the retina with fibrous connective tissue; usually observed
as a reparative process following tissue injury and necrosis.
body_text.section: Differential Diagnoses ::: Fibroplasia, Retinal or epiretinal (N) Retina ::: Acquired ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
‘Epiretinal membrane’ is a clinical term for fibroplasia found at, or on the
retinal surface. Idiopathic epiretinal membranes (iERM) are characterized by the
growth of fibrocellular tissue on the internal limiting membrane (ILM). iERM can
range from subtle cellophane-like films without visual consequences to markedly
contractile membranes that can cause metamorphopsia and decreased visual acuity.
The complete pathogenesis of iERM is unknown, but many theories have been
proposed. The most widely accepted theory is that iERM is a consequence of surface
breaks in the ILM of the retina and forms within the cortical vitreous, which
serves as the structural component and provides a medium upon which glial cells
and hyalocytes can proliferate. Impaired vision can result from retinal traction
and detachment, or impediment of light transmission.
body_text.section: Comment ::: Fibroplasia, Retinal or epiretinal (N) Retina ::: Acquired ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Mouse; Rat.
body_text.section: Species ::: Increased numbers, glial cells (N) Retina ::: Acquired ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Gliosis.
body_text.section: Other Term(s) Used ::: Increased numbers, glial cells (N) Retina ::: Acquired ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Glial cells; proliferation or migration of glial cells may occur in response to
injury or insult, or be incidental.
body_text.section: Pathogenesis/cell of origin ::: Increased numbers, glial cells (N) Retina ::: Acquired ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Localized to the retina around the optic nerve head in incidental lesions.
May occur elsewhere associated with retinal injury.Expanded nerve fiber layer containing cells with elongated nuclei,
fibrillar eosinophilic cytoplasm and indistinct membranes.
body_text.section: Diagnostic Features ::: Increased numbers, glial cells (N) Retina ::: Acquired ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
The cells are immunohistochemically positive for glial fibrillary acidic protein
(GFAP).
body_text.section: Special Techniques for Diagnostics ::: Increased numbers, glial cells (N) Retina ::: Acquired ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Retinal gliosis is seen in rats as a focal lesion localized in the peripapillary
retina (Adams, Auerbach et al.
2011). For diffuse retinal gliosis, refer to Atrophy/degeneration,
Global.
body_text.section: Comment ::: Increased numbers, glial cells (N) Retina ::: Acquired ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Mouse; Rat.
body_text.section: Species ::: Infiltrate, inflammatory cell (N) Retina ::: Acquired ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: None
body_text.section: Other Term(s) Used: ::: Infiltrate, inflammatory cell (N) Retina ::: Acquired ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Most often lymphoid, but may be myeloid. The pathogenesis is uncertain, but
presumably a self-limiting response designed for immune surveillance and minor
tissue repair activities. Lymphocyte infiltrates are often observed with
immunological responses to delivery of foreign antigens (monoclonal antibodies) to
the intraocular space.
body_text.section: Pathogenesis/cell of origin ::: Infiltrate, inflammatory cell (N) Retina ::: Acquired ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Foci of lymphocytes and rare plasma cells surrounding retinal capillaries
within the perivascular space, without other features of inflammation.
body_text.section: Diagnostic Features ::: Infiltrate, inflammatory cell (N) Retina ::: Acquired ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Inflammation:
body_text.section: Differential Diagnoses ::: Infiltrate, inflammatory cell (N) Retina ::: Acquired ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Inflammatory cellular infiltrate associated with edema, congestion,
hemorrhage, necrosis and increased numbers of glial cells (gliosis) of the
retinal tissue.
body_text.section: Differential Diagnoses ::: Infiltrate, inflammatory cell (N) Retina ::: Acquired ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
The term “infiltrate” is recommended followed by the predominant cell type
(neutrophilic, eosinophilic, lymphocytic, plasmacytic or histiocytic) or mixture
of different cell types (mixed). The most predominantly and frequently observed
inflammatory cell infiltrate in the retina is lymphocytic. Small focal to
multifocal lymphocytic infiltrates are thought to be incidental background
findings.
body_text.section: Comment ::: Infiltrate, inflammatory cell (N) Retina ::: Acquired ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Mouse; Rat.
body_text.section: Species ::: Inflammation (N) Retina ::: Acquired ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Retinitis.
body_text.section: Other Term(s) Used ::: Inflammation (N) Retina ::: Acquired ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Inflammation can occur in any cell layer. Inflammation may occur from
immune-mediated etiologies, infectious agents, trauma, be drug-induced, or
experimentally induced.
body_text.section: Pathogenesis/cell of origin ::: Inflammation (N) Retina ::: Acquired ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Inflammatory cellular infiltrate associated with edema, congestion,
hemorrhage and necrosis.Evolves to retinal degeneration and glial cell proliferation (gliosis).Can be associated with inflammation of the choroid, focal retinal
detachment, and loss of photoreceptors.
body_text.section: Diagnostic Features ::: Inflammation (N) Retina ::: Acquired ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Infiltrate, inflammatory cell
body_text.section: Differential Diagnoses ::: Inflammation (N) Retina ::: Acquired ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Spontaneous retinal inflammation is rare in the mouse and rat, but can be seen
unilaterally secondary to trauma. Retinal inflammation usually occurs secondary to
inflammation of the choroid and results in retinal degeneration (Schafer and Render 2013a).
Virally induced retinitis and immune-mediated retinitis are well-known disease
models in mice (Geiss and
Yoshitomi 1999).
body_text.section: Comment ::: Inflammation (N) Retina ::: Acquired ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Mouse; Rat.
body_text.section: Species ::: Mineralization (N) Retina ::: Acquired ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Calcification.
body_text.section: Other Term(s) Used ::: Mineralization (N) Retina ::: Acquired ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Can occur in any cell layer. Mineralization in the retina is presumed to be
associated with a primary vascular wall lesion or be secondary to dystrophic
events in necrotic areas (see Mineralization, Vitreous, above).
body_text.section: Pathogenesis/cell of origin ::: Mineralization (N) Retina ::: Acquired ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Variably sized, often irregular, purple/blue foci in H&E- stained
retinal sections.Vascular walls are usually involved.Laminated appearance (alternating dark and light zones) is typical.
body_text.section: Diagnostic Features ::: Mineralization (N) Retina ::: Acquired ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Von Kossa stain for calcium may be useful in paraffin sections, though the
chelation chemistry (silver nitrate) is not specific for calcium salts; Alizarin
red S may also be used. Nonacidic fixatives such as neutral buffered 10% formalin
or alcohol are best for tissues containing calcium deposits (Bancroft and Gamble 2002).
body_text.section: Special Techniques for Diagnostics ::: Mineralization (N) Retina ::: Acquired ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Deposits, subretina (drusen; associated with RPE).
body_text.section: Differential Diagnoses ::: Mineralization (N) Retina ::: Acquired ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Bone metaplasia
body_text.section: Differential Diagnoses ::: Mineralization (N) Retina ::: Acquired ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Mineralization can be an incidental lesion.
body_text.section: Comment ::: Mineralization (N) Retina ::: Acquired ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Mouse; Rat.
body_text.section: Species ::: Myelin, increased (N) Retina ::: Acquired ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Hypertrophy, myelin.
body_text.section: Other Term(s) Used ::: Myelin, increased (N) Retina ::: Acquired ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Ganglion cells; developmental anomaly that is generally incidental.
body_text.section: Pathogenesis/cell of origin ::: Myelin, increased (N) Retina ::: Acquired ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Presence of myelinated axons in the nerve fiber layer at the central
(peri-papillary) retina.Myelinated axons form small clusters at the retinal surface, and can cause
focal thickening of the retina.
body_text.section: Diagnostic Features ::: Myelin, increased (N) Retina ::: Acquired ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: LFB will stain myelin blue to green and may be useful for diagnosis.
body_text.section: Special Techniques for Diagnostics ::: Myelin, increased (N) Retina ::: Acquired ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Myelinated retinal nerve fibers have been seen more frequently in pigmented rats
and had been described in Long- Evans and BW rats (Rubin 1986; Hubert, Gillet et al. 1994). It is suggested to
represent a developmental rather than a congenital anomaly (Rubin 1986).
body_text.section: Comment ::: Myelin, increased (N) Retina ::: Acquired ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Mouse; Rat.
body_text.section: Species ::: Necrosis; Necrosis, single cell (N) Retina ::: Acquired ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Homogenizing cell change; ischemic cell change; metabolic arrest change; oncotic
necrosis; colloquially known as “red dead” neurons.
body_text.section: Other Term(s) Used ::: Necrosis; Necrosis, single cell (N) Retina ::: Acquired ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Ganglion cell bodies, secondary retinal neurons or photoreceptor cells; recent
cell death, typically affecting multiple retinal neurons.
body_text.section: Pathogenesis/cell of origin ::: Necrosis; Necrosis, single cell (N) Retina ::: Acquired ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Shrunken, often angular ganglion cells with hypereosinophilic cytoplasm in
H&E-stained paraffin sections.Nuclear consolidation, sometimes with shrinkage (early stages).Karyorrhexis or karyolysis (later stages).May see swollen cells, cytoplasmic vacuoles, or cytoplasmic blebs.Necrosis: focal, multifocal or focally extensive regions of the retina
containing necrotic cells and cell debris.
body_text.section: Diagnostic Features ::: Necrosis; Necrosis, single cell (N) Retina ::: Acquired ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Necrotic neurons are specifically labeled by:
body_text.section: Special Techniques for Diagnostics ::: Necrosis; Necrosis, single cell (N) Retina ::: Acquired ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Fluorescent stains (e.g., Fluoro-Jade B or Fluoro- Jade C) (Schmued, Stowers et al.
2005) performed on 5- to 10-µm-thick (i.e., routine)
perfusion-fixed, paraffin embedded sections. Affected cells appear bright
green against a dark field. (Note: erythrocytes that remain in blood vessels
of immersion-fixed specimens will autofluoresce, which may make detection of
necrotic neurons more difficult.).Cupric–silver stains (Switzer
2000) in 30- to 40- mm-thick frozen sections of unfixed tissue.
Affected cells are black against a pale-yellow background.Electron microscopy: condensed, swollen or ruptured mitochondria; swollen
or ruptured lysosomes; disruption of cell membranes.
body_text.section: Special Techniques for Diagnostics ::: Necrosis; Necrosis, single cell (N) Retina ::: Acquired ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Dark neuron artifact:
body_text.section: Differential Diagnoses ::: Necrosis; Necrosis, single cell (N) Retina ::: Acquired ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Evident as spiky basophilic neurons due to shrinkage of both nucleus and
cytoplasm with contracture of the neuronal cell body; often associated with
a prominent, tortuous, basophilic apical dendrite.
body_text.section: Differential Diagnoses ::: Necrosis; Necrosis, single cell (N) Retina ::: Acquired ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Neuronal necrosis is a common end-stage cellular response to irreversible injury.
It may be induced by many causes, but the most common are metabolic dysfunction,
ischemia, or toxicant exposure (chemicals, drugs, or metals). The intracellular
biochemical alterations that ultimately lead to neuron destruction can be
triggered by many different mechanisms, but neuronal necrosis in the retina refers
to the pathway by which disruption of cellular energy systems results in fluid
accumulation within organelles (microvacuolation) and eventually the entire soma
(swelling, or oncosis) rather than the apoptotic cascade. (McMartin, O’Donoghue et al. 1997). Necrosis is
generally associated with inflammation, but can occasionally precede inflammation
such as occurs with a vascular injury (e.g. coagulative necrosis), chronic
hypoxia, or cytotoxic cell death.
body_text.section: Comment ::: Necrosis; Necrosis, single cell (N) Retina ::: Acquired ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Mouse; Rat.
body_text.section: Species ::: Pigment, increased (N) Retina ::: Acquired ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Lipofuscinosis.
body_text.section: Other Term(s) Used ::: Pigment, increased (N) Retina ::: Acquired ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Lipofuscin represents residual bodies derived from autophagosomal lysosomes and
is composed of polymers of lipid and phospholipid complexed with protein.
Lipofuscin accumulates with age in retinal neurons, and is associated with free
radical damage.
body_text.section: Pathogenesis/cell of origin ::: Pigment, increased (N) Retina ::: Acquired ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Presence of brown pigment granules in neuronal cytoplasm, most evident in
ganglion cells, generally of medium-to-large-sized cells.The color of pigment granules varies from faint yellow to dark brown; some
are eosinophilic (ceroid).
body_text.section: Diagnostic Features ::: Pigment, increased (N) Retina ::: Acquired ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Lipofuscin granules may be detected using several special stains: pink
using PAS, pale red to red by Oil Red O, dark blue to purple by LFB, and
pale blue to blue by Schmorl’s technique for melanin; they are also acid
fast by Ziehl-Neelsen.Lapham’s method (Lapham,
Johnstone et al. 1964) is highly specific for neural
lipofuscin.Autofluorescence can be identified in H&E or unstained slides using a
fluorescent microscope.
body_text.section: Special Techniques for Diagnostics ::: Pigment, increased (N) Retina ::: Acquired ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Lipofuscin should not form part of the diagnostic term in the absence of a
confirmatory stain, although it may be mentioned in discussion. Lipofuscin
accumulation results from age-related reductions in the efficiency with which
neural cells eliminate degradation by-products (Kreutzberg, Blakemore, and Graeber 1997).
Lipofuscin arises in the cell bodies of neurons, astrocytes, and oligodendrocytes
by lipid peroxidation in cell membranes. Lipofuscin seems to accumulate without
deleterious effects to the retinal neural cells.
body_text.section: Comment ::: Pigment, increased (N) Retina ::: Acquired ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Mouse; Rat.
body_text.section: Species ::: Vacuolation, cytoplasmic (N) Retina ::: Acquired ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: None
body_text.section: Other Term(s) Used: ::: Vacuolation, cytoplasmic (N) Retina ::: Acquired ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Retinal neurons and Müller cells. Vacuolation occurs from either a degenerative
or toxic process leading to retention of fluid or metabolic byproducts inside a
subcellular compartment, and expansion of intraneuronal cytoplasm or
membrane-bound organelles.
body_text.section: Pathogenesis/cell of origin ::: Vacuolation, cytoplasmic (N) Retina ::: Acquired ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Cytoplasmic vacuolation (usually clear or pale eosinophilic) of ganglion
cells, photoreceptors segments or Müller cells.
body_text.section: Diagnostic Features ::: Vacuolation, cytoplasmic (N) Retina ::: Acquired ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Neuronal vacuoles in some storage diseases or in induced phospholipidosis may be
confirmed by electron microscopy or by using special stains (e.g., Luxol fast blue
[LFB], periodic acid-Schiff [PAS], or Sudan black) to detect a specific
biochemical component within vacuoles.
body_text.section: Special Techniques for Diagnostics ::: Vacuolation, cytoplasmic (N) Retina ::: Acquired ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Vacuolation of retinal neuropil (extracellular edema)
body_text.section: Differential Diagnoses ::: Vacuolation, cytoplasmic (N) Retina ::: Acquired ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Vacuolation artifact due to postmortem autolysis:
body_text.section: Differential Diagnoses ::: Vacuolation, cytoplasmic (N) Retina ::: Acquired ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Improper collection, handling, or fixation of the globe at the time of
necropsy; or prolonged immersion (e.g., over the weekend) in ethanol baths
during tissue dehydration. Artifactual vacuolation should not be recorded in
the pathology findings data set.
body_text.section: Differential Diagnoses ::: Vacuolation, cytoplasmic (N) Retina ::: Acquired ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Hexachlorophene causes vacuolation and degeneration of photoreceptor outer
segments, and chloroquine causes vacuolation in neurons and Müller cells.
body_text.section: Comment ::: Vacuolation, cytoplasmic (N) Retina ::: Acquired ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Mouse; Rat.
body_text.section: Species ::: Vacuolation, extracellular (N) Retina ::: Acquired ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Retinal edema, retinoschisis.
body_text.section: Other Term(s) Used ::: Vacuolation, extracellular (N) Retina ::: Acquired ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Involvement of any retinal layer, often multiple. Degenerative or toxic
processes.
body_text.section: Pathogenesis/cell of origin ::: Vacuolation, extracellular (N) Retina ::: Acquired ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Presence of clear spaces, expanding various retinal layers.May be associated with decreased numbers of cells within the affected
layer.
body_text.section: Diagnostic Features ::: Vacuolation, extracellular (N) Retina ::: Acquired ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Fixation or handling artifact
body_text.section: Differential Diagnoses ::: Vacuolation, extracellular (N) Retina ::: Acquired ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: cell loss:
body_text.section: Differential Diagnoses ::: Vacuolation, extracellular (N) Retina ::: Acquired ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Clear spaces in nuclear layers due to decreased nuclei.Clear spaces in plexiform layers due to loss of cell dentrites and
axons.
body_text.section: Differential Diagnoses ::: Vacuolation, extracellular (N) Retina ::: Acquired ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Extracellular vacuolation in the retina can be observed in multiple degenerative
processes and represent reorganization of the retinal parenchyma after cell loss.
In detached retinas, extensive clear spaces are commonly seen and may represent
tissue edema, which has been erroneously referred to as retinoschisis.
Retinoschisis is splitting of the retina between layers to form large spaces and
may occur with extensive retinal edema.
body_text.section: Comment ::: Vacuolation, extracellular (N) Retina ::: Acquired ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Mouse; Rat.
body_text.section: Species ::: Arteriolar loop, pre-retinal (N) Retina ::: Vascular Changes ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Vascular anomaly
body_text.section: Other Term(s) Used ::: Arteriolar loop, pre-retinal (N) Retina ::: Vascular Changes ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Incidental, abnormal branching of the central retinal artery.
body_text.section: Pathogenesis/cell of origin ::: Arteriolar loop, pre-retinal (N) Retina ::: Vascular Changes ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Arteriole emerging from the central retinal artery, coursing through the
posterior vitreous and reconnecting to the inner retina.Perivascular intravitreal hemorrhage can occur.
body_text.section: Diagnostic Features ::: Arteriolar loop, pre-retinal (N) Retina ::: Vascular Changes ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Serial sections through the tissue might be necessary to track the progression of
the vessel.
body_text.section: Special Techniques for Diagnostics ::: Arteriolar loop, pre-retinal (N) Retina ::: Vascular Changes ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Persistent hyperplastic primary vitreous (PHPV)
body_text.section: Differential Diagnoses ::: Arteriolar loop, pre-retinal (N) Retina ::: Vascular Changes ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Pre-retinal arteriolar loops are common abnormalities in Sprague-Dawley rats
(Tanaka, Inagaki et al.
1994).
body_text.section: Comment ::: Arteriolar loop, pre-retinal (N) Retina ::: Vascular Changes ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Mouse; Rat.
body_text.section: Species ::: Hemorrhage (N) Retina ::: Vascular Changes ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: None.
body_text.section: Other Term(s) Used ::: Hemorrhage (N) Retina ::: Vascular Changes ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Vascular disruption. Depending on size and distribution, either no clinical signs
or extension into the subretinal space leading to retinal detachment and
blindness.
body_text.section: Pathogenesis/cell of origin ::: Hemorrhage (N) Retina ::: Vascular Changes ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Distribution of hemorrhage is usually focal to multifocal but can be
extensive when caused by traumatic events.Retinal hemorrhage often happens in close proximity to the capillaries.Chronic lesions may be associated with hemosiderosis.
body_text.section: Diagnostic Features ::: Hemorrhage (N) Retina ::: Vascular Changes ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Special stains for iron accumulation (e.g. Prussian blue and Perl’s iron stain)
can be used to identify hemosiderin in old sites of hemorrhage.
body_text.section: Special Techniques for Diagnostics ::: Hemorrhage (N) Retina ::: Vascular Changes ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Retinal infarcts
body_text.section: Differential Diagnoses ::: Hemorrhage (N) Retina ::: Vascular Changes ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Retinal hemorrhages can occur in a variety of primary clotting disorders,
thrombocytopenia of any cause, retinal hypertension, inflammatory retinal
conditions, ocular trauma, or from compression to the animal during handling.
body_text.section: Comment ::: Hemorrhage (N) Retina ::: Vascular Changes ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Mouse; Rat.
body_text.section: Species ::: Neovascularization (H) Uvea: Choroid ::: Vascular Changes ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Choroidal neovascularization (CNV).
body_text.section: Other Term(s) Used ::: Neovascularization (H) Uvea: Choroid ::: Vascular Changes ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
New vessel growth from pre-existing vasculature, secondary to an ischemic
process, and/or release of proangiogenic factors (i.e. VEGF).
body_text.section: Pathogenesis/cell of origin ::: Neovascularization (H) Uvea: Choroid ::: Vascular Changes ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Growth of new blood vessels that originate from the choroid through a break
in Bruch’s membrane into the space below the retinal pigment epithelium
(sub-RPE) or into the subretinal space (between the photoreceptors and
RPE).Newly formed blood vessels may infiltrate the retina.Subretinal, retinal, and vitreal hemorrhages can occur.Retinal detachment associated with subretinal hemorrhage.
body_text.section: Diagnostic Features ::: Neovascularization (H) Uvea: Choroid ::: Vascular Changes ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Choroidal and retinal vascular changes are evaluated clinically by vascular
angiography; microscopically, via immunohistochemistry or in situ-hybridization
for angiogenic and endothelial cell markers (e.g., vascular endothelial growth
factor); by microscopic examination of retinal whole mounts, and by transmission
electron microscopy.
body_text.section: Special Techniques for Diagnostics ::: Neovascularization (H) Uvea: Choroid ::: Vascular Changes ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Retinal neovascularization:
body_text.section: Differential Diagnoses ::: Neovascularization (H) Uvea: Choroid ::: Vascular Changes ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Retinal neovascularization is differentiated from CNV by vascular profiles
that extend from the IPL and INL into the outer retinal layers, or from the
IPL and ganglion cell layers into the inner limiting membrane, or by
vascular tufts that project into the vitreous. Neovascular profiles can also
contact the RPE cells and colonize the subretinal space similar to CNV. The
main differential diagnostic feature is the presence of an intact Bruch’s
membrane in retinal neovascularization, suggesting retinal origin of the
vessels. Transmission electron microscopy might be necessary to confirm the
status of Bruch’s membrane.
body_text.section: Differential Diagnoses ::: Neovascularization (H) Uvea: Choroid ::: Vascular Changes ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Neovascularization is spontaneous in the mutant mouse strain JR5558, which
exhibits early, reproducible and spontaneous bilateral CNV, accompanied by
subsequent retinal anastomosis. In this model, chorioretinal parainflammation is
present prior to frank CNV, and is associated with upregulation of VEGF,
hyperpermeability of the choriocapillaris, and neuroglial cell loss/dysfunction
(Nagai, Izumi-Nagai et al.
2011). CNV may also be induced experimentally, e.g. via laser
photocoagulation.
body_text.section: Comment ::: Neovascularization (H) Uvea: Choroid ::: Vascular Changes ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Mouse; Rat.
body_text.section: Species ::: Neovascularization (H) Retina ::: Vascular Changes ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: New blood vessels, retina
body_text.section: Other Term(s) Used ::: Neovascularization (H) Retina ::: Vascular Changes ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Intra-retinal neovascularizationRetinal vascularization proliferation
body_text.section: Other Term(s) Used ::: Neovascularization (H) Retina ::: Vascular Changes ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Secondary to ischemic retinal process, intravitreal release of pro-angiogenic
factors (i.e. VEGF), and chronic retinal degeneration.
body_text.section: Pathogenesis/cell of origin ::: Neovascularization (H) Retina ::: Vascular Changes ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Presence of vascular profiles extending from the IPL and INL into the outer
retinal layers.Presence of vascular profiles extending from the IPL and ganglion cell
layers into the inner limiting membrane and projecting vascular tufts into
the vitreous.Neovascular profiles can contact the RPE cells and colonize the subretinal
space.Subretinal, retinal and vitreal hemorrhages can occur.Subretinal hemorrhage can cause retinal detachment.
body_text.section: Diagnostic Features ::: Neovascularization (H) Retina ::: Vascular Changes ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Retinal vascular changes are evaluated clinically by vascular angiography and
microscopically by trypsin digestion of retinal whole mounts, immunohistochemistry
for endothelial cell markers (e.g., vascular endothelial growth factor) and
transmission electron microscopy.
body_text.section: Special Techniques for Diagnostics ::: Neovascularization (H) Retina ::: Vascular Changes ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Choroidal neovascularization:
body_text.section: Differential Diagnoses ::: Neovascularization (H) Retina ::: Vascular Changes ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Vessels extending from the choroid can breach Bruch’s membrane and
infiltrate the retina. The main differential diagnostic feature is the
presence of an intact Bruch’s membrane, suggesting retinal origin of the
vessels. TEM might be necessary to confirm the status of Bruch’s
membrane.
body_text.section: Differential Diagnoses ::: Neovascularization (H) Retina ::: Vascular Changes ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Retinal neovascular proliferation can be a feature of endstage retinal
degeneration. Retinal neovascularization has been described as a feature of
chronic light induced retinopathy in albino rats (Albert, Neekhra et al. 2010). Vitreal or
subretinal hemorrhage due to retinal neovascularization can also lead to
subretinal or retinal surface fibroplasia, forming membranes.
body_text.section: Comment ::: Neovascularization (H) Retina ::: Vascular Changes ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Mouse; Rat.
body_text.section: Species ::: Atrophy (N) Optic nerve ::: Optic Nerve ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Optic atrophy; optic neuropathy (ischemic).
body_text.section: Other Term(s) Used ::: Atrophy (N) Optic nerve ::: Optic Nerve ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Ganglion cell axon; common response to many types of injuries including primary
axonal injury, ganglion cell loss, optic neuritis, or hypoxia/ischemia.
body_text.section: Pathogenesis/cell of origin ::: Atrophy (N) Optic nerve ::: Optic Nerve ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Marked loss of axons with relative increase in the prominence of the
remaining pial trabeculae (thin bands of collagen arising from the pia mater
that surround the axons).Glial proliferation (see gliosis).Decrease of optic nerve diameter can be observed in cross sections.Posterior bowing of the optic nerve head and lamina cribrosa (cupping of
the optic nerve) can be present if atrophy is associated with chronically
increased intraocular pressure.
body_text.section: Diagnostic Features ::: Atrophy (N) Optic nerve ::: Optic Nerve ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Masson’s trichrome stain can be used to highlight the collagenous tissue of the
pial trabeculae. Luxol fast blue stains myelin blue, and can be used to
demonstrate myelin loss in demyelinating injuries.
body_text.section: Special Techniques for Diagnostics ::: Atrophy (N) Optic nerve ::: Optic Nerve ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Fibrosis of the optic nerve
body_text.section: Differential Diagnoses ::: Atrophy (N) Optic nerve ::: Optic Nerve ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Species differences in the structure of the lamina cribrosa are important when
interpreting the extent of atrophy near the site where the optic nerve passes
through the sclera. Mice have a less robust lamina cribrosa when compared to rats
so the accentuation of the collagenous tissue in optic nerve atrophy is less
evident (Smith, John, and Nishina
2002). Because optic nerve atrophy is a chronic, irreversible response,
it is important to determine the progenitor lesions in toxicological studies
(Ramos, Reilly et al.
2011).
body_text.section: Comment ::: Atrophy (N) Optic nerve ::: Optic Nerve ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Mouse; Rat.
body_text.section: Species ::: Degeneration, axonal (N) Optic nerve ::: Optic Nerve ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Axonopathy; dying-back axonopathy; nerve fiber degeneration; Wallerian-type
degeneration.
body_text.section: Other Term(s) Used ::: Degeneration, axonal (N) Optic nerve ::: Optic Nerve ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Axonal degeneration occurs in several circumstances in the optic nerve. Loss of
ganglion cells, and consequently their axons, secondary to glaucoma is likely the
most common cause (Teixeira and Dubielzig 2013a). Lesions in the orbital or intracranial
portions of the optic nerve can cause Wallerian degeneration with consequent axon
loss and ganglion cell death. Causes for these lesions include trauma leading to
optic nerve crush, severance, or avulsion, and compression caused by tumors,
periosteal proliferation at the optic foramen (where the nerve enters the
calvarium), or granulomatous inflammation (Smith, John, and Nishina 2002).
body_text.section: Pathogenesis/cell of origin ::: Degeneration, axonal (N) Optic nerve ::: Optic Nerve ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Multiple, swollen eosinophilic axons (spheroids) with unaffected myelin
sheaths in the early stage (McMartin, O’Donoghue et al. 1997).Axonal fragmentation with the formation of digestion chambers containing
phagocytic macrophages (gitter cells) and central axonal fragments are
characteristics of the late state lesion.Lesion progresses to optic nerve atrophy (see above).
body_text.section: Diagnostic Features ::: Degeneration, axonal (N) Optic nerve ::: Optic Nerve ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Detailed evaluation of optic nerve axonal degeneration and axonal loss can be
obtained by transmission electron microscopy of optic nerve cross sections (Reynaud, Cull et al. 2012).
Faster methods use plastic- or resin-embedded, p-phenylenediamine (PPD) or
Toluidine blue-stained optic nerve cross sections, light microscopy and
computational image analysis to quantify axon loss (Ebneter, Casson et al. 2012).
body_text.section: Special Techniques for Diagnostics ::: Degeneration, axonal (N) Optic nerve ::: Optic Nerve ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Optic neuritis
body_text.section: Differential Diagnoses ::: Degeneration, axonal (N) Optic nerve ::: Optic Nerve ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Atrophy
body_text.section: Differential Diagnoses ::: Degeneration, axonal (N) Optic nerve ::: Optic Nerve ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Axonal degeneration associated with ageing has been reported in Sprague-Dawley
rats and DBA/2J and AKXD- 28/Ty mice (Anderson, Smith et al. 2001; Cavallotti, Cavallotti et al.
2001).
body_text.section: Comment ::: Degeneration, axonal (N) Optic nerve ::: Optic Nerve ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Mouse; Rat.
body_text.section: Species ::: Demyelination (N) Optic nerve ::: Optic Nerve ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Myelinolysis; myelinopathy.
body_text.section: Other Term(s) Used ::: Demyelination (N) Optic nerve ::: Optic Nerve ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Oligodendroglial cell processes. Disintegration of an otherwise normally formed
myelin sheath without a primary impact to the ensheathed axon.
body_text.section: Pathogenesis/cell of origin ::: Demyelination (N) Optic nerve ::: Optic Nerve ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Reduced myelin staining in demyelinated or hypomyelinated fibers.Intact denuded axons.Formation of myelin ovoids (McMartin, O’Donoghue et al. 1997).
body_text.section: Diagnostic Features ::: Demyelination (N) Optic nerve ::: Optic Nerve ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Conventional stains for myelin (paraffin sections):Luxol Fast Blue (LFB) or solochrome cyanine for myelin (used independently
or in combination with a cresyl violet counterstain for axons), or osmium
tetroxide.In the later stages of demyelination, macrophages containing recently
phagocytosed and partially digested myelin debris may be identified using
LFB/PAS (Periodic acid Schiff) staining (Grant Maxie and Youssef 2007).
Ultrastructural analysis (plastic- or resin-embedded sections), which
enables precise identification of the numbers and thicknesses of myelin
lamellae that surround axons; EM is particularly useful in the
identification of remyelinated axons versus normal axons (McKay, Blakemore et al.
1998; Smith and
Jeffery 2006).
body_text.section: Special Techniques for Diagnostics ::: Demyelination (N) Optic nerve ::: Optic Nerve ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Primary dysmyelination and demyelination affecting the optic nerve are rare in
animals, but multiple mouse models have been developed to study human diseases
such as Pelizaeus-Merzbacher disease (PMD) and multiple sclerosis (MS) (Smith, John, and Nishina
2002).
body_text.section: Comment ::: Demyelination (N) Optic nerve ::: Optic Nerve ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Mouse; Rat.
body_text.section: Species ::: Increased number, glial cells (N) Optic nerve ::: Optic Nerve ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Gliosis; reactive glia; glial hyperplasia; glial hypertrophy.
body_text.section: Other Term(s) Used ::: Increased number, glial cells (N) Optic nerve ::: Optic Nerve ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Microglial cell tissue repair process. Proliferation and/or hypertrophy of any/or
multiple glial cell lineages in response to optic nerve tissue injury.
body_text.section: Pathogenesis/cell of origin ::: Increased number, glial cells (N) Optic nerve ::: Optic Nerve ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Increased numbers and/or size of glial cells; cells are identified as glia
(rather than neurons) using cytoarchitectural characteristics and
location.Increased amount of glial processes.Presence of gitter cells (enlarged macrophage-like cells with abundant
granular to vacuolated cytoplasm).
body_text.section: Diagnostic Features ::: Increased number, glial cells (N) Optic nerve ::: Optic Nerve ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Fibrosis
body_text.section: Differential Diagnoses ::: Increased number, glial cells (N) Optic nerve ::: Optic Nerve ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Inflammation:
body_text.section: Differential Diagnoses ::: Increased number, glial cells (N) Optic nerve ::: Optic Nerve ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: See Inflammation, eye
body_text.section: Differential Diagnoses ::: Increased number, glial cells (N) Optic nerve ::: Optic Nerve ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Glial cells are identified by their cytoarchitectural characteristics and
location. Microglia have a phagocytic role following tissue damage, and are
recognized as gitter cells.
body_text.section: Comment ::: Increased number, glial cells (N) Optic nerve ::: Optic Nerve ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Mouse; Rat.
body_text.section: Species ::: Infiltrate, inflammatory cell (N) Optic nerve ::: Optic Nerve ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Infiltration, inflammatory cell.
body_text.section: Other Term(s) Used ::: Infiltrate, inflammatory cell (N) Optic nerve ::: Optic Nerve ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Primarily mononuclear cells; the cause is uncertain, but presumably an
incidental, self-limiting response designed for immune surveillance and minor
tissue repair activities.
body_text.section: Histiogenesis/cell of origin ::: Infiltrate, inflammatory cell (N) Optic nerve ::: Optic Nerve ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Foci of leukocytes within the optic nerve or optic disc without other
features of inflammation.
body_text.section: Diagnostic Features ::: Infiltrate, inflammatory cell (N) Optic nerve ::: Optic Nerve ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Inflammation:
body_text.section: Differential Diagnoses ::: Infiltrate, inflammatory cell (N) Optic nerve ::: Optic Nerve ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Inflammatory cellular infiltrate with associated inflammatory features such
as edema, congestion, hemorrhage, necrosis and gliosis of optic nerve
neuropil.
body_text.section: Differential Diagnoses ::: Infiltrate, inflammatory cell (N) Optic nerve ::: Optic Nerve ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
The term “infiltrate” is recommended followed by the predominant cell type
(neutrophilic, eosinophilic, lymphocytic, plasmacytic or histiocytic) or mixture
of different cell types (mixed). The most predominantly and frequently observed
inflammatory cell infiltrate in the optic nerve is lymphocytic. Small, focal to
multifocal aggregates of lymphocyte infiltrates are thought to be incidental
background findings.
body_text.section: Comment ::: Infiltrate, inflammatory cell (N) Optic nerve ::: Optic Nerve ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Mouse; Rat.
body_text.section: Species ::: Inflammation (N) Optic nerve ::: Optic Nerve ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Optic neuritis; optic nerve neuritis.
body_text.section: Other Term(s) Used ::: Inflammation (N) Optic nerve ::: Optic Nerve ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Leukocytes of any lineage associated with an inflammatory response.
body_text.section: Histiogenesis/cell of origin ::: Inflammation (N) Optic nerve ::: Optic Nerve ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye
