body_text.text:
Leukocyte infiltration within the optic nerve or optic disc with other
features of inflammation.Inflammatory features such as edema, congestion, hemorrhage, necrosis and
increased numbers of glial cells (gliosis) are also present.
body_text.section: Diagnostic Features ::: Inflammation (N) Optic nerve ::: Optic Nerve ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Infiltrate, inflammatory cell:
body_text.section: Differential Diagnoses ::: Inflammation (N) Optic nerve ::: Optic Nerve ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: See above.
body_text.section: Differential Diagnoses ::: Inflammation (N) Optic nerve ::: Optic Nerve ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Inflammation is the preferred diagnostic term when inflammatory features are
present, with the appropriate modifiers used to identify the predominant cell
type. Immune-mediated inflammation that is predominantly lymphocytic may be
observed in the optic nerve and nerve head following the ocular administration of
biologics that are recognized as foreign proteins by the immune system. Optic
neuritis is a clinical term designating a swollen optic nerve disc from any cause
when viewed on ophthalmoscopy and should not be used as a histological
diagnosis.
body_text.section: Comment ::: Inflammation (N) Optic nerve ::: Optic Nerve ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Mouse; Rat.
body_text.section: Species ::: Vacuolation (N) Optic nerve ::: Optic Nerve ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Myelin splitting; axon swelling; myelin edema; Wallerian degeneration.
body_text.section: Other Term(s) Used ::: Vacuolation (N) Optic nerve ::: Optic Nerve ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Separation of myelin sheaths surrounding axons, or cytoplasmic swelling of glial
cells.
body_text.section: Pathogenesis/cell of origin ::: Vacuolation (N) Optic nerve ::: Optic Nerve ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Clear spaces within the optic nerve.Irregular enlargement of axons observed in longitudinal sections.
body_text.section: Diagnostic Features ::: Vacuolation (N) Optic nerve ::: Optic Nerve ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Myelin defects may be demonstrated using Luxol blue staining.
body_text.section: Special Techniques for Diagnostics ::: Vacuolation (N) Optic nerve ::: Optic Nerve ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Fixation artifact
body_text.section: Differential Diagnoses ::: Vacuolation (N) Optic nerve ::: Optic Nerve ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Demyelination
body_text.section: Differential Diagnoses ::: Vacuolation (N) Optic nerve ::: Optic Nerve ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Degenerative changes in myelin can occur spontaneously with aging or result from
trauma, toxicity, or inflammatory conditions.
body_text.section: Comment ::: Vacuolation (N) Optic nerve ::: Optic Nerve ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Mouse; Rat.
body_text.section: Species ::: Atrophy (N) Retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) ::: Retinal Pigment Epithelium (RPE) ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Decreased numbers of RPE cells; RPE cell loss.
body_text.section: Other Term(s) Used ::: Atrophy (N) Retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) ::: Retinal Pigment Epithelium (RPE) ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
RPE cell loss often occurs as a generalized aging process that leads to cell
degeneration and eventual cell death.
body_text.section: Pathogenesis/cell of origin ::: Atrophy (N) Retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) ::: Retinal Pigment Epithelium (RPE) ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Regions that exhibit reduced RPE cell count, or areas of Bruch’s membrane
that may be devoid of overlying RPE.Remaining cells may be attenuated, spreading laterally to compensate for
any spatial defects in an attempt to maintain the blood-retinal barrier
(BRB) and homeostasis.Remaining RPE tend to have features of degeneration (cell enlargement and
irregular pigmentation).
body_text.section: Diagnostic Features ::: Atrophy (N) Retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) ::: Retinal Pigment Epithelium (RPE) ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Chronic atrophy of RPE is associated with degeneration and atrophy of the
adjacent retina. Because the BRB has been breached, there may be associated
subretinal edema and inflammation, or subretinal fibroplasia (formation of
subretinal membranes).
body_text.section: Comment ::: Atrophy (N) Retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) ::: Retinal Pigment Epithelium (RPE) ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Mouse; Rat.
body_text.section:
Species ::: Deposits, extracellular matrix, subretina (N) Retinal pigment epithelium
(RPE) ::: Retinal Pigment Epithelium (RPE) ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Drusen; drusen-like deposits
body_text.section:
Other Term(s) Used ::: Deposits, extracellular matrix, subretina (N) Retinal pigment epithelium
(RPE) ::: Retinal Pigment Epithelium (RPE) ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Impaired function of the RPE associated with the metabolism of photoreceptor
outer segments.
body_text.section:
Pathogenesis/cell of origin ::: Deposits, extracellular matrix, subretina (N) Retinal pigment epithelium
(RPE) ::: Retinal Pigment Epithelium (RPE) ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Extracellular deposits of irregular, amorphous material located between RPE
and Bruch’s membrane (Pow and
Diaz 2008).Often associated with enlarged and/or degenerating RPE containing numerous,
prominent pigmented granules.May be associated with loss of RPE polarity, RPE and retinal detachment,
and/or subretinal or retinal edema.
body_text.section:
Diagnostic Features ::: Deposits, extracellular matrix, subretina (N) Retinal pigment epithelium
(RPE) ::: Retinal Pigment Epithelium (RPE) ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: RPE degeneration or necrosis
body_text.section:
Differential Diagnoses ::: Deposits, extracellular matrix, subretina (N) Retinal pigment epithelium
(RPE) ::: Retinal Pigment Epithelium (RPE) ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Drusen are extracellular deposits composed primarily of apolipoproteins derived
from RPE metabolism of the outer segments of photoreceptors, and from members of
the compliment system (particularly factor H) derived from plasma (Hageman, Luthert et al. 2001).
Drusen contain zinc, which is thought to have a role in the precipitation and
activation of the complement system (Lengyel, Flinn et al. 2007). These amorphous
deposits may accumulate due to impaired transport of the debris through Bruch’s
membrane into the choroidal circulation. Drusen is a clinical diagnosis that
characterizes these findings, and should be avoided as a histological diagnosis.
Drusen are associated with age-related macular degeneration, and thus are rarely
observed in species other than primates. However, ‘hard’ drusen (concentric,
nodular mass, with well-defined borders; may be mineralized) do occur infrequently
in some species other than humans.
body_text.section:
Comment ::: Deposits, extracellular matrix, subretina (N) Retinal pigment epithelium
(RPE) ::: Retinal Pigment Epithelium (RPE) ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Mouse; Rat.
body_text.section:
Species ::: Fibroplasia, subretinal (N) Retinal pigment epithelium
(RPE) ::: Retinal Pigment Epithelium (RPE) ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Subretinal membranes; subretinal fibrosis; fibrous metaplasia; RPE migration.
body_text.section:
Other Term(s) Used ::: Fibroplasia, subretinal (N) Retinal pigment epithelium
(RPE) ::: Retinal Pigment Epithelium (RPE) ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Migration, proliferation, and transdifferentiation of RPE in response to injury,
and increased production of resident growth factors and cytokines such as TGFβ.
Individual RPE cells become fusiform, reminiscent of fibroblasts or
myofibroblasts, proliferate, and migrate.
body_text.section:
Pathogenesis/cell of origin ::: Fibroplasia, subretinal (N) Retinal pigment epithelium
(RPE) ::: Retinal Pigment Epithelium (RPE) ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Linear arrays of fibroblastic-like cells arranged in a membranous mat
between the retina and Bruch’s membrane.Cellular component may be derived from multiple lineages: fibroblasts,
hyalocytes, glial cells, Müller cells, and RPE.Inflammatory cells are present when there is associated inflammation.Small vascular profiles can be present spontaneously, or induced
(neovascularization) as in laser models.Contraction of membranes can cause buckling of the adjacent retina, and
result in retinal detachments.
body_text.section:
Diagnostic Features ::: Fibroplasia, subretinal (N) Retinal pigment epithelium
(RPE) ::: Retinal Pigment Epithelium (RPE) ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Histochemical stains for collagen (e.g. Masson’s trichome or Picrosirius
red) can be useful to highlight membranes.Immunohistochemistry for GFAP or RPE65 can be used to demonstrate the
presence of glial cells and RPE, respectively in the membranes.
body_text.section:
Special Diagnositic Techniques ::: Fibroplasia, subretinal (N) Retinal pigment epithelium
(RPE) ::: Retinal Pigment Epithelium (RPE) ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Choroidal Neovascularization
body_text.section:
Differential Diagnosis ::: Fibroplasia, subretinal (N) Retinal pigment epithelium
(RPE) ::: Retinal Pigment Epithelium (RPE) ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: See retinal neovascularization, below.
body_text.section:
Differential Diagnosis ::: Fibroplasia, subretinal (N) Retinal pigment epithelium
(RPE) ::: Retinal Pigment Epithelium (RPE) ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
“Subretinal membranes” is a clinical term for fibroplasia occurring in the
subretinal space, and in humans they tend to be associated with neovascularization
in age-related macular degeneration (AMD). They are rare in non-primate species,
but can be experimentally induced using lasers. Membranes may be secondary to
subretinal hemorrhage, retinal or choroidal inflammation, neovascular retinal or
choroidal disease, or intraocular surgery. Osseous metaplasia (RPE metaplasia to
an osseous phenotype) is a variation and is not well understood (Toyran, Lin et al. 2005).
Subretinal membranes can be the cause of retinal detachment or develop secondary
to retinal detachment, especially in cases of subretinal hemorrhage. More
extensive subretinal fibroplasia that infiltrates and partially replaces the
retina (retinal fibrosis) is usually secondary to traumatic inuury, such as
scleral rupture.
body_text.section:
Comment ::: Fibroplasia, subretinal (N) Retinal pigment epithelium
(RPE) ::: Retinal Pigment Epithelium (RPE) ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Mouse; Rat.
body_text.section: Species ::: Hypertrophy, RPE (N) Retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) ::: Retinal Pigment Epithelium (RPE) ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Enlarged RPE; increased size, RPE.
body_text.section: Other Term(s) Used ::: Hypertrophy, RPE (N) Retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) ::: Retinal Pigment Epithelium (RPE) ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
RPE enlargement occurs with cellular disease, toxicity, or aging processes due to
increase in size and number of organelles, enlargement of smooth endoplasmic
reticulum (increased activity), or accumulation of lipofuscin. Occasional random
cells may be enlarged without apparent reason.
body_text.section: Pathogenesis/cell of origin ::: Hypertrophy, RPE (N) Retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) ::: Retinal Pigment Epithelium (RPE) ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
RPE cells are larger than typical on light microscopy and may have unusual
pigmentation.Melanin may be reduced or irregularly distributed within the cell, or may
fuse with lipofuscin to form conjugates with different pigmentation that
appears granular.On electron microscopy, enlargement of smooth endoplasmic reticulum, and
increased numbers of lysosomes or lipofuscin granules may be observed.
body_text.section: Diagnostic Features ::: Hypertrophy, RPE (N) Retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) ::: Retinal Pigment Epithelium (RPE) ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Hypertrophy is often associated with detachment of the retina or photoreceptor
death, and may progress to RPE detachment, transdifferentiation, and migration.
Druginduced hypertrophy often presents as uniformly enlarged RPE that are closely
apposed to the retina. In some cases, such as with some β-secretase inhibitors,
hypertrophied RPE will autofluoresce (Fielden et al 2015).
body_text.section: Comment ::: Hypertrophy, RPE (N) Retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) ::: Retinal Pigment Epithelium (RPE) ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Mouse; Rat.
body_text.section:
Species ::: Inclusions (intracytoplasmic accumulation), RPE (N) Retinal pigment
epithelium (RPE) ::: Retinal Pigment Epithelium (RPE) ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
RPE degeneration; vacuolation; lysosomes; lipofuscin or lipofuscinosis; retinal
lipidosis (Ivanina, Zueva et al.
1983); myeloid bodies (Peräsalo, Rechardt et al. 1974); residual bodies (DAmico et al. 1984).
body_text.section:
Other Term(s) Used ::: Inclusions (intracytoplasmic accumulation), RPE (N) Retinal pigment
epithelium (RPE) ::: Retinal Pigment Epithelium (RPE) ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
RPE impaired degradation of shed photoreceptor outer segments is associated with
aging processes, but may also occur with enzyme deficiency of some genetic
diseases, or with toxicity, such as chloroquine (Ivanina, Zueva et al. 1983) or cationic
amphiphilic compounds (DAmico et
al. 1984).
body_text.section:
Pathogenesis/cell of origin ::: Inclusions (intracytoplasmic accumulation), RPE (N) Retinal pigment
epithelium (RPE) ::: Retinal Pigment Epithelium (RPE) ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
RPE cells are generally enlarged on light microscopy, and have increased
numbers of pigmented granules.RPE may have loss of polarity, and be detached from Bruch’s membrane.Abnormal organelles containing concentric membranous whorls can be found in
the RPE cytoplasm on electron microscopy (Gregory, Rutty et al. 1970; Matsumura, Yamakawa et al.
1986; Gaafar,
Abdel-Khalek et al. 1995); membranes may have lamellated
(fingerprint-like) appearance reminiscent of the outer segments of
photoreceptors, and are osmophilic due to the phospholipid content of the
membranes (Peräsalo,
Rechardt, and Palkama 1974).
body_text.section:
Diagnostic Features ::: Inclusions (intracytoplasmic accumulation), RPE (N) Retinal pigment
epithelium (RPE) ::: Retinal Pigment Epithelium (RPE) ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Lysosomes:
body_text.section:
Differential Diagnoses ::: Inclusions (intracytoplasmic accumulation), RPE (N) Retinal pigment
epithelium (RPE) ::: Retinal Pigment Epithelium (RPE) ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Lysosomes containing lipofuscin appear auto-fluorescent on fundic
examination, and should be differentiated from drusen (sub-RPE, or Bruch’s
membrane deposits) that also contain lipofuscin or other autofluorescent
pigments.
body_text.section:
Differential Diagnoses ::: Inclusions (intracytoplasmic accumulation), RPE (N) Retinal pigment
epithelium (RPE) ::: Retinal Pigment Epithelium (RPE) ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Vacuolation may also be associated with abnormal accumulation of lipofuscin or
other pigments that are metabolic by-products of RPE processing of shed
photoreceptor outer segments. Lipofuscin, and lipofuscin conjugates (i.e.
melanolipofuscin) often accumulate in the base of the RPE cytoplasm as granules.
These are best observed on fundic examination, and appear as autofluorescent
particles. Lipofuscin may not survive routine tissue processing and thus may not
be observed on brightfield light microscopy unless associated with other
organelles or proteins. Instead, clear vacuoles generally remain, representing the
presence of cellular accumulations. Lipofuscin accumulates spontaneously with age,
due to impaired ability to properly remove the granules from the cell, and may
also occur with toxicities (Brown
1974; Hughes and
Coogan 1974; Fox and Chu
1988; Butler, Ford, and
Newberne 1987). Occasionally, cytoplasmic crystals may be observed (Caine et al. 1975).
body_text.section:
Comment ::: Inclusions (intracytoplasmic accumulation), RPE (N) Retinal pigment
epithelium (RPE) ::: Retinal Pigment Epithelium (RPE) ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Mouse; Rat.
body_text.section: Species ::: Necrosis (N) Retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) ::: Retinal Pigment Epithelium (RPE) ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: None.
body_text.section: Other Term(s) Used ::: Necrosis (N) Retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) ::: Retinal Pigment Epithelium (RPE) ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: RPE cell death can be induced by any number of causes.
body_text.section: Pathogenesis/cell of origin ::: Necrosis (N) Retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) ::: Retinal Pigment Epithelium (RPE) ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
RPE are subject to light-induced oxidative injury, in addition to chronic
oxidative stress related to their metabolic role in photoreceptor maintenance.
body_text.section: Pathogenesis/cell of origin ::: Necrosis (N) Retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) ::: Retinal Pigment Epithelium (RPE) ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Loss of cell morphology; granular cell debris in absence of RPE, extending
into the subretinal space.Pyknotic or absent nuclei.Retinal detachment; subretinal edema may occur in locations of necrosis,
due to loss of blood-retinal barrier.
body_text.section: Diagnostic Features ::: Necrosis (N) Retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) ::: Retinal Pigment Epithelium (RPE) ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
RPE degeneration and necrosis can occur spontaneously associated with the
accumulation of lipofuscin, vitamin A dimers, and other by-products of the visual
cycle that promote free-radical injury. RPE impairment is thought to have a
critical role in age-related degeneration of the retina. The RPE contribution to
the blood-retinal barrier and transport mechanisms between the vasculature and
retina render them vulnerable to toxicities from systemically administered
compounds (iodates, L-Ornithine hydrochloride, naphthalene). Free-radical damage
can be enhanced through melanin binding, such as occurs with heavy metals and
amines. In addition, RPE degeneration and subsequent necrosis can occur secondary
to photoreceptor injury.
body_text.section: Comment ::: Necrosis (N) Retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) ::: Retinal Pigment Epithelium (RPE) ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Mouse; Rat.
body_text.section:
Species ::: Pigmentation, decreased (N) (Figure
50fig_050fig) Retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) ::: Retinal Pigment Epithelium (RPE) ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Hypopigmentation; depigmentation; pigmentary incontinence.
body_text.section:
Other Term(s) Used ::: Pigmentation, decreased (N) (Figure
50fig_050fig) Retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) ::: Retinal Pigment Epithelium (RPE) ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Reduced pigmentation (reduced numbers of pigment granules) within RPE. Only
relevant in pigmented species or strains.
body_text.section:
Pathogenesis/cell of origin ::: Pigmentation, decreased (N) (Figure
50fig_050fig) Retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) ::: Retinal Pigment Epithelium (RPE) ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
The number of melanin granules within individual RPE is reduced; RPE are
not uniformly affected, but more commonly involve regional or focal
changes.Melanosomes may assume uncharacteristic shape or size.Cytoplasmic distribution of melanin granules may be altered.
body_text.section:
Diagnostic Features ::: Pigmentation, decreased (N) (Figure
50fig_050fig) Retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) ::: Retinal Pigment Epithelium (RPE) ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Loss of RPE melanin occurs spontaneously as an age-related change. It may also be
associated with some toxicities that result in melanin binding, including some
metals and amines (Boulton 1988).
Melanin may also be taken up by lysosomes and/or fuse with lipofuscin, resulting
in apparent diffusion of pigment. Photobleaching of melanosomes also results in
diminished pigmentation, although the granules are still present.
body_text.section:
Comment ::: Pigmentation, decreased (N) (Figure
50fig_050fig) Retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) ::: Retinal Pigment Epithelium (RPE) ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Mouse; Rat.
body_text.section:
Species ::: Pigmentation, increased (N) Retinal pigment epithelium
(RPE) ::: Retinal Pigment Epithelium (RPE) ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Hyperpigmentation; increased numbers of pigment granules.
body_text.section:
Other Term(s) Used ::: Pigmentation, increased (N) Retinal pigment epithelium
(RPE) ::: Retinal Pigment Epithelium (RPE) ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Melanin gradually decreases as an age-related change. However, lipofuscin
accumulates with age, and can fuse with melanin, resulting in the presence of
increased numbers of brown, pigmented granules. Lipofuscin is derived from the
metabolism of the outer segments shed from photoreceptors (see above), and
consists of lipids and fluorescent compounds that impart a yellow-brown
auto-fluorescence characteristic to the granules.
body_text.section:
Pathogenesis/cell of origin ::: Pigmentation, increased (N) Retinal pigment epithelium
(RPE) ::: Retinal Pigment Epithelium (RPE) ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Increased numbers of intracytoplasmic granules that are light brown on
light microscopy.Pigment may be autofluorescent if lipofuscin remains following
processing.Cytoplasmic granules may be increased in size and exhibit abnormal
distribution throughout the cell.
body_text.section:
Diagnostic Features ::: Pigmentation, increased (N) Retinal pigment epithelium
(RPE) ::: Retinal Pigment Epithelium (RPE) ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Lipofuscin is best visualized on fundic imaging, as it is frequently lost during
tissue processing.
body_text.section:
Comment ::: Pigmentation, increased (N) Retinal pigment epithelium
(RPE) ::: Retinal Pigment Epithelium (RPE) ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Mouse; Rat.
body_text.section: Species ::: Polarity, loss, RPE (N) Retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) ::: Retinal Pigment Epithelium (RPE) ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Dedifferentiation; detachment/disorganization/degeneration, RPE.
body_text.section: Other Term(s) Used ::: Polarity, loss, RPE (N) Retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) ::: Retinal Pigment Epithelium (RPE) ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
In response to cell injury or degeneration (see above), RPE cells lose
attachments to adjacent cells and to Bruch’s membrane.
body_text.section: Pathogenesis/cell of origin ::: Polarity, loss, RPE (N) Retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) ::: Retinal Pigment Epithelium (RPE) ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
RPE cells are individualized or form aggregates that are separated from
Bruch’s membrane, residing in the sub-retinal space.RPE cells assume a round to polygonal shape; apical microvilli and basal
infoldings are lacking.On electron microscopy, there may be decreased phagosomes observed, but
more often, if associated with degeneration, there are numerous lysosomes
containing membranes, lipofuscin or melanolipofuscin granules, and decreased
or irregular shaped melanosomes.Retinal detachment is associated, and eventual retinal atrophy occurs.
body_text.section: Diagnostic Features ::: Polarity, loss, RPE (N) Retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) ::: Retinal Pigment Epithelium (RPE) ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Loss of polarity is associated with loss of integrity of the BRB and retinal
homeostasis. Thus, there may be subretinal fluid, retinal edema, and in chronic
cases, retinal degeneration and/or atrophy. Loss of polarity is associated with
cell migration, however, as this is a primary degenerative process, cellular
transdifferentiation does not occur, and subretinal fibroplasia is not a
sequela.
body_text.section: Comment ::: Polarity, loss, RPE (N) Retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) ::: Retinal Pigment Epithelium (RPE) ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Mouse; Rat.
body_text.section: Species ::: Atrophy (N) Sclera ::: Sclera ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Staphyloma.
body_text.section: Other Term(s) Used ::: Atrophy (N) Sclera ::: Sclera ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye
Pathogenesis/cell of origin ::: Atrophy (N) Sclera ::: Sclera ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: The sclera is focally or diffusely thinned.Connective tissue may have a sclerotic appearance.
body_text.section: Diagnostic Features ::: Atrophy (N) Sclera ::: Sclera ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Atrophy of the sclera usually occurs secondary to other changes such as
enlargement of the eye due to glaucoma or tumor formation, or as a sequela to
inflammation. Atrophy can also occur as a degenerative age-related change.
Staphyloma is a clinical term, and consists of a break in the sclera with prolapse
of intraocular tissues.
body_text.section: Comment ::: Atrophy (N) Sclera ::: Sclera ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Mouse; Rat.
body_text.section: Species ::: Infiltrate, inflammatory cell (N) Sclera ::: Sclera ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Generally limited to lymphocytes.
body_text.section: Pathogenesis/cell of origin ::: Infiltrate, inflammatory cell (N) Sclera ::: Sclera ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Loose or scattered infiltrates within the sclera wall, generally oriented
in perivascular spaces.
body_text.section: Diagnostic Features ::: Infiltrate, inflammatory cell (N) Sclera ::: Sclera ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Occasionally mononuclear cell infiltrates may be observed in the connective
tissue surrounding the globe, and extending into the sclera.
body_text.section: Comment ::: Infiltrate, inflammatory cell (N) Sclera ::: Sclera ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Mouse; Rat.
body_text.section: Species ::: Inflammation (N) Sclera ::: Sclera ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Scleritis; scleral inflammation.
body_text.section: Other Term(s) Used ::: Inflammation (N) Sclera ::: Sclera ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Depending on the inciting cause, inflammation may be composed of mixed
inflammatory cells with neutrophils predominating, mononuclear to histiocytic
cells, or granulomatous.
body_text.section: Pathogenesis/cell of origin ::: Inflammation (N) Sclera ::: Sclera ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Infiltrates of inflammatory cells are oriented in the perivascular spaces
of vessels that penetrate the sclera.Edema, congestion, necrosis and cell debris are associated findings.
body_text.section: Diagnostic Features ::: Inflammation (N) Sclera ::: Sclera ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Scleral inflammation does not occur independently, but occurs with inflammation
in neighboring areas of the eye. The only known exception is that of toxicity
associated with exposure to bisphosphonates which produces scleritis in human
patients after intravenous administration. Scleritis may also occur as a
manifestation of systemic connective tissue disease (French and Margo 2008). Due to a lack of a
primary blood supply, inflammation is slow to resolve and may culminate in
necrosis.
body_text.section: Comment ::: Inflammation (N) Sclera ::: Sclera ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Mouse; Rat.
body_text.section: Species ::: Metaplasia, bone or cartilage (N) Sclera ::: Sclera ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Osseous metaplasia; cartilaginous metaplasia, transdifferentiation.
body_text.section: Other Term(s) Used ::: Metaplasia, bone or cartilage (N) Sclera ::: Sclera ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Spontaneous formation of bone or cartilage in the sclera.
body_text.section: Pathogenesis/cell of origin ::: Metaplasia, bone or cartilage (N) Sclera ::: Sclera ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Focal or multifocal plaques of immature woven bone or foci of cartilage
occurring within the sclera.
body_text.section: Diagnostic Features ::: Metaplasia, bone or cartilage (N) Sclera ::: Sclera ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Osteoma; Chondroma;
body_text.section: Differential Diagnoses ::: Metaplasia, bone or cartilage (N) Sclera ::: Sclera ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Mineralization (see Figure 26)
body_text.section: Differential Diagnoses ::: Metaplasia, bone or cartilage (N) Sclera ::: Sclera ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Osseous metaplasia is a common alteration in aging F344 rats, although
cartilaginous metaplasia is rarely observed (Yoshitomi and Boorman 1990). Bone or
cartilage formation can also occur secondary to trauma.
body_text.section: Comment ::: Metaplasia, bone or cartilage (N) Sclera ::: Sclera ::: Retina ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

Cornea/Conjunctiva ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Choriostomatous tissue (normal tissue in abnormal location), presumably arising
from an ectodermal anlage.
body_text.section:
Pathogenesis/cell of origin ::: Dermoid, ocular (H) Cornea: Conjunctiva ::: Nonneoplastic Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye:
Cornea/Conjunctiva ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Grossly, lesion appears as an elevated white plaque with numerous fine
hairs.Lesions contain components of skin such as hair follicles, sebaceous glands
and fibrous connective tissue beneath a stratified squamous epithelium which
covers the lesion.
body_text.section:
Diagnostic Features ::: Dermoid, ocular (H) Cornea: Conjunctiva ::: Nonneoplastic Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye:
Cornea/Conjunctiva ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Epithelial cyst:
body_text.section:
Differential Diagnoses ::: Dermoid, ocular (H) Cornea: Conjunctiva ::: Nonneoplastic Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye:
Cornea/Conjunctiva ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Lined by stratified squamous epithelium with an innermost layer of
keratinizing cells; dermal appendages are not observed in the wall.
body_text.section:
Differential Diagnoses ::: Dermoid, ocular (H) Cornea: Conjunctiva ::: Nonneoplastic Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye:
Cornea/Conjunctiva ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Ocular dermoid is a rare lesion of the cornea and/or conjunctiva of the rat. This
lesion is not considered to be a neoplasm.
body_text.section:
Comment ::: Dermoid, ocular (H) Cornea: Conjunctiva ::: Nonneoplastic Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye:
Cornea/Conjunctiva ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Mouse; Rat.
body_text.section:
Species ::: Hyperplasia/hypertrophy, endothelium (H) Cornea: Conjunctiva ::: Nonneoplastic Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye:
Cornea/Conjunctiva ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Endothelialization, associated with production of Descemet’s membrane.
body_text.section:
Other Term(s) Used ::: Hyperplasia/hypertrophy, endothelium (H) Cornea: Conjunctiva ::: Nonneoplastic Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye:
Cornea/Conjunctiva ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Abnormal proliferation and migration of corneal endothelial cells over the
trabecular meshwork and iris. Compensatory endothelial cell hypertrophy can be
observed with endothelial cell loss in attempts to cover spatial defects,
particularly in species where hyperplasia is not known to occur.
body_text.section:
Pathogenesis/cell of origin ::: Hyperplasia/hypertrophy, endothelium (H) Cornea: Conjunctiva ::: Nonneoplastic Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye:
Cornea/Conjunctiva ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Spindle-shaped cells covering the iridocorneal drainage angle and/or anterior
surface of the iris.Associated with production of thickened Descemet’s membrane-like
material.Enlarged cells, often observed on the peripheral margins of the
endothelium.
body_text.section:
Diagnostic Features ::: Hyperplasia/hypertrophy, endothelium (H) Cornea: Conjunctiva ::: Nonneoplastic Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye:
Cornea/Conjunctiva ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
In rodents, the corneal endothelium has regenerative capacity throughout life,
usually in response to injury. Endothelial cell hypertrophy associated with
age-related cellular loss is observed in many species, including mouse and rat.
Endothelialization is reported to occur in DBA/2J and AKXD-28/Ty mice (Smith, Sundberg, and John
2002a).
body_text.section:
Comment ::: Hyperplasia/hypertrophy, endothelium (H) Cornea: Conjunctiva ::: Nonneoplastic Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye:
Cornea/Conjunctiva ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Mouse; Rat.
body_text.section:

5fig_005fig) Cornea: Conjunctiva ::: Nonneoplastic Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye:
Cornea/Conjunctiva ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: None

Cornea/Conjunctiva ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Epithelial cells of the cornea, conjunctiva (bulbar and palpebral), or lacrimal
duct.
body_text.section:
Pathogenesis/cell of origin ::: Hyperplasia, squamous cell (H) (Figure
5fig_005fig) Cornea: Conjunctiva ::: Nonneoplastic Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye:
Cornea/Conjunctiva ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Increased cell layers of squamous epithelium with exophytic and/or endophytic
(rete-peg-like) growth pattern.Often associated with epithelial hyperkeratosis.Underlying stroma often infiltrated by inflammatory cells (especially in case
of reactive hyperplasia).
body_text.section:
Diagnostic Features ::: Hyperplasia, squamous cell (H) (Figure
5fig_005fig) Cornea: Conjunctiva ::: Nonneoplastic Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye:
Cornea/Conjunctiva ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Papilloma, squamous cell:
body_text.section:
Differential Diagnoses ::: Hyperplasia, squamous cell (H) (Figure
5fig_005fig) Cornea: Conjunctiva ::: Nonneoplastic Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye:
Cornea/Conjunctiva ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Characterized by exophytic growth and composed of fronds of squamous
epithelium covering a fibrovascular core. Epithelium is retained by a basement
membrane.
body_text.section:
Differential Diagnoses ::: Hyperplasia, squamous cell (H) (Figure
5fig_005fig) Cornea: Conjunctiva ::: Nonneoplastic Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye:
Cornea/Conjunctiva ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Carcinoma, squamous cell:
body_text.section:
Differential Diagnoses ::: Hyperplasia, squamous cell (H) (Figure
5fig_005fig) Cornea: Conjunctiva ::: Nonneoplastic Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye:
Cornea/Conjunctiva ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Malignant neoplasm exhibiting invasion of the underlying stroma, cellular
atypia and dysplasia, as well as dyskeratosis, formation of epithelial keratin
‘pearls’ and mitotic activity.
body_text.section:
Differential Diagnoses ::: Hyperplasia, squamous cell (H) (Figure
5fig_005fig) Cornea: Conjunctiva ::: Nonneoplastic Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye:
Cornea/Conjunctiva ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Spontaneous corneal and/or conjunctival epithelial hyperplasias are rare lesions.
Reactive hyperplasia is more common, resulting from many causes, including topically
applied chemical and physical irritants; systemically administered toxins; reduced
tear production; bacterial, viral, or fungal infections; nutritional deficiencies;
heritable defects; and exophthalmos due to space-occupying orbital masses. In these
cases, stromal inflammation, neovascularization, and/or fibrosis are often
concurrently present.
body_text.section:
Comment ::: Hyperplasia, squamous cell (H) (Figure
5fig_005fig) Cornea: Conjunctiva ::: Nonneoplastic Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye:
Cornea/Conjunctiva ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Mouse; Rat.
body_text.section: Species ::: Proliferation, trabecular meshwork (TM) (H) FA/TM ::: Filtration Angle/Trabecular Meshwork ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Migration, TM cell; activation, TM cell.
body_text.section: Other Term(s) Used ::: Proliferation, trabecular meshwork (TM) (H) FA/TM ::: Filtration Angle/Trabecular Meshwork ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Universal response of TM cells regardless of the injury or irritating stimuli, e.g.
laser photocoagulation, phagocytic particle insult, or noxious agents. TM cell
activation has been associated with a heightened metabolic state needed for the
phagocytosis of debris entering the meshwork (Ramos, Attar et al. 2017).
body_text.section: Pathogenesis/cell of origin ::: Proliferation, trabecular meshwork (TM) (H) FA/TM ::: Filtration Angle/Trabecular Meshwork ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Increased numbers of trabecular shaped cells in the filtration angle and
overlying the TM.TM cells may be linearly arrayed in multiple, irregular layers overlying the
trabeculae.
body_text.section: Diagnostic Features ::: Proliferation, trabecular meshwork (TM) (H) FA/TM ::: Filtration Angle/Trabecular Meshwork ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Mononuclear cell infiltrate:
body_text.section: Differential Diagnoses ::: Proliferation, trabecular meshwork (TM) (H) FA/TM ::: Filtration Angle/Trabecular Meshwork ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: • Mononuclear leukocytes can be found within the filtration angle.
body_text.section: Differential Diagnoses ::: Proliferation, trabecular meshwork (TM) (H) FA/TM ::: Filtration Angle/Trabecular Meshwork ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
TM response to injury is limited. If adequate scaffolding remains following minimal
damage (transient elevation in intraocular pressure, mild laser beam application),
TM cell migration and proliferation, and reorganization of the trabeculae are
possible. Activated TM cells may form distinct spindle shapes expressing α-SMA,
synthesize new basement membrane and other collagens, and become phagocytotic (Rohen and van der Zypen
1968; Lütjen-Drecoll
1972; Grierson, Unger et
al. 2000).
body_text.section: Comment ::: Proliferation, trabecular meshwork (TM) (H) FA/TM ::: Filtration Angle/Trabecular Meshwork ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Ocular melanosis.

body_text.text: Aggregates of polygonal melanocytes filled with pigment.Minimal or no cellular atypia.Minimal displacement of normal structures.
body_text.section: Diagnostic Features ::: Hyperplasia, melanocyte (H) Uvea ::: Uvea ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Melanocyte hyperplasia has been reported in the rat (Ackermann et al. 1998).
body_text.section: Comment ::: Hyperplasia, melanocyte (H) Uvea ::: Uvea ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Proliferation of the epithelium (normally a single layer) to form focal or
multifocal nodules or aggregates of epithelial cells under the anterior lens
capsule.Possible migration and proliferation of the epithelium under the posterior
portion of the lens capsule.
body_text.section:
Diagnostic Features ::: Hyperplasia, lens epithelium (H) (Figures
18fig_018fig, 56fig_056fig) Lens ::: Lens ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

Differential Diagnoses ::: Hyperplasia, lens epithelium (H) (Figures
18fig_018fig, 56fig_056fig) Lens ::: Lens ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Injury to the lens may result in epithelial cell proliferation and/or
transformation to myofibroblasts.

Comment ::: Hyperplasia, lens epithelium (H) (Figures

Species ::: Hyperplasia, RPE (H) (Figure 49fig_049fig)
Retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) ::: Retinal Pigment Epithelium (RPE) ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: RPE proliferation.
body_text.section:
Other Term(s) Used: ::: Hyperplasia, RPE (H) (Figure 49fig_049fig)
Retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) ::: Retinal Pigment Epithelium (RPE) ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Hyperplasia occurs as focal populations of RPE that proliferate in response to lost
or damaged cells or inflammation (Machemer and Laqua 1975).
body_text.section:
Pathogenesis/cell of origin ::: Hyperplasia, RPE (H) (Figure 49fig_049fig)
Retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) ::: Retinal Pigment Epithelium (RPE) ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
RPE hyperplasia is often observed as focal proliferations of jumbled cell
layers that undermine the adjacent retina.Involved cells generally lack polarity and may be loosely attached to
adjacent cells or to Bruch’s membrane.On electron microscopy, hyperplastic RPE cells generally have large vesicular
nuclei, scant cytoplasmic organelles, few melanosomes, and reduced numbers of
apical microvilli (Lee and
Valentine 1991).
body_text.section:
Diagnostic Features ::: Hyperplasia, RPE (H) (Figure 49fig_049fig)
Retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) ::: Retinal Pigment Epithelium (RPE) ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
RPE hyperplasia may lead to degeneration of the adjacent retina due to impaired
capacity to support the metabolic needs of the retina, and subsequent loss of
homeostasis. Proliferation of RPE can also be associated with retinal detachment
(McMartin et al.
1992).
body_text.section:
Comment ::: Hyperplasia, RPE (H) (Figure 49fig_049fig)
Retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) ::: Retinal Pigment Epithelium (RPE) ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.section: Other Term(s) Used: ::: Papilloma, squamous cell (B) Cornea: Conjunctiva ::: Cornea/Conjunctiva ::: Neoplastic Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Epithelial cells of the cornea, conjunctiva (bulbar and palpebral), or the
lacrimal duct.
body_text.section: Pathogenesis/cell of origin ::: Papilloma, squamous cell (B) Cornea: Conjunctiva ::: Cornea/Conjunctiva ::: Neoplastic Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Exophytic growth with development of multiple branched fronds composed of a
lining of variably keratinized squamous epithelium and a variably developed
vascular connective tissue core.Cells are retained by a basement membrane without invasion into the
underlying tissues.No cellular dysplasia observed. No or only slight mitotic activity.
body_text.section: Diagnostic Features ::: Papilloma, squamous cell (B) Cornea: Conjunctiva ::: Cornea/Conjunctiva ::: Neoplastic Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Carcinoma, squamous cell:
body_text.section: Differential Diagnoses ::: Papilloma, squamous cell (B) Cornea: Conjunctiva ::: Cornea/Conjunctiva ::: Neoplastic Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Malignant neoplasm exhibiting invasion of the underlying stroma, cellular
atypia and dysplasia as well as dyskeratosis, formation of epithelial
keratin ‘pearls’ and mitotic activity.
body_text.section: Differential Diagnoses ::: Papilloma, squamous cell (B) Cornea: Conjunctiva ::: Cornea/Conjunctiva ::: Neoplastic Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Squamous cell papillomas are rare neoplasms of the cornea and conjunctiva, but
have been induced in rats by exposure to vapors of certain carcinogens. A variant
of this neoplasm, an inverted mucoepidermoid papilloma, has been reported in a
F344/N rat, exhibiting a downward growth pattern of proliferating superficial
conjunctival epithelium with prominent squamous metaplasia (Yoshitomi and Boorman 1994).
body_text.section: Comment ::: Papilloma, squamous cell (B) Cornea: Conjunctiva ::: Cornea/Conjunctiva ::: Neoplastic Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Mouse; Rat.
body_text.section: Species ::: Carcinoma, squamous cell (M) Cornea: Conjunctiva ::: Cornea/Conjunctiva ::: Neoplastic Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: None
body_text.section: Other Term(s) Used: ::: Carcinoma, squamous cell (M) Cornea: Conjunctiva ::: Cornea/Conjunctiva ::: Neoplastic Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Epithelial cells of the cornea, conjunctiva (bulbar and palpebral), or the
lacrimal duct.
body_text.section: Pathogenesis/cell of origin ::: Carcinoma, squamous cell (M) Cornea: Conjunctiva ::: Cornea/Conjunctiva ::: Neoplastic Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Mass composed of cords and nests of neoplastic squamous cells with variable
amounts of keratinization.Neoplastic cells are large, have abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm, and round
to oval vesicular nuclei with prominent nucleoli.Neoplastic cells penetrate the basement membrane, invade the underlying
corneal stroma and adjacent tissues, and form areas of dyskeratosis and
keratin ‘pearls’.Features of malignancy include lack of differentiation, numerous mitogenic
figures, loss of intercellular bridges and metastasis.
body_text.section: Diagnostic Features ::: Carcinoma, squamous cell (M) Cornea: Conjunctiva ::: Cornea/Conjunctiva ::: Neoplastic Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Papilloma, squamous cell:
body_text.section: Differential Diagnoses ::: Carcinoma, squamous cell (M) Cornea: Conjunctiva ::: Cornea/Conjunctiva ::: Neoplastic Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Characterized by exophytic growth and composed of fronds of squamous
epithelium covering a fibrovascular core. Epithelium is retained by a
basement membrane.
body_text.section: Differential Diagnoses ::: Carcinoma, squamous cell (M) Cornea: Conjunctiva ::: Cornea/Conjunctiva ::: Neoplastic Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
In contrast to domestic animals (cattle, horses, cats), squamous cell carcinoma
is a rare neoplasm in the rat.
body_text.section: Comment ::: Carcinoma, squamous cell (M) Cornea: Conjunctiva ::: Cornea/Conjunctiva ::: Neoplastic Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.section: Species ::: Leiomyoma, uveal (B) Uvea ::: Uvea ::: Neoplastic Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: None
body_text.section: Other Term(s) Used: ::: Leiomyoma, uveal (B) Uvea ::: Uvea ::: Neoplastic Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Smooth muscle cells of either the iris dilatator or sphincter muscles
(neuroectodermal) or from ciliary muscle or muscles of the uveal arterioles
(mesodermal).
body_text.section: Pathogenesis/cell of origin ::: Leiomyoma, uveal (B) Uvea ::: Uvea ::: Neoplastic Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
The neoplasm is composed of closely packed interlacing bundles and whorls
(sometimes around blood vessels) of spindle-shaped cells with eosinophilic
granular cytoplasm and elongated to oval nuclei.Myofibrils are demonstrated by phosphotungstic/acid hematoxylin stain
(PTAH) (Owen and Duprat
1991).
body_text.section: Diagnostic Features ::: Leiomyoma, uveal (B) Uvea ::: Uvea ::: Neoplastic Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Melanoma, uveal, malignant:
body_text.section: Differential Diagnoses ::: Leiomyoma, uveal (B) Uvea ::: Uvea ::: Neoplastic Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Differentiation by light microscopic features may be difficult as both
neoplasms are composed of spindle-shaped cells with formation of
perivascular whorls. Leiomyoma react positive to desmin on
immunohistochemistry, and may be differentiated from melanoma cells, which
are negative. Ultrastructurally, leiomyoma cells have cytoplasmic
myofibrils, focal cytoplasmic densities and surface-connected vesicles,
whereas melanoma cells contain stage II melanosomes.
body_text.section: Differential Diagnoses ::: Leiomyoma, uveal (B) Uvea ::: Uvea ::: Neoplastic Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Schwannoma, intraocular, malignant:
body_text.section: Differential Diagnoses ::: Leiomyoma, uveal (B) Uvea ::: Uvea ::: Neoplastic Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Leiomyomas are frequent tumors of the soft tissue, however, few uveal leiomyomas
have been reported. Diagnosis should be confirmed by immunohistochemistry and/or
electron microscopy.
body_text.section: Comment ::: Leiomyoma, uveal (B) Uvea ::: Uvea ::: Neoplastic Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Mouse; Rat.
body_text.section: Species ::: Melanoma, uveal (M) Uvea ::: Uvea ::: Neoplastic Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Melanoma, amelanotic; Melanoma, intraocular, malignant.
body_text.section: Other Term(s) Used ::: Melanoma, uveal (M) Uvea ::: Uvea ::: Neoplastic Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Neuroectodermal from uveal melanocytes.
body_text.section: Pathogenesis/cell of origin ::: Melanoma, uveal (M) Uvea ::: Uvea ::: Neoplastic Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Generally unilateral lesion of the anterior uvea, but may also be located
in the choroid; uveal melanomas may invade the cornea, conjunctiva, sclera,
retina and orbit.Neoplasms can be composed of spindle-shaped (most common type), epithelioid
or mixed cells.Spindle-shaped cells arranged in bundles and whorls with perivascular
orientation, indistinct cell borders, scant to moderate cytoplasm, fusiform
nuclei and indistinct nucleoli.Epithelioid cells have ill-defined cell borders, pale-staining cytoplasm,
and large oval nuclei with or without nucleoli; large epithelioid cells
(rare) have large bizarre nuclei with nucleoli.Melanin granules are present in the cytoplasm in varying numbers.Necrotic areas may be present.Mitotic figures may be numerous in some neoplasms; argyrophilic fibers are
present along with a few cells containing yellow-brown pigment.
body_text.section: Diagnostic Features ::: Melanoma, uveal (M) Uvea ::: Uvea ::: Neoplastic Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: (none described in mice).
body_text.section: Differential Diagnoses ::: Melanoma, uveal (M) Uvea ::: Uvea ::: Neoplastic Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Leiomyoma, uveal:
body_text.section: Differential Diagnoses ::: Melanoma, uveal (M) Uvea ::: Uvea ::: Neoplastic Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Also composed of spindle-shaped cells with perivascular orientation. Can be
differentiated immunohistochemically: leiomyomas are positive for desmin and
negative for S-100 protein; melanoma shows opposite immunoreactivity.
body_text.section: Differential Diagnoses ::: Melanoma, uveal (M) Uvea ::: Uvea ::: Neoplastic Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Schwannoma, intraocular, malignant:
body_text.section: Differential Diagnoses ::: Melanoma, uveal (M) Uvea ::: Uvea ::: Neoplastic Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Composed of S-100 positive spindle-shaped cells. Differentiation
electromicroscopically by demonstration of pericytoplasmic basal lamina,
attenuated long cellular processes, and desmosomes.
body_text.section: Differential Diagnoses ::: Melanoma, uveal (M) Uvea ::: Uvea ::: Neoplastic Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Spontaneous melanomas in rodents are apparently extremely rare. There are no
reports of benign melanomas in albino or pigmented mice and rats; malignant
amelanotic melanomas in albino mice; spontaneous epithelioid anterior uveal
melanomas; or uveal melanomas in pigmented strains of rats. However, there are
several chemicals known to induce intraocular melanomas in laboratory animals
(Ernst et al. 1991).
Extraocular metastasis of uveal melanomas is rare. In humans, uveal melanomas are
the most common primary intraocular tumors in adults (Everitt and Shadduck 1991).
body_text.section: Comment ::: Melanoma, uveal (M) Uvea ::: Uvea ::: Neoplastic Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
In rats the diagnosis of uveal melanomas is aided by immunohistochemical
demonstration of a positive reaction in the neoplastic cells for S-100 protein and
vimentin intermediate filaments and a negative reaction for cytokeratin, desmin
and glial fibrillary acid protein (GFAP). Ellipsoid premelanosomes (stage II
melanosomes) could be demonstrated in electron micrographs of cells of a rat with
amelanotic uveal melanoma. Since the main differential diagnosis is malignant
schwannoma, which can be positive for S-100 protein as well, electron microscopy
appears to be the best diagnostic method for differentiating these two neoplasms.
Schwannomas, especially the “melanotic variant” may contain melanosomes;
convoluted, moderately thin cytoplasmic processes lined by a continuous basal
lamina are diagnostic for schwannomas.
body_text.section: Comment ::: Melanoma, uveal (M) Uvea ::: Uvea ::: Neoplastic Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Mouse; Rat.
body_text.section: Species ::: Schwannoma, intraocular (M) Uvea ::: Uvea ::: Neoplastic Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Neurilemmoma, malignant; neurinoma, malignant.
body_text.section: Other Term(s) Used ::: Schwannoma, intraocular (M) Uvea ::: Uvea ::: Neoplastic Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Schwann cells of intraocular ciliary nerves.
body_text.section: Pathogenesis/cell of origin ::: Schwannoma, intraocular (M) Uvea ::: Uvea ::: Neoplastic Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Found in the iris and can involve the ciliary body, and fill the anterior
chamber. Local invasion may occur into the cornea. Schwannomas can also be
found in the optic nerve.Plump spindle-shaped cells with abundant eosinophilic vacuolated cytoplasm;
cells are arranged in parallel rows and form palisades around vessels.Nuclei are normochromatic oval to short elongate, varying slightly in size.
Some cells have a small eosinophilic nucleolus.Mitotic figures may be numerous; may contain multiple areas of
necrosis.
body_text.section: Diagnostic Features ::: Schwannoma, intraocular (M) Uvea ::: Uvea ::: Neoplastic Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Melanoma, uveal, malignant:
body_text.section: Differential Diagnoses ::: Schwannoma, intraocular (M) Uvea ::: Uvea ::: Neoplastic Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
The spindle shaped cells of the malignant schwannoma are arranged in a
perivascular fascicular pattern, whereas the spindle cells of the uveal
melanoma are arranged in a perivascular whorl pattern. In electron
micrographs melanoma cells contain cytoplasmic stage II premelanosomes.
body_text.section: Differential Diagnoses ::: Schwannoma, intraocular (M) Uvea ::: Uvea ::: Neoplastic Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Leiomyoma, uveal:
body_text.section: Differential Diagnoses ::: Schwannoma, intraocular (M) Uvea ::: Uvea ::: Neoplastic Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Uveal leiomyoma should have a positive immunoreactivity for desmin and a
negative immunoreactivity for S-100 protein (Chandra and Frith 1993). In electron
micrographs, cells of uveal leiomyoma have cytoplasmic myofibrosils, focal
cytoplasmic densities, and surface-connected vesicles.
body_text.section: Differential Diagnoses ::: Schwannoma, intraocular (M) Uvea ::: Uvea ::: Neoplastic Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Schwannoma occur frequently in the nervous system of rats and mice. However, they
are considered rare spontaneous neoplasms of the globes of rats. Intraocular
schwannoma show positive immunoreactivity for S-100 protein.
Electromicroscopically, the cells have long thin cellular processes with
desmosomes, and a pericytoplasmic partial to complete basal lamina.
body_text.section: Comment ::: Schwannoma, intraocular (M) Uvea ::: Uvea ::: Neoplastic Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Pathogenesis/Cell of origin: Dependent on primary neoplasm.
body_text.section: Secondary tumors ::: Neoplastic Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Differential diagnosis: Dependent on primary neoplasm.
body_text.section: Secondary tumors ::: Neoplastic Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Comments: Malignant lymphoma originating in the spleen, lymph nodes
and/or thymus has been seen in B6C3F1 mice. Lymphomas are found primarily in the
choroid, and can be associated with retinal detachment. Harderian gland carcinomas may
also invade the globe, as can fibrosarcoma induced by the injection of
20-methylcholanthrene into the orbit. Secondary hemangiosarcoma has also been reported
(Geiss and Yoshitomi
1999).
body_text.section: Secondary tumors ::: Neoplastic Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.section: Pathogenesis/cell of origin ::: Meningioma, benign (B) Optic nerve ::: Optic Nerve ::: Neoplastic Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Meningiomas that have been reported in rats have exhibited features of malignant
meningiomas, as described below.
body_text.section: Comment ::: Meningioma, benign (B) Optic nerve ::: Optic Nerve ::: Neoplastic Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Mouse; Rat.
body_text.section: Species ::: Meningioma, malignant (M) Optic nerve ::: Optic Nerve ::: Neoplastic Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Meningeal sarcoma.
body_text.section: Other Term(s) Used ::: Meningioma, malignant (M) Optic nerve ::: Optic Nerve ::: Neoplastic Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Stromal cells of the meninges.
body_text.section: Pathogenesis/cell of origin ::: Meningioma, malignant (M) Optic nerve ::: Optic Nerve ::: Neoplastic Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Meningiomas of the optic nerve of rats have exhibited characteristics of the
malignant form, including local invasion and a high mitotic rate (but without
metastasis). They have an epithelioid pattern (meningothelial type), which is rare
in the cranial cavity. The epithelioid pattern is characterized by pleomorphic
spindle cells with pale eosinophilic cytoplasm, arranged in a whorling pattern,
often with perivascular orientation and resembling Hassall’s corpuscles of the
thymus. Mineralization may be present, but no typical psammoma bodies are
observed. Giant cells may be present, some occasionally containing intranuclear
cytoplasmic herniations appearing as vacuoles. Foci of necrosis with cholesterol
clefts have been seen. Meningiomas of the optic nerve may or may not be S100
positive, and their ultrastructure features consist of interdigitating cellular
processes and desmosomes (Yoshitomi and Boorman 1990; (Yoshitomi, Everitt, and Boorman 1991).
body_text.section: Comment ::: Meningioma, malignant (M) Optic nerve ::: Optic Nerve ::: Neoplastic Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Mouse; Rat.
body_text.section: Species ::: Schwannoma, benign (B) Optic nerve ::: Optic Nerve ::: Neoplastic Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text: Neurilemmoma; neurinoma.
body_text.section: Other Term(s) Used ::: Schwannoma, benign (B) Optic nerve ::: Optic Nerve ::: Neoplastic Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
Schwann cells (myelinating cells of peripheral nerves) considered to be of
neuroectodermal origin but capable of facultative differentiation to express
mesenchymal properties.
body_text.section: Pathogenesis/cell of origin ::: Schwannoma, benign (B) Optic nerve ::: Optic Nerve ::: Neoplastic Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye

body_text.text:
The reported schwannoma in a rat exhibited malignant characteristics, as
described below.
body_text.section: Comment ::: Schwannoma, benign (B) Optic nerve ::: Optic Nerve ::: Neoplastic Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye ::: Terminology and Descriptions ::: I. Nonproliferative and Proliferative Lesions of the Rat and Mouse Eye
